419,"<summary>
• The federal government is the largest producer, collector, and user of information in the US
• Federal agencies collect personal information like name, address, and SSNs for various missions
• SSA administers income support programs and maintains wage and earnings information
• SSA adopted Regulation No. 1 in 1937 to protect privacy and confidentiality of records
• Amendments to the Social Security Act in 1939 reinforced the regulation
• Subsequent legislation like the FOIA and Government in the Sunshine Act caused SSA to reexamine its disclosure policy
• The Privacy Act of 1974 governs the protection of personal privacy by federal agencies
• The act regulates the collection, maintenance, use, and disclosure of personal information
• Agencies must inform individuals of the authority for collection, purpose, routine uses, and consequences of not providing information
• The Privacy Act authorizes 12 exceptions for disclosure without consent
• Agencies are required to keep an accurate accounting of each disclosure of a record
• Agencies must retain the accounting for at least 5 years or the life of the record
• SSA's disclosure policy is more restrictive than most federal agencies
• SSA shares information with law enforcement under certain conditions
• SSA considers factors like nature of criminal activity before disclosing information
• SSA's disclosure policy is contained in 20 C.F.R. Part 401 and is promulgated through regulations
• POMS provides detailed guidance for field offices on disclosure decisions
• Emergency Messages provide implementing guidance in emergency situations
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"
420,"<summary>
• The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) aims to minimize threats to human health and the environment from hazardous waste.

column2: • RCRA governs the management of hazardous waste from generation to disposal.

column1: • EPA has established criteria for identifying hazardous waste, including specific types and characteristics.

column2: • Waste from both current and past industrial operations is regulated under RCRA.

column1: • RCRA requirements can negatively affect cleanups, with land disposal restrictions, minimum technological requirements, and permit requirements posing significant barriers.

column2: • Compliance with land disposal restrictions can be costly and complex, especially for large volumes of waste.

column1: • The unitary approach would exempt all remediation waste from RCRA requirements, potentially saving $2.1 billion in cleanup costs annually.

column2: • Stakeholders disagree on the extent to which states should be authorized to manage remediation waste.

column1: • EPA has developed policy and regulatory alternatives to mitigate the impact of RCRA requirements on cleanups, but stakeholders have raised concerns about their applicability and legal defensibility.

column2: • EPA has proposed comprehensive regulatory reform through the Hazardous Waste Identification Rule for Contaminated Media (HWIR-Media), but plans to withdraw the proposal due to disagreements among stakeholders.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '•'}"
421,"<summary>
* Medicare program integrity activities were previously funded under Medicare's general administrative budget and performed by insurance companies under contract with CMS.

column2: * Funding constraints limited the ability of contractors to conduct audits and review medical claims.
* HIPAA established the Medicare Integrity Program (MIP) in 1997, providing dedicated funding for program integrity activities.

column1: * MIP funds are primarily allocated to support contractors' program integrity efforts for fee-for-service Medicare.

column2: * Contractors include fiscal intermediaries, carriers, Program Safeguard Contractors (PSCs), and Medicare administrative contractors (MACs).
* MACs were introduced in 2011 to replace intermediaries and carriers.

column1: * MIP funds support activities such as audits, medical review, secondary payer identification, benefit integrity, and provider education.

column2: * CMS increased funding for provider education by 590% from 1997 to 2005.
* Expenditures for medical review increased by 40% during the same period.

column1: * CMS plans to use additional funding provided under DRA to address potential fraud, waste, and abuse in the Medicare prescription drug benefit.

column2: * CMS is developing initiatives to measure the effectiveness of audit and provider education activities.
* The agency is transitioning to MACs and increasing the use of MIP funds for award payments to encourage superior performance.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
422,"<summary>
• TSA has had long-standing concerns about the performance of passenger and checked baggage screeners in detecting threat objects at airports.

column2: • In the late 1990s, screeners' abilities to detect dangerous objects declined as testing objects became more realistic.

column1: • After the 9/11 attacks, the Aviation and Transportation Security Act was signed into law to strengthen aviation security.

column2: • ATSA created TSA as an agency responsible for securing all modes of transportation, including aviation.

column1: • TSA oversees security operations at over 450 commercial airports, classifying them into security risk categories based on various factors.

column2: • TSA implemented a basic screener training program with classroom instruction and on-the-job training.

column1: • TSA faced challenges in providing access to recurrent training due to staffing shortages and lack of high-speed Internet/intranet connectivity at some training facilities.

column2: • TSA developed an Online Learning Center with self-guided training courses and hands-on training tools.

column1: • TSA has taken steps to enhance the training of screeners and screening supervisors but has encountered difficulties in providing access to recurrent training.

column2: • TSA has implemented leadership and technical training programs for Screening Supervisors.

423,"<summary>
* IRS operates a network of 10,000 customer service representatives at 25 call sites around the country.

column2: * The network was established in 1999 as a single call center providing round-the-clock service.
* Calls are routed based on the shortest hold times among representatives assigned to specific issues.
* The Operations Center manages the network, forecasting call demand and developing staffing requirements.

column1: * IRS expanded its toll-free network coverage in January 1999 to operate 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.

column2: * Call sites are responsible for recruiting, training, and assigning customer service representatives.
* Staffing requirements are developed weekly with input from call sites.
* IRS employed nearly 10,000 customer service representatives in October 2000.

column1: * IRS faces challenges in determining staffing levels for its toll-free telephone customer service operations.

column2: * IRS has not established a long-term service-level goal based on taxpayer needs.
* The agency annually determines funding levels based on balancing taxpayer assistance and compliance efforts.
* IRS plans to set strategic goals and staff to meet those goals in the future.

column1: * IRS faces challenges in recruiting, training, retaining, and scheduling customer service representatives.

column2: * Challenges include difficulties in recruiting due to job characteristics and training representatives on a broad range of topics.
* IRS is developing a national recruiting strategy to target recruiting efforts.
* IRS is working on providing just-in-time training and specializing training for specific taxpayer groups.

column1: * IRS faces challenges in evaluating its human capital management practices.

column2: * Evaluations focus on short-term improvements rather than long-term strategic planning.
* IRS needs to establish a system for assessing competency gaps and identifying refresher training needs.
* The agency is working on implementing an automated system for forecasting demand and scheduling staff.

425,"<summary>
• DOD has reversed $592 million of illegal and improper adjustments out of $615 million identified in a prior report

column3: • DOD and GAO cannot determine the remaining corrections needed after reversals
• DFAS Columbus estimates over 21,000 hours needed to correct accounting for 30 contracts
• Reversals of adjustments have led to identification of additional errors that must be corrected
• Air Force officials have initiated an investigation into circumstances surrounding illegal adjustments

column1: • DOD reported $1.9 billion of closed account adjustments in fiscal year 2001, with $172 million found to be illegal or improper

column2: • DOD agreed to reverse and correct the $172 million of adjustments

column3: • Additional reviews of $1.1 billion of adjustments planned to be completed by December 31, 2002
• Reaudits and corrections for fiscal year 2001 adjustments not expected to be completed until September 2004

column1: • DOD has made improvements to controls to prevent illegal adjustments, resulting in an 80% reduction in closed account adjustments in the first 6 months of fiscal year 2002

column2: • DFAS upgraded CRS to prevent illegal adjustments

column3: • DFAS officials believe the reduction in adjustments is due to increased management emphasis on resolving problems
• $253,212 of illegal adjustments were identified and corrected after system upgrade

column1: • Options for Congress to consider include prohibiting adjustments to closed accounts or allowing a limited period for adjustments after account closure

column2: • Taking no legislative action at this time and monitoring DOD's implementation of controls is one option

column3: • Amending the account closing law to prohibit adjustments or allowing a limited adjustment period are other options
• DOD's sustained commitment to addressing financial management problems is crucial for long-term success

column1: • GAO recommends DOD to complete reviews and corrections of illegal adjustments, reverse and correct fiscal year 2001 adjustments, and continue monitoring for future adjustments

column2: • DOD agreed with recommendations and outlined ongoing actions to address illegal adjustments

column3: • DFAS Columbus estimates over 9,000 hours needed to correct accounting for one contract with $210 million of unnecessary adjustments

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
426,"<summary>
• The Internet has grown in importance for American businesses and consumers, supporting commerce and vital services.

column2: • The domain name system ensures the uniqueness of each e-mail and Web site address.

column1: • The U.S. government supported the implementation of the domain name system and began transitioning technical responsibility to the private sector in 1998.

column2: • The Department of Commerce issued a general statement of policy known as the ""White Paper"" to guide the transition.

column1: • ICANN made progress in increasing competition by certifying more registrars and reducing the cost of securing domain names.

column2: • However, progress was slower in addressing other guiding principles such as stability, security, and representation in domain name policy-making.

column1: • Efforts to enhance the stability and security of the Internet, formalize relationships with entities involved in running the domain name system, and increase representation have been behind schedule.

column2: • ICANN faced challenges in implementing the transition and needed fundamental reform.

column1: • The Department of Commerce has oversight of the transition process and is responsible for determining ICANN's capability to manage the domain name system.

column2: • The Department's public assessment of the transition progress has been limited, with informal oversight and no specific status reports issued.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '•'}"
427,"<summary>
* The federal government has held funds in trust for Indian tribes since 1820.

column2: * Enacted in 1887, the General Allotment Act provided for the division of Indian tribal lands into allotments for individual tribal members and families.
* The Indian Reorganization Act of 1934 ended the allotment of tribal lands and extended the period that the federal government would hold allotted lands in trust.

column1: * The Secretary of the Interior is responsible for managing trust funds, providing trust services, and maintaining official Indian land title and ownership records.

column2: * The Bureau of Indian Affairs (BIA) has been delegated much of the responsibility for trust management.
* Interior issued the Comprehensive Trust Management Plan in 2003 to guide trust reform efforts.

column1: * The Office of the Special Trustee for American Indians (OST) has increased its budget and staff to implement trust reforms.

column2: * OST is responsible for trust fund management, maintaining trust records, and developing trust investment strategies.
* OST has implemented key trust fund management reforms, such as the Trust Funds Accounting System and the Trust Beneficiary Call Center.

column1: * OST relies heavily on contractors to perform trust reform activities.

column2: * In fiscal years 2004 and 2005, nearly 21% of OST's appropriated funds were spent on contracts.
* Interior's Office of Inspector General found instances of preferential treatment of a contractor in contracting for risk management services.

column1: * OST has not provided a timetable for completing trust fund management reforms as required by the 1994 Act.

column2: * The lack of a timetable hinders oversight and planning for trust fund operations.
* OST has not developed a workforce plan to reexamine staffing levels and funding needs for trust fund operations once reforms are completed.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
428,"<summary>
• VA and DOD began joint efforts in 1998 to share patient health information for military personnel and veterans.

column2: • The Government Computer-Based Patient Record (GCPR) project was the first initiative to allow access to data from each agency's health information systems.

column3: • Lack of clear mission and planning hindered progress in the GCPR project.
• Recommendations were made to strengthen management and oversight of the project.
• The Federal Health Information Exchange (FHIE) program was established to enable the exchange of health care information between VA and DOD.

column1: • The CHDR initiative aims to achieve a two-way exchange of health information between VA's Health Data Repository and DOD's Clinical Data Repository.

column2: • Challenges include the need for a detailed project management plan and delays in implementing standards for data exchange.

column3: • The CHDR project faces obstacles in completing data quality testing and meeting established milestones.
• Limitations in the current data repositories of both VA and DOD hinder the exchange of complete patient health information.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"
429,"<summary>
• The Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) outlines the desired outcome of an income tax audit as determining the correct taxable income and tax liability.

column2: • The auditor is responsible for conducting a quality audit to ensure accuracy.

column3: • IRS uses nine audit standards to define audit quality, addressing scope, techniques, technical conclusions, reports, and time management.
• Workpapers are crucial for documenting the audit scope, procedures, evidence, and technical conclusions.
• Audit workpapers are reviewed by first-line supervisors to identify and correct any quality issues.

column1: • Workpapers are essential for supporting the auditor's report on findings and conclusions about the taxpayer's tax liability.

column2: • IRS' Examination Quality Measurement System (EQMS) collects information on audit quality and process improvements.

column3: • EQMS staff review audit workpapers to assess compliance with audit standards.
• Audits must pass all key elements of the standards to be considered successful.

column1: • Despite historical issues with workpaper quality, IRS has found problems with meeting the workpaper standard.

column2: • Inadequate workpapers can lead to additional work or overturned adjustments.

column3: • Supervisory review of audit workpapers is crucial for quality control.
• Documentation of supervisory review is lacking in many audits.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"
430,"<summary>
* Congress authorized State’s ATA program in 1983 through the Foreign Assistance Act

column2: * Purpose of ATA is to enhance antiterrorism skills of friendly countries

column3: * Provide training and equipment to deter and counter terrorism

column2: * ATA offers training courses and grants of counterterrorism equipment to partner nations

column3: * Focus on critical counterterrorism capabilities such as crisis management and cyberterrorism

column1: * ATA is State’s largest counterterrorism program receiving appropriations under the Nonproliferation, Anti-Terrorism, Demining, and Related Programs account

column2: * Fiscal year 2002 appropriations for ATA increased to about $158 million

column3: * Top 10 recipients represented about 57% of ATA funding allocated for training

column2: * S/CT and DS/T/ATA did not systematically use country-specific needs assessments and program reviews to plan assistance

column3: * S/CT places countries on a tiered list based on criteria such as country-specific threats and engagement

column1: * S/CT and DS/T/ATA did not systematically assess sustainability of program assistance

column2: * State did not have measurable performance goals and outcomes related to the program’s objectives prior to fiscal year 2003

column3: * State has made progress in defining goals and measures related to program objectives

column1: * State did not comply with a congressional mandate to report on U.S. international counterterrorism assistance since 1996

column2: * Recent ATA annual reports contained inaccurate data regarding program information

column3: * DS/T/ATA lacked guidance on reporting program data accurately

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
431,"<summary>
* Large financial companies can be reorganized or liquidated through judicial bankruptcy or special resolution regimes.

column2: * Bankruptcy is a federal court procedure to help individuals and businesses eliminate or restructure debts.
* Equitable treatment of creditors is a key aspect of bankruptcy proceedings.

column1: * Chapter 7 and Chapter 11 of the Code govern liquidation and reorganization of business debtors.

column2: * Debtors can voluntarily or involuntarily file for bankruptcy.
* A trustee oversees the liquidation of assets in a Chapter 7 proceeding.

column1: * The U.S. bankruptcy system involves multiple federal entities.

column2: * Bankruptcy courts are located in 90 federal judicial districts.
* The Federal Judicial Center assists bankruptcy courts with reports and assessments.

column1: * The Dodd-Frank Act amended the Federal Reserve Act to prohibit emergency lending programs for specific companies.

column2: * The Act also allows for the resolution of large financial companies outside of bankruptcy through the OLA.

column1: * Efforts have been made to improve cross-border coordination for the resolution of failed large financial companies.

column2: * The Financial Stability Board issued principles to guide the development of resolution regimes for financial firms.
* The European Union's Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive establishes requirements for national resolution frameworks.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
432,"<summary>
* The electricity industry is composed of four functions: generation, transmission, distribution, and system operations.

column2: * Electricity is generated through various means and sent through transmission lines to local distributors.
* Local distributors transform electricity into lower voltage for consumption by consumers.

column1: * System operators constantly balance generation and consumption of power to ensure smooth flow.

column2: * Utilities own and operate electricity assets, including generation plants and transmission lines.

column1: * The smart grid vision aims to increase efficiency, reliability, and integration of renewable energy sources.

column2: * Smart grid systems use IT systems and networks for automation and real-time monitoring.

column1: * Federal and state governments oversee the electricity industry, with FERC regulating wholesale rates and transmission.

column2: * NERC is responsible for ensuring the reliability of the bulk power system.

column1: * Cyber threats to the electricity industry come from various sources and can have serious impacts.

column2: * Threats include unintentional errors, targeted attacks, and sophisticated adversaries.

column1: * Efforts to secure the electricity grid involve developing cybersecurity standards and information sharing.

column2: * NERC, NIST, FERC, DHS, and DOE play key roles in protecting the sector against cyber threats.

column1: * Challenges in securing the electricity grid include monitoring compliance with cybersecurity standards and clarifying regulatory responsibilities.

column2: * A comprehensive approach to cybersecurity, built-in security features, and effective information sharing are essential.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
433,"<summary>
• Federal workforce faces skills gaps in mission-critical areas

column2: • Shortfalls in government-wide and agency-specific occupations hinder effective service

column3: • Insufficient number of people or lack of appropriate skills contribute to skills gaps
• Budget pressures, changing nature of work, and potential wave of retirements exacerbate the issue
• Over 34% of federal employees eligible to retire by 2020

column1: • Challenges in federal personnel systems identified

column2: • Issues with classification system, recruiting, pay system, performance management, and employee engagement

column3: • GS system not keeping pace with evolving requirements
• Hiring process needs to be applicant-friendly and flexible
• Pay system rewards length of service over performance

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"
434,"<summary>
* About 90 percent of the costs associated with GWOT fall into military personnel and operation and maintenance accounts.

column2: * Military personnel funds cover pay and allowances of mobilized reservists and special payments for qualifying military personnel.

column3: * Includes Imminent Danger Pay and Family Separation Allowance.

column2: * Operation and maintenance funds are used for transportation, unit support costs, and intelligence, communications, and logistics support.

column3: * Can be shifted between appropriation accounts using transfer authority.

column2: * In fiscal years 2004 and 2005, military services received supplemental appropriations for GWOT expenses.

column3: * Army, Air Force, and Navy also received funds through annual appropriations.

column2: * DOD and military services lost visibility over funds provided through annual appropriations.

column3: * Unable to determine how much was used to support GWOT in fiscal years 2004 and 2005.

column2: * DOD increased annual appropriation request by more than $10 billion per year to support GWOT.

column3: * Program Budget Decision 736 provided for the increase in annual budget request.

column2: * In fiscal years 2004 and 2005, military services received additional funds in their annual appropriations.

column3: * Funds were intended to support military operations in the war on terrorism.

column2: * Military services projected gaps between reported obligations and supplemental appropriations at midyear budget review.

column3: * Army and Air Force projected obligations above supplemental appropriations for GWOT.

column2: * DOD and military services plan to take actions to cover any gaps and meet GWOT needs.

column3: * Actions include transferring funds, reducing or deferring planned spending for peacetime operations.

column2: * DOD did not concur with recommendations to adjust future supplemental appropriations requests and consider additional GWOT funds provided through annual appropriations.

column3: * DOD believes funds are considered when determining needs and expenses of the war.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
435,"<summary>
* The financial crisis prompted extraordinary government interventions to stabilize the financial system.

column2: * Interventions included providing capital to financial institutions, enhancing access to liquid assets, purchasing nonperforming assets, guaranteeing liabilities, intervening in financial markets, and mitigating home foreclosures.

column3: * Programs like the Capital Purchase Program and Capital Assistance Program provided capital directly to financial institutions.
* The Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP) included various initiatives to stabilize the financial system and restore investor confidence.
* The Public-Private Investment Program (PPIP) aimed to address troubled securities through partnerships with private sector fund managers.

column1: * Treasury extended TARP to address weaknesses in the economy and respond to unanticipated shocks.

column2: * The decision to extend TARP was made in consultation with the Federal Reserve and FDIC.

column3: * Treasury identified housing market indicators, credit conditions for small businesses, and financial stress as factors influencing the decision.
* The extension allowed Treasury to retain resources to respond to financial instability and threats to the recovery.

column1: * Treasury used quantitative indicators like loan originations, spreads in asset-backed securities markets, and bank capital raising to inform its decisions.

column2: * Data on loan originations, asset spreads, and bank capital raising reflected improvements in the financial system.

column3: * Indicators like the TED spread and ABS market issuance volumes were used to assess market conditions.
* Treasury considered the impact of its programs on bank balance sheets and lending activities.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
436,"<summary>
* USDA and FDA are responsible for ensuring the safety of meat, poultry, and certain egg products, as well as all other foods.

column2: * FDA and FSIS work to ensure the safety of food products through a regulatory system of preventive controls.

column1: * The Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point (HACCP) system is used to identify and prevent contamination in food-processing facilities.

column2: * FDA inspects over 57,000 food facilities every 5 years on average, while USDA inspects over 6,000 meat and poultry facilities daily.

column1: * Both agencies have the authority to take enforcement actions to ensure facilities meet safety requirements.

column2: * In fiscal year 1999, FDA, FSIS, and states spent about $1.3 billion on food safety activities.

column1: * After September 11, 2001, efforts were intensified to address potential deliberate contamination of agriculture and food products.

column2: * FDA and USDA received emergency funding to prevent, prepare for, and respond to potential bioterrorist attacks.

column1: * FDA and USDA issued voluntary security guidelines to food-processing industry to enhance security at facilities.

column2: * The guidelines cover areas such as risk assessment, developing security plans, and adopting security measures.

column1: * The food industry is voluntarily implementing security measures, but FDA and USDA do not have comprehensive information on the extent of implementation.

column2: * Trade associations are providing guidelines and industry is taking steps to prevent deliberate contamination of food products.

column1: * FDA and USDA inspectors are not authorized to enforce security measures but are encouraged to discuss them with facility management.

column2: * The lack of authority to mandate security measures and concerns about information release hinder agencies' ability to assess industry efforts.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
437,"<summary>
* The MAS program is the largest interagency contracting vehicle managed by GSA.

column2: * MACs and GWACs are also interagency contracts used by government buyers.

column1: * Government buyers usually pay a fee for using other agencies' GWACs, MACs, and schedule contracts.

column2: * These fees are usually a percentage of the value of the procurement.

column1: * Enterprisewide contracts are similar to interagency contracts but do not allow purchases outside of the original acquiring activity.

column2: * They can be used to reduce contracting administrative overhead and avoid fees charged for using interagency contracts.

column1: * In fiscal year 2008, federal agencies spent at least $60 billion through various interagency contracts.

column2: * Sales under the MAS program have been relatively flat in recent years.

column1: * Concerns exist about contract duplication and lack of reliable data on interagency and enterprisewide contracts.

column2: * Limited governmentwide policy is in place for establishing and overseeing MACs and enterprisewide contracts.

column1: * Recent legislation and OFPP initiatives aim to strengthen oversight and management of MACs.

column2: * Agencies have cited reasons for establishing their own MACs and enterprisewide contracts, including cost avoidance and mission-specific requirements.

column1: * GSA faces challenges in managing the MAS program, including lack of transactional data and limited use of pricing tools.

column2: * GSA lacks data on the use of MAS contracts by customer agencies and struggles to determine if the program achieves its goal of obtaining the best prices.

column1: * GSA uses tools like pre-award audits and clearance panel reviews to obtain and maintain best prices for its contracts.

column2: * However, these tools are applied to a small number of contracts, hindering GSA's ability to determine if it achieves the program's goal.

column1: * GSA's decentralized management structure for the MAS program and shortcomings in assessment tools create management challenges.

column2: * GSA lacks consistent performance measures across the MAS program and has a low customer satisfaction survey response rate.

column1: * The federal government lacks a clear and comprehensive view of who is using interagency and enterprisewide contracts and if they are being used efficiently.

column2: * Long-standing problems with FPDS-NG data and lack of consistent governmentwide policy on these contracts hamper the government's ability to realize the strategic value of using them.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
438,"<summary>
* Investments in IT can enrich people’s lives and improve organizational performance.

column2: * The Internet has matured into a national resource for citizens to interact with the government.

column1: * Some federally funded IT projects have become risky, costly, and unproductive mistakes.

column2: * Examples include failed projects like the Office of Personnel Management’s Retirement Systems Modernization program.

column1: * 18F and USDS were formed to address troubled IT efforts in the federal government.

column2: * 18F provides expert designers, developers, and technologists to help deploy digital services.

column1: * 18F is funded through the Acquisition Services Fund and aims to achieve full cost recovery by fiscal year 2019.

column2: * The program uses special hiring authorities and has established business units to provide services to agencies.

column1: * USDS aims to transform important digital services for citizens by partnering private sector experts with government agencies.

column2: * The program has developed guidance, tools, and training programs to improve government websites and services.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
439,"<summary>
* The maturation of the baby boom generation will lead to significant changes in the aged dependency ratio.

column2: * The aged dependency ratio is expected to reach 35 percent by 2030.
* This increase is due to the growing numbers of older persons and the slowing growth of the labor force of younger workers.

column1: * Changes in Social Security retirement policy could strengthen incentives to work longer.

column2: * The practice of reducing Social Security benefits when a beneficiary has earnings and has reached the normal retirement age was eliminated in 2000.
* The delayed retirement credit for persons who first claim benefits after the normal retirement age is steadily being increased.

column1: * The Age Discrimination in Employment Act of 1967 promotes the employment of older persons based on ability rather than age.

column2: * ADEA prohibits age discrimination in employment.
* ADEA applies only to firms with 20 or more employees.

column1: * Pension benefits are a key source of retirement income for many workers and can influence the work decisions of older individuals.

column2: * The federal government provides preferential tax treatment for pension plans that meet certain requirements.
* ERISA establishes certain minimum standards for private employee pension plans.

column1: * The number of older workers is expected to grow substantially over the next two decades.

column2: * BLS estimates that there will be 31.8 million older labor force participants in 2015.
* Older workers are employed in a diverse group of occupations.

column1: * Older workers are projected to make relatively greater gains in earnings than their younger counterparts between 2000 and 2008.

column2: * Workers age 55 to 64 and workers age 65 to 74 had median earnings increases of 9 percent and 19 percent, respectively, from 1989 to 1999.
* These earnings increases were primarily driven by a greater number of older workers working full-time and a movement in the occupational composition toward higher paying white-collar jobs.

column1: * Employers are using various arrangements to retain and extend the careers of older workers.

column2: * Some employers offer part-time work, seasonal or part-year work, consulting or contracting, or a reduction of job responsibilities.
* Flexible employment arrangements are not yet widespread in the private sector.

column1: * Public employers are more active in initiating programs to retain older workers.

column2: * Some states have implemented programs to encourage older employees to remain on the job.
* Public employers are using pension incentives to retain older workers.

column1: * Factors contributing to discouraging the continued labor force participation of older workers include negative perceptions of older workers, higher costs",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
440,"<summary>
* The Visa Waiver Program (VWP) was established in 1986 to facilitate legitimate travel for business or tourism.

column2: * Purpose is to boost international business and tourism, create economic benefits, and allocate resources to higher risk applicant pools.
* DHS oversees VWP activities and monitors countries' adherence to program requirements.

column1: * VWP countries must meet specific criteria to qualify, including reciprocal visa-free travel privileges and information sharing agreements.

column2: * Passports issued after certain dates must contain digital photographs and be e-passports.

column1: * ESTA was implemented to enhance program security, reduce burden on travelers, and collect passenger data for security checks.

column2: * DHS has taken steps to minimize burden associated with ESTA use, such as reducing frequency of applications and providing widespread outreach.

column1: * DHS has not fully analyzed risks of carrier and passenger noncompliance with ESTA requirement.

column2: * DHS has not established a target completion date for reviewing potential security risks associated with noncompliance.

column1: * DHS has not completed half of mandated biennial reports on VWP country reviews in a timely manner.

column2: * Delays in completing reports are due to lack of resources, delays in receiving intelligence assessments, and lengthy internal review processes.

column1: * DHS should establish time frames for reviewing cases of VWP passengers without verified ESTA approval and address delays in biennial country review process.

column2: * DHS concurred with GAO's recommendations and expects to implement them.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
441,"<summary>
• State child welfare systems are struggling to keep pace with the needs of troubled children and their families.

column2: • Foster care population grew significantly from 1984 to 1995, with federal funds supporting a large number of children.
• States are required to make efforts to prevent removing children from their homes and provide services to reunite families.

column1: • Permanency planning is a key aspect of the child welfare system, with states required to develop case plans for each child.

column2: • Permanency hearings must be held within specific time frames to determine the future status of the child.
• Options for a child's future status include reuniting with family, adoption, or long-term foster care.

column1: • Some states have implemented initiatives to expedite the permanency process and improve outcomes for children.

column2: • Initiatives include concurrent planning, housing assistance programs, and expedited termination of parental rights.
• Evaluation data on the impact of these initiatives is often lacking, hindering a full understanding of their effectiveness.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"
442,"<summary>
* OMB and Treasury have taken steps to improve federal spending transparency through the DATA Act, requiring agencies to disclose expenditures and link spending information to federal programs.

column2: * The DATA Act requires government-wide reporting on various federal funds and compliance with new data standards established by OMB and Treasury.
* OMB has issued guidance to help agencies meet reporting requirements, including implementing data definition standards and linking financial systems with award systems.

column1: * Challenges in implementing the DATA Act include issues with intragovernmental transactions, IT security, and missing or incorrect ZIP+4 information.

column2: * Agencies face challenges in reconciling intragovernmental transactions and ensuring proper access controls to limit users to needed systems and functions.
* Missing or incorrect ZIP+4 information poses challenges for agencies in validating financial assistance award information.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
443,"<summary>
• OSC has an agreement with ARC to provide contracting support for a fee

column2: • ARC relies on revenue from federal agency customers to pay expenses
• Interagency contracting involves three parties: requiring agency, ordering agency, and contractors

column1: • OSC hired intermittent consultants under 5 U.S.C. § 3109

column2: • Agencies can acquire temporary services of experts or consultants
• OPM prescribes criteria for employing experts and consultants

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"
444,"<summary>
• VA's mission is to promote the health, welfare, and dignity of all veterans by providing medical care, benefits, social support, and memorials.
• VA consists of three major components: VBA, VHA, and NCA, responsible for benefits, health care, and burial services.
• VA relies heavily on IT infrastructure to deliver services and benefits to veterans, with plans to modernize legacy systems.
• VA has faced challenges in developing new systems, modernizing existing systems, and increasing interoperability with DOD.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
445,"<summary>
* HCFA is responsible for managing the Medicare program, which serves about 33 million beneficiaries and processes a high volume of claims.
* Medicare is divided into two parts: hospital insurance (part A) and supplementary medical insurance (part B).
* HCFA also oversees more than 400 managed care health plans serving over 5 million beneficiaries.
* Recent legislation, such as HIPAA and BBA, has granted HCFA authority to reform Medicare and combat fraud and abuse.
* HCFA is facing challenges related to staffing, expertise, and organizational restructuring.
* HCFA is rethinking its strategy to improve automated claims processing and information systems.
* The agency is facing difficulties in replacing experienced staff who have retired or are eligible to retire.
* HCFA has restructured its organization to focus on managed care and establish technical and support offices.
* Managers are concerned about the timing of the reorganization and the challenges of establishing new communication and coordination links.
* HCFA is struggling to balance important deadlines and pressures while addressing critical functions.
* The agency may not be adequately informed about the status of all Medicare activities and associated resource needs.
* HCFA is focusing on BBA-related activities but may be neglecting other mission-related work.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
446,"<summary>
* FAA is primarily supported by the Trust Fund, which receives revenues from excise taxes paid by users of the NAS.
* Trust Fund revenues are available for use subject to appropriations.
* General Fund revenues have also been used to fund FAA.
* The Trust Fund provides funding for FAA's capital accounts, AIP, F&E, and RE&D.
* The administration's reauthorization proposal would change FAA's financing system to be more based on cost-based charges.
* ATO funding would come from user charges on commercial aircraft and fuel taxes on general aviation aircraft.
* Contributions from the General Fund would cover ATO costs for military and public aircraft.
* Funding for AIP, EAS, and part of RE&D would come from fuel taxes and a tax on international passengers.
* FAA released a cost allocation study to assign air traffic costs to user groups based on aircraft type.
* High-performance and piston aircraft groups were identified as the two principal user groups.
* The cost allocation methodology is based on the assumption that high-performance users compete for the same air traffic control resources.
* Differences in speed and cruising altitudes of aircraft types affect their en route costs.
* The current funding structure has successfully funded a growing FAA budget.
* Trust Fund revenues are projected to increase substantially at current excise tax rates.
* Congress has changed the mix of excise taxes and tax rates over the years.
* General Fund contributions have ranged from 0 to 59 percent of FAA's budget.
* Funding for NextGen does not require a change in the current funding structure.
* Revenues obtained from the existing structure are projected to increase substantially.
* Congress could make further changes within the current structure to provide additional revenue for FAA.
* The proposed funding structure aims to address concerns about revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency.
* The proposed funding structure includes user charges on commercial aircraft and fuel taxes on general aviation.
* A fee for congested airports would encourage efficient use of the NAS.
* The proposed fuel tax rates may not yield the expected revenue due to possible reductions in fuel purchases.
* The proposed creation of an advisory board raises questions about congressional oversight.
* The proposed restructuring of FAA's budget accounts aligns with the principle of cost-based funding.
* Linking the General Fund contribution to public benefits is consistent with public finance principles.
* The proposed funding structure deserves serious consideration and may address concerns with the current structure.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
447,"<summary>
* GSA is responsible for ensuring federal agencies have access to telecommunications services and solutions.

column2: * GSA awarded contracts to Sprint and MCI WorldCom for long-distance services under the FTS2001 program.

column1: * GSA is planning the Networx acquisition program to replace existing contracts and meet agency needs.

column2: * The Networx program includes two acquisitions - Networx Universal and Networx Select - to provide a range of services to federal agencies.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
448,"<summary>
• FSA manages and administers student financial assistance programs authorized under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965

column2: • Programs include Direct Loan, Guaranteed Loan, Federal Pell Grant, and campus-based programs
• Approximately $50 billion in student aid is provided annually to 8 million students and families
• FSA oversees $200 billion in outstanding loans for 100 million borrowers

column1: • Congress established FSA as the government’s first PBO in October 1998

column2: • PBOs are to commit to clear management objectives and specific targets for improved performance
• FSA's enabling legislation requires the appointment of a chief operating officer and the development of performance plans
• FSA has taken steps towards developing and implementing a strategic direction, but additional actions are needed

column1: • FSA's performance plan includes goals for increasing customer and employee satisfaction and reducing unit costs

column2: • Measures for gauging FSA progress include the American Customer Satisfaction Index and the Gallup Q12
• FSA's unit cost measure has limitations and does not fully measure total obligations per person receiving aid
• FSA has begun to implement a balanced scorecard to link employees' activities with strategic goals

column1: • FSA's efforts in human capital management have gaps and need improvement

column2: • FSA has restructured its workforce and created a management council to steer the organization strategically
• FSA has not fully addressed critical elements of human capital management such as workforce planning and development

450,"<summary>
* Transit-oriented development is described as a compact, mixed-use neighborhood near transit stations.
* Typically located up to a half-mile from a transit station.
* Can encompass multiple city blocks.
* Has pedestrian-friendly environments.

* Stakeholders involved in planning and implementing transit-oriented development include local transit agencies, state and local departments of transportation, local governments, private developers, lenders, and business improvement districts.
* Local transit agencies are responsible for building, maintaining, and operating transit systems.
* State and local departments of transportation develop transportation plans and improvement programs.
* Local governments have control over land use planning and zoning policies.
* Private developers decide on and create developments.

* FTA does not have a discrete program for transit-oriented development but has been expanding its role in recent years by funding research, coordinating with other agencies, and implementing a planning pilot program.
* FTA provides funds for transit projects that may spur transit-oriented development.
* FTA evaluates projects based on criteria such as mobility improvements, environmental benefits, congestion relief, cost-effectiveness, economic development, and land use.
* FTA considers factors like market demand, available land, resident support, and efficient access to jobs and activity centers.

* Factors that support transit-oriented development include market demand for real estate, available land for development, resident support for transit, and efficient access to jobs and activity centers.
* Market demand for real estate is driven by the strength of the local economy.
* Large parcels of land near transit stations can support development.
* Residents, especially younger age groups, tend to be supportive of transit-oriented development.
* Efficient transit connections to job centers are crucial for attracting ridership.

* Challenges that hinder transit-oriented development include higher construction costs, lenders' reluctance to finance projects, lengthy approval processes, unsupportive local populations, and undesirable physical features around transit stations.
* Construction costs can be higher for mixed-use developments.
* Lenders may view transit-oriented developments as riskier investments.
* Lengthy approval processes can create uncertainty for developers.
* Local populations may not support transit or dense development.
* Local governments can encourage transit-oriented development through zoning regulations, area planning, infrastructure investments, and tax incentives.
* Zoning regulations can facilitate development near transit stations.
* Area plans provide guidance and resolve contentious issues.
* Infrastructure investments can enhance transit accessibility.
* Tax credits can help mitigate challenges associated with development on industrial land.
* FTA assesses factors related to potential",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
451,"<summary>
* Workers have the right to review their earnings records at SSA since 1935

column2: * SSA introduced PEBES in 1988 for workers to review earnings records and obtain benefit estimates

column3: * Fewer than 2% of workers request statements each year
* SSA plans to mail statements to over 70 million workers by fiscal year 2000
* Accurate earnings records are important for determining Social Security benefits
* PEBES estimates may over- or understate benefits for certain individuals

column1: * PEBES has been revised based on feedback from surveys and focus groups

column2: * Public reaction to receiving PEBES has been favorable

column3: * Majority of respondents are glad to receive statements
* 95% find the information helpful
* Older individuals react more favorably than younger individuals
* SSA representatives report that most callers find the information useful for financial planning

column1: * Current PEBES statement provides too much information and is complex

column2: * Statement lacks clear organization and design

column3: * Readers may be overwhelmed by the amount of information
* Explanations are scattered throughout the statement
* Benefit estimates may be difficult to understand for some recipients
* SSA has not collected detailed feedback from front-line workers on public response to PEBES

• SSA administers two programs for individuals unable to work due to disability

column2: • DI and SSI use same definition of disability for initial entitlement

column3: • Must have medically determinable impairment lasting at least one year
• Must prevent individual from engaging in substantial gainful activity
• DI is an insurance program based on work credits, while SSI provides income for those with limited resources
• Most beneficiaries qualify for either DI or SSI, but some receive benefits from both programs
• Work incentive provisions in both programs encourage beneficiaries to return to work
• SSA faces challenges in coordinating rules for concurrent beneficiaries who work and adjusting benefits in a timely manner

453,"<summary>
* Hurricane Katrina devastated the Gulf Coast region in August 2005, leading to significant human casualties and damage.

column2: * The Stafford Act authorizes the federal government to provide assistance in disaster relief efforts.

column3: * Nearly $88 billion was appropriated by Congress for relief and recovery efforts related to the Gulf Coast hurricanes.
* FEMA, as the administering agency, used funds from the Disaster Relief Fund to support relief and recovery efforts.
* Mission assignments are issued by FEMA to other federal agencies to support disaster relief efforts.

column1: * FEMA's reporting on obligations and expenditures for mission assignments did not reflect the governmentwide perspective accurately.

column2: * Some federal agencies recorded obligations much less than what FEMA reported.

column3: * DOD, COE, Coast Guard, and HUD were examples of agencies with discrepancies in reported obligations.

column2: * Some agencies did not have mission assignments recorded in their internal tracking systems as reported by FEMA.

column3: * Department of Health and Human Services and Environmental Protection Agency were examples of agencies with this issue.

column1: * FEMA's reported expenditures were understated due to timing issues with reimbursements to performing agencies.

column2: * Performing agencies had higher levels of expenditures on mission assignments than what FEMA reported.

column3: * Examples included DOD and the U.S. Forest Service.

column1: * FEMA experienced billing problems with COE, leading to delays in reimbursement.

column2: * COE had outstanding accounts receivable for mission assignment costs not yet reimbursed by FEMA.

column3: * COE had not received reimbursement for about $1.2 billion of bills submitted to FEMA.

column1: * There was no central collection point to compile and report on the use of the $88 billion in hurricane relief and recovery funds.

column2: * Lack of mechanisms in place for governmentwide reporting on the status of hurricane-related funding.

column3: * OMB or another agency could establish a framework for governmentwide reporting on the funding.

column2: • COAs are issued to public entities for specific UAS activities, while experimental certificates are for civil entities for research and development.

* CERP efforts in Afghanistan focus on development and construction, while in Iraq the focus is on reconstruction of neglected infrastructure.

456,"<summary>
* Solar energy technologies include photovoltaics, concentrated solar power, and solar hot water.

column2: * Photovoltaic cells convert sunlight into electricity for various applications.
* Concentrated solar power uses mirrors to generate electricity via thermal energy conversion.

column1: * Solar hot water systems absorb heat from the sun to heat water for residential and industrial use.

column2: * Innovation in solar energy technology involves basic research, applied research, demonstration, and commercialization.
* Federal agencies undertook 65 solar-related initiatives in fiscal years 2010 and 2011.

column1: * Initiatives supported various solar technologies and technology advancement activities.

column2: * Funding recipients included universities, industry, nonprofit organizations, and federal labs.
* Initiatives primarily used grants and contracts for funding solar projects.

column1: * Over $2.6 billion was obligated for solar projects by federal agencies in fiscal years 2010 and 2011.

column2: * DOE accounted for the majority of obligations, primarily through the Loan Guarantee Program.
* Coordination efforts among federal solar-related initiatives aimed to avoid duplication and leverage resources.

* DOD provides servicemembers with protective ensembles to survive and conduct military operations, but the equipment is bulky, not fully interoperable, and many suits will expire by 2007.

458,"<summary>
* Program evaluations are systematic studies that use research methods to address specific questions about program performance.

column2: * Evaluation is closely related to performance measurement and reporting.

column1: * Evaluations can be designed to better isolate the causal impact of programs from other external economic or environmental conditions in order to assess a program’s effectiveness.

column2: * Evaluation studies can provide valuable feedback on program design and execution to program managers, policy officials, and the public.

column1: * Most federal managers reported lacking recent evaluations of their programs, citing lack of resources as a barrier to implementing evaluation findings.

column2: * Leadership support of evaluation, building a strong body of evidence, and engaging stakeholders throughout the evaluation process are key strategies to facilitate evaluation influence.

column1: * GPRAMA established an expectation that evidence would have a greater role in agency decision making.

column2: * The act required agencies to establish agency priority goals, review progress quarterly, and report publicly on their progress and strategies to improve performance.

column1: * The Trump Administration’s 2018 Budget proposal endorses a continued commitment to agencies building a portfolio of evidence on what works and how to improve results.

column2: * The Evidence-Based Policymaking Commission Act of 2016 created a Commission to conduct a comprehensive study of data inventory related to federal policy making.

column1: * The Foreign Aid Transparency and Accountability Act of 2016 requires guidelines for monitoring and evaluating federal foreign assistance by January 2018.

column2: * The guidelines are to provide direction to federal agencies on establishing monitoring and evaluation plans, quality assurance procedures, and public dissemination of findings.

459,"<summary>
• Federal agencies are required to promote the employment of individuals with disabilities through special hiring authorities and plans for hiring and retaining employees with disabilities.

column2: • Agencies must develop plans with specific goals, designate a senior-level official accountable for meeting the goals, and implement strategies such as increasing the use of Schedule A hiring authority.
• Agencies should provide training for staff on hiring procedures related to individuals with disabilities, offer career development opportunities, and create a flexible work environment.

column1: • The accuracy of data on the number of employees with disabilities in the federal government is a challenge, with concerns about underreporting and the need for strategies to encourage voluntary self-disclosure.

column2: • Agencies should regularly survey their workforce on disability issues, coordinate roles and responsibilities, and provide centralized funding for reasonable accommodations.

• OPM should incorporate information about plan deficiencies into regular reporting, expedite the development of mandatory training programs, and assess the accuracy of SF-256 data to improve reporting on progress towards the executive order's goals.

460,"<summary>
• BLM's ALMRS/Modernization project aims to automate land and mineral records and case processing activities to support land and resource management activities.

column2: • ALMRS/Modernization consists of three components: ALMRS IOC, GCDB, and technology modernization and rehost of selected systems.

column3: • ALMRS IOC supports case processing activities and land and resource management activities.
• GCDB contains geographic coordinates and survey information for land parcels.

column1: • BLM has been meeting most of its schedule milestones for the initial installation of ALMRS IOC and modernization computer and telecommunications hardware.

column2: • BLM plans to stress test the entire ALMRS/Modernization system to ensure it can process workloads expected during peak operating conditions.

column3: • Stress testing only a portion of the modernized system may not provide assurance that all systems can perform as intended during peak workloads.

462,"<summary>
* The public faces a high risk of critical service disruptions due to the Year 2000 computing crisis.

column2: * Financial transactions, flights, power, and national defense could be affected.
* Key economic sectors at risk include information, banking, health, transportation, power, and manufacturing.

column3: * Telecommunications sector readiness is crucial for operations of public and private organizations.
* Global readiness for Year 2000 is a concern, with many countries lagging behind.
* Various industries are at different stages of Year 2000 compliance.

column1: * The government is making slow progress in fixing systems, with many agencies behind schedule.

column2: * FAA and DOD are facing challenges in resolving Year 2000 issues.
* Recommendations have been made to address issues such as setting priorities and contingency planning.

column3: * Governmentwide priorities need to be established based on criteria like health, safety, and national security.
* Contingency planning for critical core business processes is essential.
* End-to-end testing responsibilities need to be defined to ensure reliable data exchange.

463,"<summary>
* OMB was required to develop and issue guidelines for federal agencies to ensure quality, objectivity, utility, and integrity of information by the end of fiscal year 2001.

column2: * OMB Circular A-130 and the Paperwork Reduction Act of 1980 were previous federal efforts to improve information quality.

column3: * IQA requires executive branch agencies to manage information resources to improve integrity, quality, and utility of information.
* OIRA developed governmentwide IQA guidelines and helped agencies develop their own guidelines.
* Agencies were required to establish administrative mechanisms for correction of information and report IQA complaints to OMB.

column1: * OIRA concentrated efforts on cabinet-level and regulatory agencies for IQA implementation.

column2: * OIRA did not clarify IQA requirements for many independent agencies, leading to a lack of IQA guidelines on their websites.

column3: * OIRA issued memorandums to clarify IQA implementation and directed agencies to post IQA information online.
* OIRA monitored IQA correction requests and assisted agencies in developing responses.
* OIRA did not provide specific guidance on how agencies should provide access to online IQA information.

464,"<summary>
* Mutual fund companies and banks are financial intermediaries that raise funds from savers and invest them back into the economy.

column2: * Banks use deposits to make loans or invest in debt securities, while mutual funds invest in securities like bonds and stocks.

column3: * Money from mutual funds flows to issuers through primary or secondary securities markets.
* Corporations and households have become less dependent on bank loans for financing.
* Securitization has replaced bank credit as a source of finance, with securities firms, insurance companies, and finance companies providing direct loans.

column1: * The impact of mutual funds on deposits is assessed through data from industry sources, bank regulators, and the Federal Reserve.

column2: * The movement of money from deposits to mutual funds has affected the total supply of loanable and investable funds.

column3: * Mutual funds invest mainly in securities, increasing liquidity in the securities markets.
* The availability of credit for residential, consumer, and business borrowers may be affected by the shift from bank deposits to mutual funds.

column1: * Small businesses may face credit availability constraints if their banks lose deposits to mutual funds.

column2: * Small banks could fund loans by selling securities if faced with a loss of deposits.

column3: * The channels of financing are varied, and a shift from deposits to mutual funds may not reduce credit availability for most borrowers.

465,"<summary>
• HHS and DHS have major initiatives related to public health IT, focusing on bioterrorism preparedness and response.

column2: • HHS has primary responsibility for coordinating the nation's response to public health emergencies.

column3: • CDC, FDA, and other agencies under HHS have specific roles in disease surveillance, research, and response.
• HHS is working on developing a national health IT strategy and federal health architecture to improve public health infrastructure.

column2: • DHS is responsible for protecting the US against terrorist attacks and has initiatives focused on surveillance and response to biological threats.

column3: • DHS's Science and Technology Directorate and Information Analysis and Infrastructure Protection Directorate are involved in research and response efforts.
• DHS is working on aligning its IT initiatives with other public health IT efforts and adopting data and communication standards.

466,"<summary>

* Large sponsors of DB pension plans have made revisions to benefit offerings over the last 10 years, including modifying benefit formulas, converting plans to hybrid designs, and freezing some plans.

column2: * 81% of sponsors modified benefit formulas, with reasons including unpredictability of funding requirements for nonbargaining employees and competitive pressures for bargaining unit employees.
* 52% of sponsors converted plans for nonbargaining employees to hybrid designs, citing trends in employee demographics as a key reason.
* Health benefits are a significant component of employer offerings, with 15% of base pay allocated to active employee and retiree health plans.

column1: * Respondents were generally not influenced by recent legislation or rule changes in their decisions on benefit offerings, with most not planning to make changes to their pension plans in the future.

column2: * 50% of sponsors indicated likely implementation of automatic enrollment features in 401(k) plans, with 43% citing the Pension Protection Act as a major factor.

467,"<summary>
* The Refugee Act of 1980 provides a systematic procedure for admitting refugees to the United States and encourages self-sufficiency.

column2: * Federal, state, and local government agencies coordinate with private organizations for refugee resettlement.

column1: * Challenges in refugee resettlement include secondary migration, limited consultation with stakeholders, and short-term focus on employment outcomes.

column2: * Recommendations include improving consultation with stakeholders, increasing responsiveness to secondary migration, and reevaluating performance measures to focus on long-term integration.

468,"<summary>
* The National Flood Insurance Act of 1968 established NFIP as an alternative to providing direct assistance after floods.

column2: * NFIP provides government-guaranteed flood insurance to homeowners and businesses to reduce federal government costs for repairing flood damage.

column1: * FEMA, within the Department of Homeland Security, oversees and manages NFIP.

column2: * Congress has enacted legislation to strengthen NFIP, such as the Flood Disaster Protection Act of 1973 and the National Flood Insurance Reform Act of 1994.

column1: * NFIP requires communities to enforce regulations for land use and new construction in high-risk flood zones.

column2: * Currently, over 20,000 communities participate in NFIP.

column1: * NFIP offers subsidized and full-risk flood insurance premiums.

column2: * Subsidized premiums apply to about 22% of all NFIP policies.

column1: * FEMA uses mitigation efforts like elevation and relocation to reduce flood damage to insured properties.

column2: * Despite efforts, the number of repetitive loss properties has increased.

column1: * Congress increased NFIP's borrowing authority to $20.8 billion after the 2005 hurricanes.

column2: * GAO identified four public policy goals for evaluating the federal role in providing natural catastrophe insurance.

column1: * Actions to achieve these goals include charging premium rates that reflect actual risks and limiting costs to taxpayers.

column2: * Increasing rates to reflect full risk could reduce costs for taxpayers and encourage private market participation.

column1: * FEMA needs to address operational and management issues to improve NFIP's stability.

column2: * GAO has highlighted challenges with NFIP's administration and operations for the past 35 years.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
469,"<summary>
* ICE has the authority to enter into agreements with state or local law enforcement agencies to perform immigration officer functions.

column2: * Agreements are not required for communication with ICE regarding immigration status or cooperation in identifying and removing aliens.
* State and local officers have direct access to ICE databases and can process aliens for removal under the agreements.
* ICE has discretion to establish enforcement priorities for the program.

column1: * The 287(g) program is managed by ICE's Office of State and Local Coordination (OSLC).

column2: * OSLC organizes various programs under ACCESS to partner with state and local law enforcement agencies.
* ICE provides training, equipment, and supervision to participating agencies.
* Agencies can apply for financial assistance to cover some costs associated with the program.

column1: * ICE lacks management controls for the 287(g) program.

column2: * Objectives are not clearly documented in program materials.
* Program documents lack specificity on how and when 287(g) authority should be used.
* ICE has not defined supervision activities for participating agencies.

column1: * ICE has not developed performance measures for the 287(g) program.

column2: * Compliance inspections are being conducted, but do not include performance assessments.
* ICE is working to develop performance measures, but no timeline has been provided.
* ICE has allocated resources for training, equipment, and supervision for the program.

* SEC, NASD, and NYSE share information and written examination guidance related to mutual fund sales practices and other examination priorities.

column2: * Each regulator has developed its own examination module covering various topics related to mutual fund sales.
* SEC reviews SRO examination modules during on-site inspections and coordination meetings.
* SEC, NASD, and NYSE coordinate efforts to respond to industry trends and examination findings.

column2: * SEC officials believe sharing examination modules could hinder SRO innovation and improvement.

471,"<summary>
• TVA is an independent federal corporation established by the TVA Act in 1933 to improve the quality of life in the Tennessee River Valley.

column2: • TVA built dams and hydropower facilities on the Tennessee River and its tributaries to achieve its goals.

column1: • TVA is governed by a nine-member Board of Directors nominated by the President and confirmed by the U.S. Senate.

column2: • The board sets goals and policies, appoints the CEO, approves budgets, and sets wholesale electric power rates.

column1: • TVA's debt ceiling has not been changed since 1979, but its business and operations have grown over the years.

column2: • TVA aims to reduce its debt to about $22 billion by fiscal year 2023 through various strategies.

column1: • TVA's pension plan, managed by the TVARS board, had about $6 billion in unfunded liabilities as of September 30, 2016.

column2: • TVA plans to contribute $300 million annually to the pension plan for up to 20 years to address the funding shortfall.

column1: • TVA faces challenges related to regulatory pressures, changes in demand for electricity, technological innovations, and unforeseen events.

column2: • Factors such as energy storage technology, distributed generation, and environmental regulations could impact TVA's operations and financial health.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '•'}"
472,"<summary>
* First City Bancorporation of Texas faced financial difficulties in the late 1970s and early 1980s due to high concentration of loans to the energy industry in the Southwest United States.

column2: * By 1986, First City was reporting operating losses and needed major capital infusions to survive.

column3: * FDIC provided $970 million in open bank assistance along with $500 million in private capital to restore First City's financial health.
* First City embarked on an aggressive growth policy, resulting in increased assets but also high-risk loans and operating losses.
* Problems with loan portfolios led to continued losses and erosion of capital, ultimately resulting in the failure of First City banks in 1992.

column1: * Regulatory changes in the late 1980s and early 1990s provided FDIC with greater authority to resolve troubled financial institutions.

column2: * FDIC had the authority to provide open bank assistance, organize bridge banks, and recoup losses from commonly controlled depository institutions.

column3: * FDIC provided open bank assistance to First City in 1988, but the ultimate failure of the banks in 1992 led to the closure of all 20 First City banks.
* FDIC considered various resolution alternatives, including bridge banks, but ultimately chose the least costly and most orderly resolution method.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
473,"<summary>
• The Single Audit Act of 1984 was passed to address concerns about oversight and accountability for federal assistance provided to state and local governments.

column2: • Before the act, audits of individual grants were conducted haphazardly and did not address financial controls or systemic problems.
• The act established the concept of a single audit to replace multiple grant audits with one audit of an entity as a whole.

column1: • The quality of single audits conducted under the act has been a longstanding area of concern, with deficiencies related to audit planning, internal control, and compliance testing.

column2: • A National Single Audit Sampling Project was conducted to determine the quality of single audits and make recommendations to address any audit quality issues.

• The PCIE report recommended revising and improving single audit standards, establishing minimum continuing professional education requirements for auditors, and enhancing disciplinary processes to address unacceptable audits.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"
474,"<summary>
• Medicare is a federal health insurance program for elderly and disabled beneficiaries.

column2: • Part A covers inpatient hospital, skilled nursing facility, hospice care, and certain home health services.
• Part B covers physician and outpatient hospital services, laboratory, and other services.

column1: • Claims are paid by 49 claims administration contractors called intermediaries and carriers.

column2: • Intermediaries process claims from hospitals and institutional providers under part A.
• Carriers process part B claims.

column1: • Medicare contracting for intermediaries and carriers differs from most federal programs.

column2: • Intermediaries are selected through a nomination process by provider associations.
• Carriers are chosen by the Secretary of Health and Human Services from a small pool of health insurers.

column1: • Medicare could benefit from various contracting reforms.

column2: • Allowing Medicare to choose contractors on a competitive basis could improve efficiency and performance.
• Allowing contractors to specialize in specific functions and pay based on performance could lead to better program management.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"
475,"<summary>
• DOD focused on reducing support costs to increase investments in modernization
• DSB identified activities for private sector outsourcing for cost savings
• Estimated savings of $7-12 billion annually by fiscal year 2002
• Recommendations included outsourcing all activities except warfighting and policy-making
• Savings primarily from outsourcing support functions
• PA&E analysis found DSB's $6 billion logistics savings estimate overstated by $1 billion
• Another $3 billion in projected savings difficult or unlikely to achieve
• Difficulties included legal restrictions on outsourcing depot maintenance activities
• Achievable savings estimated at $2 billion
• DOD faced cultural resistance to outsourcing logistics activities
• DOD recognized importance of reducing costs and achieving savings
• Recommended detailed implementation plan for improving logistics infrastructure efficiency
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
476,"<summary>
• Federal employment levels were cut in the 1990s to reduce costs and deficits.

column2: • Goals were set for reducing federal staffing levels through executive orders and legislation.

column3: • The Federal Workforce Restructuring Act of 1994 mandated governmentwide reductions.
• The National Performance Review recommended streamlining operations and improving government operations.
• Agencies were required to develop strategic plans and submit annual performance reports.

column1: • Between 1993 and 1996, the federal civilian workforce was cut by about 12%.

column2: • Certain agencies experienced larger percentage reductions, such as HUD, DOI, GSA, NASA, and OPM.

column3: • HUD's Office of Housing and GSA's PBS accounted for the largest portion of staffing reductions.
• DOI's BOR, NASA's Human Space Flight Program, and OPM's Investigations Service were also heavily downsized.

column1: • Agencies took actions to maintain performance during downsizing.

column2: • Refocused missions, reengineered work processes, and built and maintained employee skills.

column3: • HUD consolidated single family housing activities and planned further consolidations.
• BOR shifted its mission emphasis to water resources management.

column1: • Lessons learned included the importance of open communication, involving employees in planning, and treating employees with compassion.

column2: • Agencies should communicate openly with employees and involve them in planning.

column3: • Employees should be treated with compassion and valued by the agency.
• Critical skills should be backed up to ensure continuity in case of employee turnover.

477,"<summary>
• IRS designed the National Research Program (NRP) to measure voluntary reporting compliance and minimize burden on taxpayers.

column2: • NRP consists of casebuilding, classification, and audits to verify information reported on tax returns.

column2: • NRP audits are reviewed for accuracy before being closed to ensure data quality.

column1: • IRS plans to use NRP results to improve future compliance efforts and reduce audits of compliant taxpayers.

column2: • NRP sample size was smaller than expected, leading to more face-to-face audits than initially projected.

column1: • IRS will survey taxpayers to assess satisfaction and burden of NRP audits, consulting with stakeholders for feedback.

column2: • Efforts to minimize taxpayer burden and gather meaningful compliance data are on track.

column2: * Lack of agreement on design could lead to late changes and increased risks

483,"<summary>
