490,"<summary>
• Franchise funds are government-run, self-supporting businesslike enterprises managed by federal employees.

column2: • Franchise funds provide common administrative services such as payroll processing, information technology support, and contracting.
• Franchise funds are required to recover their full costs of doing business and are allowed to retain up to 4 percent of their total annual income.

column3: • Fees are charged for services to cover costs.

column1: • DOD primarily uses two franchise funds for contracting services—GovWorks and FedSource.

column2: • GovWorks generally uses other agencies' contracts, while FedSource generally uses its own contracts.

491,"<summary>
• Wildland fires play an important ecological role on the nation’s landscapes.

column2: • Fires have long shaped the composition of forests and grasslands across every region of the United States.
• Fires can be ignited by lightning or by humans, either accidentally or intentionally.
• Land use and management practices over the past century have reduced the normal frequency of fires in many forest and rangeland ecosystems.

column1: • Changing climate conditions have increased the length and severity of wildfire seasons.

column2: • Western forests in the United States will be increasingly affected by large and intense fires that occur more frequently.
• Federal agencies and nonfederal entities collaborate to reduce the risk of wildland fire through fuel reduction, fire preparedness, prevention, and education activities.
• Individuals and communities may take action to mitigate fire risk by using fire-resistant building materials or building in low-risk areas.

494,"<summary>
• American Samoa, CNMI, Guam, Puerto Rico, and the U.S. Virgin Islands are territories of the United States with small populations and lower income levels compared to states.
• Territories have some discretion in setting Medicaid and CHIP eligibility standards, provider payment rates, covered benefits, and administrative structures.
• Territories have greater flexibility in setting income eligibility levels and using locally established poverty levels for determining eligibility.
• Medicaid and CHIP funding in territories is different from states, with fixed matching rates and statutory caps on federal funding.
• PPACA increased territories' FMAP and CHIP enhanced FMAP, but funding is subject to a cap and territories must assume full costs once funding is exhausted.
• Temporary increases in Medicaid and CHIP funding have allowed territories to increase spending and avoid funding shortfalls.
• Territories may experience funding shortfalls in the future due to the temporary nature of the funding.
• Territories vary in eligibility criteria, benefits covered, and methods of determining eligibility.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
495,"<summary>
• In 1980, the Congress passed the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act (CERCLA) to establish the Superfund program for cleaning up hazardous waste sites.

column2: • EPA administers the program, oversees cleanups by responsible parties, and performs cleanups itself.

column3: • States can enter into agreements with EPA for cleanup actions.
• Most states have their own hazardous waste programs for independent cleanups.

column1: • As of November 1998, EPA had investigated over 40,000 potential hazardous waste sites and made decisions on almost 35,000 sites for the National Priorities List.

column2: • EPA has completed cleanup construction at 585 sites.
• States have reported cleaning up thousands of sites under their own programs.

497,"<summary>
• OPM's retirement modernization program aims to automate and modernize the retirement processing system for federal employees.

column2: • The agency has not established a reliable cost estimate, EVM, requirements management plan, or test planning activities.

498,"<summary>
* The number of school-aged children with limited English proficiency in the US has grown significantly over the past 2 decades.

column2: * Enrollment of children with limited English proficiency increased exponentially between 1989-90 and 1997-98.

column1: * The Bilingual Education Act (BEA) was passed in 1968 to educate students with limited English proficiency.

column2: * The BEA created four bilingual education grant programs to distribute funds to school districts serving these children.

column1: * Federal programs like Title I also support children with limited English proficiency, in addition to the BEA programs.

column2: * Most services for these children are funded by local and state dollars.

column1: * The Office of Bilingual Education and Minority Languages Affairs (OBEMLA) administers the four competitive bilingual education grant programs.

column2: * The cost of administering these programs is funded through Education’s program administration account.

column1: * In fiscal year 2000, Education funded approximately 28% of the 665 applications it received for bilingual education grants.

column2: * Grants were awarded to school districts to serve children with limited English proficiency.

column1: * The four bilingual education programs have similar performance goals and measures, eligibility criteria, and uses of program funds.

column2: * They target students with limited English proficiency in kindergarten through 12th grade.

column1: * The effectiveness of the four bilingual education programs on a national level is unknown due to locally collected data not being comparable.

column2: * Grantees are required to submit evaluations every 2 years to measure student outcomes.

column1: * Education officials believe that consolidating the four bilingual education programs into one may provide benefits such as reducing administrative burden and increasing efficiency.

column2: * Consolidation may allow for more time to conduct other important program-related activities.

column1: * Peer reviewers rate applications for each of the four bilingual education programs using selection criteria to determine grant awards.

column2: * The selection criteria help assess the strength of individual applications.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
499,"<summary>
• The National Crime Information Center (NCIC) is a system maintained by the FBI that stores data on crimes, criminals, missing persons, and unidentified persons.

column2: • Over 92,000 law enforcement agencies have access to NCIC, including federal, state, and local agencies.

column3: • NCIC is managed by the FBI's CJIS division and state and local agencies.

• CJIS conducts audits of CSAs to ensure compliance with NCIC policies.
• CJIS audits CSAs to verify compliance with federal laws and NCIC policies.

column1: • CJIS audits CSAs to assess compliance with the 2-hour entry requirement for reports of missing children.

column2: • CJIS funding for NCIC audits has varied over the years.

column3: • CJIS conducts compliance audits of CSAs every 3 years.

500,"<summary>
• Automobile safety is a major concern, with efforts focused on reducing traffic fatalities and injuries.

502,"<summary>
• DOD's personal property program is used for household goods moves for military servicemembers and DOD civilians when they relocate.
• Military services pay shipment and storage costs from their budgets.
• Servicemembers work with DOD transportation officials at personal property processing offices.
• DOD previously evaluated three pilot programs to improve the quality of household goods moves.
• DOD developed Families First program to improve quality of household goods moves.
• Families First is executed by the Military Surface Deployment and Distribution Command.
• DOD's personal property system has used the Transportation Operational Personal Property Standard System since 1989.
• TOPS is being phased out due to lack of support and poor reporting capabilities.
• DOD expects TOPS to be functional until DPS is fully operational.
• Servicemembers are provided with basic claims coverage under the current system.
• Additional coverage options are available for servicemembers to purchase.
• Some private insurance companies and moving companies sell insurance to cover personal property during moves.
• DOD evaluated pilot programs and plans for implementing Families First.
• DOD submitted a report to Congress in 2002 with recommendations to improve the quality of household goods moves.
• DOD developed a new program called Families First to address the recommendations.
• Families First is executed by the Military Surface Deployment and Distribution Command.
• DOD's personal property system has used the Transportation Operational Personal Property Standard System since 1989.
• TOPS is being phased out due to lack of support and poor reporting capabilities.
• DOD expects TOPS to be functional until DPS is fully operational.
• Servicemembers are provided with basic claims coverage under the current system.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
503,"<summary>
• Tobacco is a high-value, pesticide-intensive crop grown in the United States and other countries.

column2: • Tobacco is the nation’s ninth highest valued crop and ranks sixth in pesticide use per acre.

column3: • Two states, Kentucky and North Carolina, produce two-thirds of domestic tobacco.
• The United States is the second largest producer of cigarettes in the world.
• Most tobacco is used for cigarette production, with some used for other products like chewing tobacco and cigars.
• Pesticides used on tobacco are regulated by EPA and USDA to ensure human health and environmental safety.

column1: • EPA conducts risk assessments on pesticide residues on tobacco to evaluate potential health risks to humans.

column2: • EPA focuses on short-term exposure risks and uses a tiered approach to evaluate residue levels on tobacco.

column3: • EPA requires additional residue data if levels exceed a certain threshold.
• EPA uses a margin of exposure method to quantify health risks associated with pesticide residues in tobacco smoke.
• EPA does not include tobacco residue exposure in aggregate health risk assessments of individual pesticides.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
504,"<summary>
• User financing through user fees, charges, or excise taxes is a way to fund federal programs.

column2: • User fees assign costs to identifiable users of programs.

column3: • Payers expect a link between their payments and the cost of services.
• User fees can include excise taxes with a ""user pays"" element.

column1: • Examples of user fees include those for motor fuels, tires, and heavy vehicles.

column2: • Federal programs like FAA activities are funded in part by excise taxes.

column3: • Fees must be fair and based on costs, value of service, and public policy.
• Agencies derive authority to charge fees from the Independent Offices Appropriation Act of 1952.

column1: • Legislation may authorize agencies to assess user fees.

column2: • Fee rates should be set based on the cost of providing the service.

column3: • The beneficiary-pays principle guides the allocation of costs between general public and users.
• User fees should be regularly reviewed and updated to ensure alignment with program costs.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '•'}"
505,"<summary>
* In school year 2009-2010, the District's school system enrolled over 72,300 students, including DCPS and 57 public charter schools.

column2: * Public charter schools in D.C. act independently and are authorized by the Public Charter School Board.

column1: * Federal payments were provided to DCPS and public charter schools for various initiatives, including facility financing, academic programs, and staff incentives.

column2: * OSSE and DCPS faced challenges in managing grants and contracts, leading to weaknesses in financial management and monitoring practices.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
506,"<summary>
• Agencies need to separate wants from needs in order to maximize return within fiscal constraints.
• Agency budgets may not be linked to strategic goals or consider resource limitations.
• Agencies often prioritize individual needs over collective needs.
• Congressional direction may lead to unnecessary purchases and services.
• Agencies should allocate resources based on strategic plans rather than historical precedents.
• Information technology portfolio selection criteria should align with agency missions and strategic plans.
• Many agencies have not fully implemented portfolio selection criteria.
• Lack of effective investment management at DHS hinders strategic mission support.
• Commercial companies use portfolio management to adjust resource allocations based on market changes.
• Fragmented decision-making processes in agencies can lead to individual needs overshadowing collective interests.
• DOD lacks a departmental approach to investment decision-making.
• Pursuing individual needs can lead to program instability and resource misallocation.
• Agencies may invest in capabilities that undermine agency-wide goals.
• Contracts often lack definitive requirements, fail to allocate risk appropriately, and do not reflect project complexity.
• Time-and-materials contracts pose risks to the government and lack proper oversight.
• Interagency contracting can lead to fair and reasonable pricing challenges.
• Undefinitized contract actions can waste taxpayer dollars and lack proper definitization.
• The acquisition workforce faces challenges in size, skills, knowledge, and succession planning.
• Key program staff turnover can reduce accountability and promote myopia.
• Revolving door between industry and government can present conflicts of interest.
• Lack of oversight leads to little accountability for recurring problems.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
507,"<summary>
* DOD sets a standard price per barrel for fuel customers annually based on three components: crude oil price, refinement markup, and nonproduct costs.

column2: * Crude oil price is based on forecasts provided by OMB using WTI projections.
* Refinement markup is added to account for the cost of refining crude oil into fuel products.

column1: * DOD uses the Defense-wide Working Capital Fund to purchase bulk fuel and shield military services from market price volatility.

column2: * Fluctuations in fuel prices can lead to adjustments in the standard price for the following year.
* DOD may cover fund losses by obtaining appropriations from Congress or transferring funds from other accounts.

column1: * Differences between estimated and actual fuel costs are primarily driven by fluctuations in fuel prices and differences in estimated fuel consumption levels.

column2: * Crude oil prices and refinement markup costs account for most of the differences between estimated and actual prices.
* DOD has adjusted the refinement markup to account for price differences between WTI and other crude oil benchmarks.

column1: * DOD has not reevaluated its approach for estimating fuel costs since 2007 or documented the rationale for its assumptions.

column2: * DOD's Financial Management Regulation provides guidance on setting prices but does not require detailed documentation of the methodology.
* DOD has faced challenges in setting a standard price that closely approximates actual fuel costs due to changes in market conditions.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
508,"<summary>
* DOD's procurement process involves acquiring supplies and services from nonfederal sources and administering contractual instruments.

column2: * The process begins with a requirement and ends at contract closeout.
* The SPS program was initiated in 1994 to automate contract management functions within DOD.

column1: * DOD awarded a contract to American Management Systems (AMS) to develop the SPS system.

column2: * The system was to be deployed in incremental releases, but delays and software deficiencies have occurred.
* DOD has not yet contracted for the sixth and seventh releases.

column1: * The Office of the Inspector General has issued reports critical of SPS, citing lack of functionality and user dissatisfaction.

column2: * Concerns have been raised about the cost-effectiveness of relying on a single vendor for system support.
* DOD has not met key SPS commitments regarding product delivery, user satisfaction, and use of a commercial system solution.

column1: * DOD has not accumulated total actual program costs for SPS and lacks information on cost savings and benefits realized.

column2: * The economic analysis for SPS does not reflect actual costs and benefits, raising questions about the justification for further investment.
* Incremental investment management practices are not being followed for SPS, risking continued investment in a system that may not produce commensurate value.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
509,"<summary>
* USCIS processes millions of immigration benefit applications each year

column2: * USCIS has a staff of 3,000 permanent adjudicators
* Service centers and district offices adjudicate applications

column1: * USCIS's budget in fiscal year 2005 was $1.8 billion

column2: * $1.6 billion was expected from service fees

column1: * USCIS had a backlog of several million applications in fiscal year 2004

column2: * A plan was developed to eliminate the backlog by the end of fiscal year 2006

column1: * USCIS lacks a comprehensive approach for managing risk

column2: * USCIS does not actively use administrative sanctions for immigration benefit fraud

510,"<summary>
• IRS performance during the 1994 filing season was assessed
• Focus was on processing income tax returns and refunds accurately and efficiently
• Also on providing taxpayers access to forms, information, and electronic filing methods
• Validation of accuracy and timeliness of refunds was done by reviewing 853 randomly selected refunds
• Various methods were used to achieve the objective
• Data analysis from IRS’ Management Information System
• Review of processing errors, including those involving the EIC
• Review of refund fraud reports
• Assessment of availability of tax materials at walk-in sites
• Positive aspects of the 1994 filing season included an increase in individual income tax return filings and more returns filed through alternative methods like electronic filing
• IRS computer systems generally performed well with minor delays
• IRS exceeded accuracy and timeliness goals for processing refunds and returns
• EIC continued to be a leading source of errors, contributing to IRS’ error resolution workload
• Number of fraudulent refund claims identified by IRS continued to grow
• IRS had some intermittent systems problems affecting taxpayers
• Efforts were made to improve check processing and deposit tax receipts more timely
• IRS conducted lockbox tests and required service centers to develop depositing procedures
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
511,"<summary>
* Medicaid was established in 1965 as a jointly funded federal-state program providing medical assistance to qualified low-income persons.

column2: * Each state designs and administers its own Medicaid program, subject to federal requirements for eligibility, services covered, and provider payments.

column3: * States decide whether to cover optional services and how much to reimburse providers for a particular service.
* The federal government pays a portion of whatever qualifying expenditures a state Medicaid program incurs.

column2: * In recent years, Medicaid costs have escalated, leading some states to move their Medicaid population into a capitated managed care system.

column3: * Certain provisions of the Medicaid law inhibit states' use of managed care, but waivers can be obtained from HCFA under section 1115 of the Social Security Act.
* HCFA requires states to demonstrate budget neutrality for the entire demonstration project when granting waivers.

column2: * Tennessee was the first state to move its Medicaid program enrollees to a statewide demonstration project in January 1994.

column3: * The TennCare program was designed to expand coverage to the uninsured population and control total program and state costs.
* TennCare offered insurance to uninsured and uninsurable persons regardless of income who were not eligible for Medicaid.

column2: * TennCare implemented a capitated managed care system by contracting with 12 MCOs to provide delivery of all Medicaid acute and primary care services.

column3: * MCOs were responsible for claims processing and received additional payments for high-cost chronic conditions and higher than average utilization rates.
* TennCare also provided incentive payments to physicians and supplemental payments to hospitals based on unallocated funds.

513,"<summary>

column2: • States were required to establish a system to profile new claimants for UI regular compensation and refer them to reemployment services.
• Labor issued guidance to help states establish profiling tools and provide necessary reemployment services.

515,"<summary>
* NTSB has fully implemented or made significant progress in implementing leading management practices in all eight areas addressed in 2006 and 2008.
* Implemented recommendations include facilitating communication from staff to management and aligning organizational structure to strategic plans.
* Progress has been made in areas such as IT, knowledge management, human capital management, and financial management.
* NTSB has taken steps to address diversity management within the agency.
* The agency has established goals for recruiting, developing, and retaining a diverse workforce.
* NTSB provided diversity training to senior managers and office directors.
* NTSB has made progress in investigating accidents and incidents in various transportation modes.
* The agency has developed transparent policies for selecting accidents to investigate.
* NTSB has increased its use of safety studies to improve transportation safety.
* NTSB has increased the use of its Training Center and reduced its operating deficit.
* The agency has subleased classroom space to other agencies, increasing revenues.
* NTSB has decreased personnel expenses related to the Training Center.
* NTSB has proposed changes to its authorizing legislation to allow for investigating incidents and reduce requirements for investigating rail and maritime accidents.
* The proposed changes aim to clarify NTSB's roles and responsibilities in maritime accident investigations.
* NTSB seeks to strike a balance between discretionary and criteria-based investigations to enhance transportation safety.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"

column2: * Annual performance plans under GPRA inform Congress and public of goals, measures, strategies, and procedures

517,"<summary>
* The Department of Defense (DOD) initiated the Corporate Information Management (CIM) initiative in 1989 to improve business practices and make better use of information technology.

column2: * CIM aimed to eliminate duplicative information systems across seven administrative areas within DOD.
* The primary objective of CIM was to significantly improve business processes through techniques like business process reengineering and continuous process improvements.

column1: * The CIM initiative faced challenges such as lack of acceptance by functional managers, isolation of CIM efforts, and unclear program management authority.

column2: * DOD established boards and councils to facilitate integration of CIM efforts, but more needs to be done to address these challenges.
* DOD needs to ensure active participation of functional managers, provide training to employees, and consider renaming the initiative to improve understanding and acceptance.

column1: * DOD has taken steps to address some of the challenges faced by the CIM initiative, including establishing the Enterprise Integration Executive Board and issuing the CIM Strategic Plan.

column2: * DOD should continue to revise the CIM management strategy, train employees, and consider renaming the initiative to overcome fundamental weaknesses in the management of the initiative.
* DOD disagreed with the recommendation to rename the initiative, citing potential confusion, but the benefits of improved understanding and acceptance outweigh the risks of confusion.

518,"<summary>
• Undercover investigation involved producing counterfeit documents and transporting radioactive sources

column2: • Counterfeit NRC documents and bill of lading were created using computer software

column3: • Investigators transported radioactive sources for a dirty bomb across borders
• Purchased radioactive sources and containers from commercial sources
• Suppliers did not verify legitimacy of buyers or require NRC documents for small purchases

column1: • Border crossings were successful with counterfeit documents and no questions raised by CBP inspectors

column2: • CBP inspectors used handheld devices to scan for radioactive sources

column3: • Inspectors did not question validity of counterfeit documents
• Corrective action briefings were conducted with CBP and NRC officials

column1: • NRC officials disagreed with the amount of radioactive material needed for a dirty bomb

column2: • NRC is aware of potential issues with counterfeiting documents and is working to resolve them

column3: • Concerns raised about the ease of purchasing and transporting radioactive sources
• Amount of radioactive sources transported could be sufficient for two dirty bombs

519,"<summary>
• DOD relies on research labs, industry, and academia to develop new technologies for military operations

column2: • Historically, DOD has had challenges transitioning technologies out of the lab

column3: • Technologies may not leave the lab due to lack of recognition or funding
• Acquisition programs may prefer to invest in other areas rather than final stages of technology development
• DOD faces difficulties in seizing opportunities to introduce technological advances due to budgeting process

column1: • Various technology transition programs have been established by DOD and Congress

column2: • Programs like ACTD and FCT aim to get technologies into the hands of users faster and at less cost

column3: • ACTD allows military operators to test prototypes in realistic settings
• FCT identifies and procures technologies developed and tested in other countries

column2: • Programs like MANTECH and Dual Use Science and Technology focus on solving production problems and partnering with the commercial sector

column3: • MANTECH seeks to solve production problems associated with technology transition
• Dual Use Science and Technology partners with the commercial sector on projects useful to both military and industry

column1: • Despite the benefits of certain projects, it is too early to determine the impact of technology transition programs

column2: • Only a few projects have been completed and made available to warfighters

column3: • T58 Titanium Nitride Erosion Protection project aims to improve reliability of helicopter engines in desert environments
• The Ping project aimed to broaden microwave technology capabilities but was cancelled due to accuracy issues

column1: • Effective selection, management, oversight, and assessment processes are crucial for successful technology transition

column2: • Programs must assure proposals have a sound business case and technologies are mature

column3: • Technology readiness levels assessment is a valuable tool for selecting projects
• Designating individuals as ""deal brokers"" can facilitate communication between labs and acquisition programs

520,"<summary>
• The MAF is a data file used for census and demographic surveys, containing address information and geographic codes.

column2: • The Bureau is researching targeted address canvassing to update the MAF more efficiently.

column1: • The Bureau's 2020 Census preparation is divided into five phases, with a focus on cost and quality implications.

column2: • The Bureau faces legally mandated deadlines for delivering census tabulations.

column1: • The Bureau's schedules for MAF development exhibit some characteristics of reliability but have important weaknesses.

column2: • The schedules lack comprehensive coverage, logical sequencing, and credibility.

column1: • The Bureau should improve scheduling practices in three areas: comprehensiveness, construction, and credibility.

column2: • A workforce planning process is recommended to address gaps in scheduling skills.

521,"<summary>
• The Clean Air Act was passed in 1963 to regulate air pollution from stationary and mobile sources.

column2: • The act was substantially overhauled in 1970, 1977, and 1990 to set national ambient air quality standards and reduce emissions.

column1: • States and local governments are responsible for implementing certain portions of the act.

column2: • States develop implementation plans to comply with national standards set by EPA.

column1: • EPA has made progress in improving air quality, but many Americans still live in areas with pollution exceeding federal standards.

column2: • Exposure to pollutants like ozone and particulate matter can have adverse health effects.

column1: • EPA identified 452 actions required to meet the objectives of Titles I, III, and IV of the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990.

column2: • Many of these requirements were met late, with an average delay of 24-25 months after statutory deadlines.

column1: • EPA has completed most of the required actions related to Titles I, III, and IV, but some requirements remain unmet.

column2: • Reasons for delays include stakeholder involvement, resource limitations, and competing demands.

column1: • The acid rain program under Title IV has been successful in reducing emissions through a market-based trading program.

column2: • EPA has decided not to pursue certain actions under Title IV due to resource constraints and lack of environmental benefits.

column1: • EPA is required to periodically review and revise national ambient air quality standards under Title I.

column2: • EPA has met most of the requirements related to Title I, but some rules limiting emissions of volatile organic compounds remain uncompleted.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '•'}"
522,"<summary>

column2: * Objectives included identifying effective programs, developing program models, and disseminating findings.
* The Study Group reviewed over 1,000 documents on girls' delinquency programs.
* They identified 61 programs targeting girls' delinquency and assessed their methodological quality.

523,"<summary>
* DOD established DFAS in 1991 to standardize finance and accounting operations.
* DFAS consolidated finance and accounting centers from military services and defense agencies.
* DFAS assumed control of finance and accounting operations at 332 offices.
* DFAS was designated a Defense Business Operations Fund (DBOF) business area in 1992.

526,"<summary>
* The distribution of prescription drugs involves interactions among multiple entities such as drug wholesalers, independent pharmacies, PSAOs, and third-party payers and their PBMs.

column2: * Drug wholesalers purchase drugs from manufacturers and distribute them to pharmacies, with three wholesalers accounting for over 80% of drug distribution revenue in the US.

column1: * Independent pharmacies dispense medications to consumers and account for almost 34% of retail pharmacies in the US, with prescription drugs making up the majority of their sales.

column2: * Independent pharmacies primarily purchase drugs from wholesalers and rely on PSAOs to negotiate contracts with third-party payers or PBMs on their behalf.

column1: * PSAOs provide a range of services to independent pharmacies, including contract negotiation, communication, help-desk services, and assistance with issues related to third-party payers and PBMs.

column2: * PSAOs may charge monthly fees for bundled services, with most fees paid for by member pharmacies, and they must ensure their arrangements do not unreasonably restrain trade to avoid antitrust concerns.

527,"<summary>
• Enterprise architecture is a blueprint that describes the current and desired state of an organization or functional area in both logical and technical terms.

column2: • It includes a plan for transitioning between the two states.

column1: • Enterprise architectures are important for organizational transformation and IT management in public and private organizations.

column2: • Various frameworks have been published by government agencies and OMB to define the content of these architectures.

column1: • Legislation and federal guidance require agencies to develop and use architectures.

column2: • An enterprise can be viewed as a single organization or a functional area that transcends more than one organization.

column1: • An architecture describes the enterprise in logical and technical terms for both the current and target environments.

column2: • It provides perspectives on business processes, business rules, information needs, and technical attributes.

column1: • The Federal Enterprise Architecture Framework (FEAF) provides a common construct for agency architectures.

column2: • It facilitates coordination of common business processes, technology insertion, and system investments among federal agencies.

column1: • OMB has established the Federal Enterprise Architecture Program Management Office (FEAPMO) to develop a federal enterprise architecture.

column2: • The architecture is intended to facilitate government-wide improvement through cross-agency analysis and collaboration.

column1: • Our Enterprise Architecture Management Maturity Framework provides federal agencies with a benchmarking tool for assessing and improving their architecture efforts.

column2: • It includes five hierarchical maturity stages and four critical success attributes for effective enterprise architecture management.

column1: • Most departments and agencies have not fully satisfied all core elements associated with stage 2 of the maturity framework.

column2: • However, many have fully satisfied a large percentage of core elements across stages 3, 4, and 5.

column1: • Departments and agencies have reported wide variability in costs related to developing and maintaining their enterprise architectures.

column2: • The majority of costs are attributed to contractor support and agency personnel.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '•'}"
528,"<summary>
* The U.S.-Oman Free Trade Agreement was signed in 2006 after seven months of negotiation.

column2: * Oman is strategically located at the entrance to the Persian Gulf and is a small exporter of oil and natural gas.

column1: * The agreement includes provisions for open markets, protections for labor and the environment, and broad commitments to various sectors.

column2: * Oman is seeking to diversify its economy beyond oil and gas exports and sees the U.S. as an important ally in this endeavor.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
529,"<summary>
• Concerns about hate crimes have led to the enactment of laws such as the Civil Rights Act of 1968 and the Hate Crimes Sentencing Enhancement Act of 1994.

column2: • Hate crimes are criminal offenses motivated by bias against race, religion, disability, ethnicity, or sexual orientation.

column1: • The Matthew Shepard and James Byrd, Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act expanded hate crime victims to include gender, sexual orientation, gender identity, and disability.

column2: • The law broadened federal jurisdiction to prosecute hate crimes based on these factors.

column1: • The United States Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Morrison limited Congress's authority to regulate non-economic, violent criminal conduct under the commerce clause.

column2: • The Court emphasized the need for Congress to distinguish between national and local issues when enacting legislation.

column1: • The legislative clauses of the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments grant Congress the power to enforce civil rights legislation.

column2: • Section 5 of the 14th Amendment allows Congress to pass laws to address state actions that violate equal protection or due process.

column1: • The 13th Amendment prohibits slavery and involuntary servitude, giving Congress the authority to pass laws to abolish all badges and incidents of slavery.

column2: • It is unclear whether violence based on bigotry constitutes a ""badge or incident of slavery"" under the 13th Amendment.

column1: • Constitutional limits on hate crime legislation include considerations under the 1st and 6th Amendments.

column2: • The 1st Amendment protects freedom of speech, while the 6th Amendment guarantees defendants the right to a jury trial.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '•'}"
530,"<summary>
* Some East Asian nations have been accused of keeping their currencies undervalued to maintain competitive exports.

column2: * Accusations of ""currency manipulation"" have been made against countries like China, Japan, and South Korea.

column3: * These accusations violate the Articles of Agreement of the International Monetary Fund.
* The Trade Facilitation and Trade Enforcement Act of 2015 requires enhanced analysis of exchange rates for major trading partners.
* Treasury identified six major trading partners, including China, Germany, Japan, South Korea, Switzerland, and Taiwan.

column1: * East Asian governments adopt various exchange rate policies, such as fixed, free float, and managed float.

column2: * Hong Kong has a linked exchange rate with the U.S. dollar, while Japan, the Philippines, and South Korea allow their currencies to float freely.

column3: * Most East Asian governments choose a managed float policy to balance autonomy and stability.
* Different exchange rate policies have advantages and disadvantages in terms of autonomy, risk, and stability.

column1: * The Department of the Treasury provides biannual reports to Congress on exchange rate policies of foreign countries.

column2: * The Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988 required analysis of exchange rate policies and identification of currency manipulators.

column3: * The Trade Facilitation and Trade Enforcement Act of 2015 requires reports on macroeconomic and currency exchange rate policies of major trading partners.
* The latest report placed six major trading partners on a ""Monitoring List"" for close attention to their currency practices.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"

533,"<summary>
• A variety of statutes and regulations govern oil and gas development on federal lands
• National mining and minerals policy encourages private enterprise and orderly development of mineral resources

534,"<summary>
• Policymakers are interested in reforming or limiting itemized tax deductions to increase federal tax revenue, simplify the tax code, and reduce incentives for inefficient economic behavior.

column2: • Analysis of tax filer data from the IRS provides insights into who claims itemized deductions, for how much, and for which provisions.

column3: • Tax filers can choose between a standard deduction or itemized deductions, with higher-income individuals more likely to itemize.
• Some itemized deductions have minimum threshold amounts and caps to limit benefits or eligibility.
• Specific deductions, such as charitable gifts and state/local taxes, are claimed more frequently by higher-income tax filers.

column1: • Limits on itemized deductions could impact tax filer behavior and revenue, with different structures affecting which deductions are claimed and how much revenue is generated.

column2: • A fixed dollar amount cap may target higher-income households but could limit revenue raised.
• The form of a limit on deductions could influence which deductions tax filers choose to claim.
• The extent to which a limit on deductions increases revenue depends on its structure and potential impact on tax filer behavior.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"
535,"<summary>
* The Pacific Islands region, also known as the South Pacific or Southwest Pacific, presents Congress with a diverse array of policy issues.

column2: * The region encompasses U.S. Pacific territories and has attracted Chinese diplomatic attention and economic engagement.

column1: * U.S. relations with Australia and New Zealand include pursuing common interests in the Southwest Pacific, particularly in areas such as climate change adaptation and mitigation.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
536,"<summary>
* The Endangered Species Act (ESA) provides for the listing and protection of species that are endangered or threatened with extinction.

column2: * Listing a species results in limitations on activities that could affect that species and penalties for taking individuals of a listed species.

column1: * Federal agencies are required to consult with the Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) or the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) to determine if an agency project might harm listed species.

column2: * This process is known as consultation and concludes with a biological opinion (BiOp) being issued.

column1: * If a project could jeopardize a species, a jeopardy opinion is released along with reasonable and prudent alternatives (RPAs) to avoid jeopardy.

column2: * An incidental take statement is issued to excuse any incidental taking of listed species.

column1: * The exemption process is available for federal projects that cannot be conducted without jeopardizing species.

column2: * The process allows for economic factors to override jeopardy to the species.

column1: * The Endangered Species Committee (ESC) reviews applications for exemptions and is composed of top government officials.

column2: * Application for an exemption is limited to three eligible entities: the federal agency proposing the action, the governor of the state, or the permit or license applicant.

column1: * An exemption application must describe the consultation process already carried out and explain why the action cannot be altered to conform to the ESA requirements.

column2: * The Secretary must determine if the applicant has met three criteria before proceeding with the exemption process.

column1: * The ESC must convene a formal hearing on the application and prepare a report within 140 days of determining the applicant has met the requirements.

column2: * The ESC must grant an exemption if it determines there are no reasonable and prudent alternatives, the benefits of the action outweigh alternative courses of action, and the action is of regional or national significance.

column1: * An exemption from the ESC is permanent unless it would result in the extinction of a species not identified in a biological assessment.

column2: * The penalties for taking an endangered or threatened species do not apply to takings resulting from actions that are exempted.

column1: * The exemption process is rarely invoked due to the complexity, costs, and the need for the applicant to fund mitigation measures.

column2: * The consultation process provides opportunities for federal agencies to modify their actions to avoid harm to listed species and avoid the need for an exemption.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
537,"<summary>
* The taxation of capital gains income has been a topic of debate in Congress since 1913.

column2: * Numerous bills are introduced each session to change the taxation of capital gains income.
* Congress has shown interest in the tax treatment of capital losses.
* The loss limit prevents selective realization of losses from being a significant problem.

column1: * The tax treatment of capital gains and losses has changed over the years.

column2: * Historically, there have been legislative changes to address the tax treatment of gains and losses.
* The current system has asymmetries in the treatment of long-term gains and losses.
* Recent economic proposals aim to stimulate the economy through tax benefits.

column1: * Increasing the net capital loss deduction may not effectively stimulate the economy.

column2: * An increase in the loss limitation could depress stock prices and benefit higher income individuals.
* The tax benefits of an increase in the loss limitation may not translate into increased spending.
* Restoring the value of the loss limitation to its 1978 level would require addressing asymmetry in the tax system.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
538,"<summary>
* The National Labor Relations Act (NLRA) recognizes the right of employees to engage in collective bargaining through representatives of their own choosing.

column2: * The Act aims to mitigate labor-related obstructions to the free flow of commerce.
* Congressional interest in the NLRA remains significant, with over 30 bills introduced in the 112th Congress to amend the Act.

column1: * The NLRA defines ""supervisor"" as an individual with authority to perform specific functions requiring independent judgment.

column2: * Job title does not determine supervisor status.
* The NLRB and courts have interpreted the term ""supervisor"" in various cases.

column1: * In NLRB v. Kentucky River Community Care, Inc., the Court considered whether nurses should be classified as supervisors based on their use of independent judgment.

column2: * The Court set forth a three-part test for determining supervisory status.
* The Court disagreed with the NLRB's interpretation of ""independent judgment.""

column1: * In Oakwood Healthcare, Inc., the NLRB defined terms like ""assign,"" ""responsibly to direct,"" and ""independent judgment"" as used in the NLRA.

column2: * The NLRB concluded that charge nurses were supervisors based on their exercise of independent judgment.
* The NLRB considered various factors in determining supervisory status.

column1: * The NLRA prohibits certain misconduct by both employers and unions that interferes with the right to engage in collective bargaining.

column2: * Sections 8(a)(1) and 8(b)(1)(A) outline unfair labor practices related to interference and coercion.
* Courts assess whether misconduct ""reasonably tends"" to restrain or coerce employees.

column1: * Employers and unions have restrictions on communication with employees, including antiunion speeches and distribution of union literature on company property.

column2: * Last-minute speeches before elections are prohibited.
* The Court has upheld an employer's right to restrict union communication on its premises if other channels are available.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
539,"<summary>
• Banks play a central role in the financial system by connecting borrowers to savers and allocating capital across the economy.

column2: • Banking is vital to the health and growth of the U.S. economy.
• Banking is an inherently risky activity involving extending credit and taking on liabilities.
• Banking can generate tremendous societal and economic benefits, but banking panics and failures can create devastating losses.

column1: • Over time, a regulatory system designed to foster the benefits of banking while limiting risks has developed, and both banks and regulation have coevolved as market conditions have changed and different risks have emerged.

column2: • Congress often considers policies related to the banking industry.
• Recent years have been a particularly transformative period for banking.
• The 2008-2009 financial crisis threatened the total collapse of the financial system and the real economy.
• Many assert only huge and unprecedented government interventions staved off this collapse.

column1: • Others argue that government interventions were unnecessary or potentially exacerbated the crisis.

column2: • Many argue the crisis revealed that the financial system was excessively risky and the regulatory system had serious weaknesses.
• Many regulatory changes were made in response to perceived weaknesses in the financial regulatory system, including to bank regulation.
• Congress enacted the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (P.L. 111-203; Dodd-Frank Act) in 2010 with the intention of strengthening regulation and addressing risks.

column1: • In addition, U.S. and international bank regulators agreed to the Basel III Accords—an international framework for bank regulation—which called for making certain bank regulations more stringent.

column2: • In the ensuing years, some observers have raised concerns that the potential benefits of the regulatory changes (better-managed risks, increased consumer protection, greater systemic stability, etc.) are outweighed by the potential costs (e.g., reduced credit availability for consumers and businesses, and slower economic growth).

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
540,"<summary>

• The Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Extension Act of 2007 made changes to Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP programs, including suspending a Medicare physician payment cut and providing SCHIP funding through March 2009.

column2: • The Act also extended various expiring provisions and programs, such as Medicare Advantage plans and Medicaid payments.

column1: • The Act included funding for miscellaneous activities, such as State Health Insurance Assistance Programs and grants for Area Agencies on Aging.

column2: • The Act established a 0.5% increase in the Medicare physician fee schedule for the first six months of 2008 and provided FY2008 and FY2009 SCHIP allotments through March 31, 2009.

column1: • The Act also addressed issues related to Medicare physician payment, cost-based Medicare plans, and the calculation of average sales price for Medicare Part B drugs.

column2: • The Act extended provisions related to Medicare payments for certain providers and services, such as rural hospitals and outpatient therapy services.

column1: • The Act included provisions related to Medicaid payments, such as increased payments for Medicaid disproportionate hospital share allotments and coverage of Medicare part B premiums under the Qualifying Individual program.

column2: • The Act extended the Title V Abstinence Education block grant through June 30, 2008 and provided funding for research into the prevention of Type I diabetes and grants for the prevention and treatment of diabetes among American Indians and Alaskan Natives.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '•'}"
541,"<summary>
* House committees adopt rules at the beginning of each Congress
* Rules govern authority, operations, and procedures of committees
* Committees must comply with House directives and adopt written rules
* Committees must submit reports on activities at the end of each Congress
* Committee records are property of the House and must be preserved
* Committees have specific rules for hearings, markups, and meetings
* Hearings and markups must be open to the public
* Committees may close meetings under certain circumstances
* Committees must maintain records of rollcall votes and hearings
* Committees must include oversight findings and recommendations in reports
* Committees have rules for staff, funding, and travel
* Committees can appoint professional staff and consultants
* Committees must follow rules for staff salaries and travel expenses
* Committees must submit views and estimates on spending to the Budget Committee
* Committees must submit reports on foreign travel expenses and activities
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
542,"<summary>
* ASEAN is a multilateral organization in Southeast Asia with 10 member countries and a combined population of 580 million and GDP of $1.5 trillion.

column2: * Established in 1967 to foster regional dialogue during the post-colonial, Cold War period.
* ASEAN has grown into one of the world's largest regional fora, representing a strategically and economically important region.

column1: * The Obama Administration is pursuing a policy of expanding and upgrading U.S. relations with Southeast Asia and ASEAN.

column2: * The Bush Administration was perceived as narrowly focused on terrorism and neglectful of other issues.

column1: * The United States has deep-seated interests in Southeast Asia, including maritime security, democracy promotion, trade, counterterrorism, and combating illegal trafficking.

column2: * China's economic and cultural ties in Southeast Asia have led to a ""soft power"" rivalry with the United States.

column1: * The United States has close bilateral relations with many ASEAN nations, with Thailand and the Philippines as U.S. treaty allies.

column2: * The Obama Administration has taken steps to deepen ties with ASEAN, including attending ASEAN meetings and acceding to the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation.

column1: * ASEAN was founded in 1967 to prevent domination by any single power and to forge independent foreign policies during the Cold War.

column2: * ASEAN has an informal structure and operates on principles of consensus and non-interference in internal affairs.

column1: * ASEAN has been actively promoting economic integration through the ASEAN Free Trade Area and the ASEAN Economic Community.

column2: * ASEAN has also negotiated trade agreements with countries like Australia, China, India, Japan, and South Korea.

column1: * The United States provides assistance to ASEAN for trade facilitation, counterterrorism, security sector reform, and environmental protection.

column2: * U.S. funding for East Asia Pacific regional programs totaled $20 million in 2009.

column1: * China, Japan, and the United States are key external powers in Southeast Asia, with China's influence growing in recent years.

column2: * Japan is the largest donor of development assistance in the region, while the United States exerts a strong military presence.

column1: * Congress has played a role in U.S. policy toward ASEAN, including pushing for FTAs, addressing labor and environmental concerns, and sanctions policy toward Burma.

column2: * The conduct and outcome of Burma's 2010 parliamentary elections may impact U.S. policy toward Burma and ASEAN relations.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
543,"<summary>
* The ""state sponsors of terrorism list"" is mandated under Section 6(j) of the Export Administration Act of 1979, listing countries that provide support for acts of international terrorism.

column2: * Countries on the list face trade restrictions, aid limitations, and other sanctions.
* Cuba has been on the list since 1982, along with Iran, North Korea, Sudan, and Syria.

column1: * Various laws restrict trade benefits, foreign aid, and support to countries on the terrorism list.

column2: * Validated licenses are required for exports to these countries, except for certain items like humanitarian assistance.
* Bilateral assistance is restricted in foreign assistance appropriations acts.

column1: * Cuba was added to the terrorism list in 1982 due to its support for terrorist groups in Latin America.

column2: * Cuba supported groups like the M-19 guerrilla group in Colombia.
* The State Department alleged Cuba's ties to international terrorism in reports from the 1980s.

column1: * Cuba has been accused of providing safe haven to members of terrorist organizations and U.S. fugitives from justice.

column2: * Cuba has hosted members of the Basque ETA group and Colombian guerrilla groups.
* The presence of fugitives in Cuba has been a point of contention between the U.S. and Cuba.

column1: * The U.S. has accused Cuba of having a limited offensive biological weapons program.

column2: * There is disagreement over the existence and extent of Cuba's biological weapons program.
* Some observers believe Cuba has the capability for biological warfare but question if it has an active program.

column1: * Critics argue that Cuba's retention on the terrorism list is a Cold War relic.

column2: * They believe Cuba has made efforts to fight terrorism and has offered to negotiate with the U.S.
* Some question the rationale for keeping Cuba on the list based on its current activities.

column1: * The level of terrorist activity varies among countries on the state sponsors of terrorism list.

column2: * Iran is considered the most active state sponsor of terrorism.
* Some suggest a tiered approach to sanctions based on the degree of support for terrorism.

column1: * Flexibility in adding and removing countries from the terrorism list is debated.

column2: * Some believe there should be more flexibility to incentivize behavioral changes.
* Others argue that current legislative conditions provide sufficient flexibility for the Administration.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
544,"<summary>
• The Alternative Minimum Tax (AMT) provides for an alternative tax calculation on a broader tax base than the regular tax.

column2: • Individuals add back a variety of provisions including business provisions, itemized deductions, standard deduction, and personal exemptions.

column1: • The AMT base is broader than the regular tax base, but excludes benefits of lower capital gains tax rates and certain deductions.

column2: • The number of taxpayers subject to the AMT has increased over time due to inflation and lack of indexing exemptions.

column1: • In 2009, over 9 million taxpayers are projected to pay the AMT, constituting 6.3% of all tax returns filed.

column2: • The AMT will gradually reach further down into the income distribution.

column1: • The cost of correcting the AMT is significant, with estimates of billions of dollars by 2008 and beyond.

column2: • Indexing AMT exemptions and eliminating credit limit provisions are among the proposed solutions.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '•'}"
545,"<summary>
• The THUD Appropriations Subcommittees draft bills for annual appropriations for DOT, HUD, and related agencies.
• DOT primarily provides grants for transportation infrastructure and oversees safety.
• FAA operates the U.S. air traffic control system and employs the majority of DOT's workforce.
• HUD addresses housing issues for low-income households and special needs populations.
• The THUD bill funds agencies involved in transportation, housing, and community development.
• Agencies include the Access Board, Federal Maritime Commission, and National Transportation Safety Board.
• Other agencies include the U.S. Interagency Council on Homelessness and Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.
• Most of the THUD bill's funding comes from regular annual appropriations and contract authority.
• Contract authority controls spending from trust fund resources for transportation infrastructure.
• Appropriators are subject to limits on discretionary funding and use rescissions and offsets to offset costs.
• The Trump Administration requested a reduction in funding for DOT and HUD in FY2018.
• Reductions included zeroing out programs and cutting funding for various initiatives.
• The House and Senate proposed different funding levels for THUD in FY2018.
• The House and Senate Appropriations Committees reported FY2018 THUD bills based on informal suballocations.
• The House bill would result in a reduction in real funding, while the Senate bill would result in a slight increase.
• Budget savings from rescissions and offsets allow for additional discretionary appropriations.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"
546,"<summary>
* The U.S. and India established a ""global partnership"" in 2005, focusing on economic issues, energy, democracy, non-proliferation, and high-technology.

column2: * India has positive relations with Iran, which could potentially hinder U.S.-India ties.

column1: * India maintains positive ties with Iran, especially in energy commerce, despite U.S. opposition to Iran.

column2: * Indian firms have long-term contracts for Iranian gas and oil, and support a pipeline project from Iran to India through Pakistan.

column1: * India's relations with Iran have historical and civilizational ties, but India aligns with international efforts to bring Iran's nuclear program into compliance.

column2: * India faces challenges balancing its relations with the U.S. and Iran, with domestic political forces urging resistance to U.S. pressure.

column1: * India and Iran have steady but low-level defense relations, with expectations of expanding military ties under the 2003 ""New Delhi Declaration.""

column2: * Joint naval exercises and cooperation in defense have not evolved into a significant strategic alliance.

column1: * India imports Iranian crude oil and has a significant trade relationship with Iran, including a $22 billion deal for Iranian LNG.

column2: * India's energy ties with Iran, including a proposed gas pipeline, could conflict with U.S. policy and the Iran Sanctions Act.

column1: * India and Iran cooperate in Afghanistan to counter Sunni Islamic extremism, supporting the Northern Alliance against the Taliban and providing aid to the Afghan government.

column2: * Both countries aim to prevent a Taliban return to power and have interests in stabilizing Afghanistan.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
547,"<summary>
• Low farm milk prices and declining dairy farm incomes in 2009 led to renewed interest in imposing new import barriers on milk protein concentrates (MPCs).
• MPCs are derived from raw milk and used in various food products, animal feed, and industrial products.
• U.S. imports of MPCs have limited trade restrictions, while advocates of stricter controls argue it would benefit domestic producers and raise milk prices.
• Opponents fear increased costs and higher retail food prices, with major foreign suppliers likely seeking compensation under WTO rules.
• Milk is mostly water, with the remaining 12.6% consisting of milk solids split into fat, protein, lactose, and minerals.
• Milk protein is primarily casein and whey protein, with MPCs containing both and identified by their protein content.
• MPCs have wide-ranging applications in the food industry, with different protein levels used in various products.
• Some food manufacturers prefer MPCs over nonfat dry milk due to better functionality and composition control.
• The U.S. produces minimal casein or milk protein concentrates, with federal dairy policies favoring nonfat dry milk production.
• U.S. imports of dairy products were valued at over $3 billion in 2008, with MPCs and casein/caseinates representing 35% of total import value.
• Legislation has been proposed to impose new import restrictions on MPCs, with potential implications for U.S. dairy farmers and trade agreements.
• Enactment of the proposed legislation could lead to compensation negotiations with major MPC suppliers and potential impacts on U.S. dairy exports.
• U.S. milk producers support legislation to limit MPC imports, citing disruptions to farm-level prices, while dairy processors oppose further import restrictions.
• The potential impact of imposing TRQs on MPCs depends on farm prices relative to USDA's purchase price levels and could affect government purchases and farm prices.
• Imposing TRQs on MPCs could have a small effect on average U.S. farm milk prices, but some view it as part of broader policies to address the financial situation for dairy farmers.
• USDA purchased surplus dairy products from 2008 to 2009, primarily nonfat dry milk, with the impact of TRQs on farm prices dependent on product prices and government purchases.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
548,"<summary>
* Serbia has undergone political and economic changes since the defeat of Slobodan Milosevic in 2000:

column2: * Transition towards Western democratic and free market standards
* Challenges include organized crime, corruption, and economic setbacks
* Focus on integration into the European Union

column1: * Recent political developments in Serbia include:

column2: * 2012 elections with a coalition government led by the Serbian Progressive Party
* Presidential election victory of Tomislav Nikolic over Boris Tadic
* Formation of a new government with a coalition of parties

column1: * Relations with Kosovo remain a key issue for Serbia:

column2: * Negotiations and agreements with Kosovo under EU mediation
* Challenges in implementing agreements, particularly in northern Kosovo

549,"<summary>
* The Supreme Court decided four search and seizure cases during its October 2012 term

column2: * Cases involved questions related to dog sniffs, probable cause, and blood testing in drunk-driving cases
* The Court clarified Fourth Amendment standards for dog sniffs, probable cause for vehicle searches, and exigencies for blood testing
