617,"<summary>
* Antireflection (AR) technology is crucial for high-efficiency solar cells by increasing light coupling into the active region.

column2: * Combining surface texturization with thin-film deposition can reduce light reflectivity in crystalline silicon solar cells.
* Nanostructures like nanowires and nanocones based on wide bandgap materials, such as ZnO, are used for AR layers.

column1: * ZnO nanorod arrays have shown better antireflective properties than other oxide compounds.

column2: * A weighted global reflectance of 6.6% has been achieved in the broadband range from 400 to 1,200 nm.

column1: * ZnO nanowhiskers (NWS) grown on CZ silicon solar cells can improve efficiency by 3%.

column2: * The NWS are grown using a seeding and growth two-step process in zinc salt and amide mixed solutions.

column1: * The growth time of ZnO NWS affects their density, length, and performance on solar cells.

column2: * Longer growth times result in higher reflectivity due to increased light absorption by the NWS.

column1: * ZnO NWS-coated solar cells exhibit lower reflectance and higher external quantum efficiencies.

column2: * Solar cells with ZnO NWS grown for 45 min show the highest efficiency improvement of 3%.

column1: * Prolonged immersion of solar cells in the growth solution can lead to a deterioration in cell performance.

column2: * The fill factor and efficiency of the cell may decrease with longer growth times.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
618,"<summary>
* Hyperhidrosis is a condition that affects 0.6 to 1.0% of the population, primarily young adults.

column2: * It generally occurs in the axillae, palms, feet, and face.
* Primary hyperhidrosis can be exacerbated by emotional stress and manifests in childhood.
* Treatment options include surgery, such as sympathicotomy at the third or fourth rib level.
* Compensatory sweating is a common side effect, with r4 sympathicotomy showing lower incidence compared to r3.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
619,"<summary>
• Parkinson's disease (PD) is a common neurodegenerative parkinsonian syndrome characterized by degeneration of dopaminergic and nondopaminergic neurons with Lewy bodies.

column2: • Clinical diagnosis of PD can be challenging, especially in mild or uncertain cases, and in differentiating from other parkinsonian syndromes.

column3: • Early and accurate diagnosis is crucial for proper management and prognosis.
• Molecular imaging techniques like PET or SPECT using dopamine transporter (DAT) ligands and sympathetic innervation imaging have improved diagnostic accuracy.
• DAT SPECT and MIBG myocardial scintigraphy are commonly used in clinical practice to visualize dopaminergic degeneration and sympathetic cardiac nerve terminals.

column2: • A retrospective study compared DAT SPECT and MIBG scintigraphy results in patients with suspected parkinsonian syndromes to evaluate diagnostic accuracy.

column3: • The combination of DAT SPECT and MIBG scintigraphy showed improved accuracy in differentiating PD from non-PD.
• The sensitivity and specificity of the combined approach were higher than individual molecular methods.

620,"<summary>
* Amblyomma testudinarium is a large, ornate tick species that feeds on a variety of vertebrates, including humans in Asian countries.

column2: * In Korea, human infestation with A. testudinarium is rare, with only a few reported cases, including a 73-year-old man who was infested in the perianal area.

column1: * The tick was identified as a female adult A. testudinarium based on morphological characteristics, and it is commonly found in warm, subtropical areas like South East Asia and the Indian peninsula.

column2: * The tick embeds its anterior part, called capitulum, into the skin to feed, causing skin laceration and inflammatory responses in the dermis.

column1: * Histopathological observations of the tick attachment site showed a feeding lesion with inflammatory cell infiltrations and a paucicellular zone possibly due to tick saliva's anti-inflammatory effects.

column2: * The tick's salivary glands secrete eosinophilic cement material to aid attachment, with distribution varying based on mouthpart length.

621,"<summary>
* Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) is characterized by left and/or right ventricular hypertrophy, with predominant involvement of the interventricular septum.
* Familial HCM is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in genes encoding sarcomere proteins.
* Major genes causing HCM include myh7, tropomyosin, tnnt2, mybpc3, tnni3, myl2, and myl3.
* Mutations in tnnt2 account for approximately 15% of familial HCM and are associated with a severe form of the disease.
* Mutations in tnnt2 alter the contractile properties of cardiac muscle.
* Genetic analysis and determination of genotype are important for risk stratification.
* Late gadolinium enhancement with cardiac magnetic resonance can predict ventricular arrhythmia and poor prognosis in HCM.
* Mutation-specific risk stratification is considered clinically informative.
* The genotype-phenotype correlation of tnnt2 in Japanese familial HCM remains insufficient.
* DNA analysis in 173 Japanese patients with familial HCM identified reported and new mutations in tnnt2.
* Different families with the same genetic mutation showed varying phenotypes.
* Sudden death in youth was observed in all families with tnnt2 mutations.
* The clinical importance of a deletion/deletion polymorphism in tnnt2 needs further investigation.
* The type of genetic mutation alone is not useful in predicting prognosis in HCM.
* Detailed observation of patients from birth is crucial regardless of genetic mutation type.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
622,"<summary>
• Schistosomatidae includes several digenetic endoparasites with complex life cycles, infecting a wide range of hosts.

column2: • Developmental stages alternate between intermediate hosts (freshwater gastropods) and definitive hosts (birds, reptiles, fishes, mammals).

column1: • Schistosoma species have increased longevity in human hosts, causing schistosomiasis.

column2: • Six species infect humans: S. haematobium, S. intercalatum, S. japonicum, S. malayensis, S. mansoni, S. mekongi.

column1: • Schistosomiasis is a serious public health issue, endemic in 77 countries, affecting millions of people worldwide.

column2: • Control methods include drug treatment, snail control, sanitation, and health education.

column1: • Advances in genomics and transcriptomics have improved understanding of schistosome biology.

column2: • Sequencing projects have decoded nuclear and mitochondrial genomes of Schistosoma species.

column1: • Transcriptomic analyses have identified gene expression profiles and posttranscriptional regulatory mechanisms.

column2: • Functional studies using RNA interference and transgenesis tools are being developed for schistosomes.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '•'}"
623,"<summary>
• Patients with synchronous colorectal liver metastases (SCLM) often undergo hepatic resection for treatment.

column2: • Reported 5-year survival rates range from 23% to 37%.
• Resections of both primary colorectal lesion and hepatic metastases are needed for resectable SCLM.

column1: • Optimal surgical strategy for resectable SCLM is controversial.

column2: • Simultaneous resection of primary colorectal and liver tumors is favored by some, but others report high morbidity rates.
• Staged resection is considered an alternative strategy to reduce surgical stress.

column1: • Factors affecting postoperative morbidity and anastomotic leakage after simultaneous resection were analyzed.

column2: • Intraoperative blood loss and operation time over 8 hours were predictive factors for complications.
• Presence of diverting stoma, extent of hepatectomy, and timing of anastomosis did not correlate with complications.

column1: • Hospitalization was longer for patients with postoperative morbidity and anastomotic leakage.

column2: • Overall survival rate after simultaneous resection for SCLM was 61% at 3 years and 45% at 5 years.
• Staged resections should be considered when operation time is expected to exceed 8 hours to prevent complications.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"
624,"<summary>
• Asthma is a chronic inflammatory disease that affects daily activities and requires pharmacological treatment for control.

column2: • Inhalation is the most common approach for asthma treatment, allowing drugs to reach the lungs effectively.

column3: • However, many patients struggle with correct inhaler use, leading to treatment failure and non-adherence.

column1: • Validating inhaler technique scores can help identify common errors, classify patients, and improve inhaler use through educational programs.

column2: • Errors such as inadequate breath-holding and incorrect inhalation speed are common and impact drug efficacy.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '•'}"
625,"<summary>
• Bacteriocins are ribosomally synthesized antimicrobial peptides produced by bacteria with potential applications in food preservation, human and veterinary use, and animal production.
• Bacteriocins can have a broad spectrum of activity across genera, influenced by environmental conditions such as salt concentration, pH, and inducing cultures.
• Gram-positive bacteriocins are classified into four classes, including lantibiotics, heat-stable peptides, large heat-labile proteins, and complex proteins.
• Enterococcus strains are known for producing bacteriocins with diverse structures and modes of action against various pathogens.
• Enterocin S37, produced by E. faecalis, showed antagonistic activity against Listeria and Campylobacter species.
• The antibacterial activity of Enterocin S37 was tested against various gram-negative and gram-positive bacteria.
• Purification and characterization of Enterocin S37 revealed its stability at different pH levels and high temperatures.
• Enterocin S37 exhibited increased activity during purification and interacted with K channel modulators to affect the growth of sensitive and resistant strains of L. monocytogenes.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
626,"<summary>
* Lumbar punctures were successfully performed in children with spinal muscular atrophy using a 24-gauge needle or smaller, resulting in lower incidence of complications.

column2: * Bed rest, hydration, oral caffeine, and analgesics were effective in resolving post-lumbar puncture headache/syndrome without the need for a therapeutic blood patch.

column1: * Intrathecal delivery of medication was found to be feasible, safe, and well tolerated in children with spinal muscular atrophy.

column2: * Ultrasound guidance may be beneficial in reducing radiation exposure compared to fluoroscopy for repeated procedures.

627,"<summary>
* Clinical governance (CG) is a strategy introduced by the UK Department of Health in 1997 to improve the quality of healthcare services.

column2: * CG aims to continuously improve service quality and safeguard high standards of care.
* The Iranian Ministry of Health and Medical Education (MOHME) implemented CG in hospitals in 2009, focusing on seven components including clinical effectiveness and risk management.

column1: * Senior managers play a crucial role in CG implementation by demonstrating knowledge, attitude, and commitment towards the program.

column2: * Managers with adequate knowledge and positive attitude towards CG are more optimistic about its success.
* Continuous training on CG principles can enhance managers' positive attitude towards the program.

column1: * Organizational factors such as culture, commitment, and effective interactions within departments are key facilitators in CG implementation.

column2: * A culture promoting alignment of CG goals at all levels and embedding CG components in daily work is essential.
* Adequate organizational commitment, effective communication, and staff involvement are crucial for successful CG implementation.

column1: * Barriers to CG implementation include lack of resources, resistance from staff overwhelmed by workload, and concerns about program sustainability.

column2: * Shortage of staff, limited resources, and resistance from physicians and medical staff are major obstacles in CG implementation.
* Incentive mechanisms, employee recognition, and stable managerial positions are suggested to mitigate barriers and sustain staff motivation in CG implementation.

628,"<summary>
* Hydatid cyst disease is a zoonotic disease caused by the larval stage of the Echinococcus granulosus parasite.

column2: * Canines are the final host, spreading the parasite through feces.
* Herbivores are the main intermediate host, becoming infected by consuming contaminated forage.

column1: * Human infection occurs through contaminated water, vegetables, or direct contact with infected dogs.

column2: * Hydatid cysts commonly affect the lungs and liver in humans.
* The disease's epidemiological, clinical, and pathological symptoms vary based on factors like age and gender.

column1: * Hydatidosis is prevalent in regions with animal husbandry, with high incidence rates in countries like Argentina and China.

column2: * Iran is considered hyper-endemic due to close contact with animals and traditional animal husbandry practices.
* The prevalence of hydatid cysts in Iran ranges from 1.1% to 13.7% in different regions.

column1: * A study in Khorasan Razavi province in 2011-14 found 357 cases of hydatid cysts.

column2: * Most cases were in cities like Mashhad, with a higher proportion in women.
* Abdominal pain was the most common symptom, with liver involvement in 59.4% of patients.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
629,"<summary>
* Friederich described the first case of a ciliated hepatic foregut cyst (CHFC) in 1857, suggesting a congenital origin.

column2: * Wheeler and Edmonson coined the term CHFC and identified specific characteristics differentiating it from other hepatic cysts.
* CHFC is thought to result from foregut evagination during embryonic development.

column1: * Approximately 103 cases of CHFC have been reported worldwide, with laparoscopic excision being rare.

column2: * A 32-year-old woman underwent successful laparoscopic excision of a CHFC.
* CHFC is most commonly found in segment IV of the left lobe of the liver.

column1: * CHFC typically presents as an asymptomatic, unilocular cyst with specific histological features.

column2: * Imaging techniques show variable appearances of CHFC, with ultrasound, CT, and MRI being used for diagnosis.
* Differential diagnosis includes simple cyst, hydatid cyst, biliary cystadenoma, and bronchogenic cyst.

column1: * Treatment of CHFC varies from observation to surgical excision, with laparoscopic excision being recommended for larger or symptomatic lesions.

column2: * Laparoscopic excision is effective for lesions in segments II to VI, with minimal morbidity and easy access to the cyst.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
630,"<summary>
• Orally dissolving strips are a popular form of drug delivery due to their quick absorption and ease of administration.

column2: • They dissolve within 60 seconds in the mouth without the need for water or chewing.

column1: • Clobazam, an antiepileptic drug, was formulated into orally dissolving strips for quick management of seizures.

column2: • The strips were optimized using a 3 factorial design with pva and ssg as key polymers.

column1: • Physicochemical characterization showed that the strips were flexible, smooth, and uniform in drug content.

column2: • In vitro studies demonstrated rapid drug release and suitable disintegration time for the optimized formulation.

column1: • In vivo studies in rabbits showed comparable results between the optimized strip and a marketed tablet.

column2: • Stability studies indicated that the formulation was stable for at least 6 months.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '•'}"
631,"<summary>
* Stroke is a major cause of death and disability worldwide, with survivors often experiencing impairment post-stroke.

column2: * Recovery from stroke is complex and multidimensional, involving bio-medical, psychological, and sociological elements.

column3: * Self-management practices are key to promoting recovery and improving health outcomes.
* Evaluation of self-management interventions must consider whether individuals develop skills to manage their health and if this leads to better health.
* Theoretical premises and outcome measures used in stroke self-management interventions are unclear.
* Measures used in stroke self-management interventions need to be developed with involvement from the target population to enhance content validity.

column1: * Outcome measures used in stroke self-management interventions lack consensus and may not accurately reflect the concept of self-management.

column2: * Measures often focus on physical functioning, but may not capture other important aspects of self-management.

column3: * Theoretical bases for stroke self-management interventions are unclear, leading to difficulties in selecting appropriate outcome measures.
* Further research is needed to conceptualize stroke self-management and develop robust outcome measures for evaluation.
* Studies should explore the theoretical underpinnings of self-management interventions in stroke to inform the development of interventions.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
632,"<summary>
* Osteoarthritis in the knee joint is a common cause of functional disability in elderly individuals in India.
* Factors influencing OA severity include age, height, weight, and BMI.
* Physiotherapy aims to reduce pain, improve daily activities, and enhance quality of life in OA knee patients.
* Self-reported questionnaires and performance-based tests are used to monitor progress in pain, symptoms, ADL, and QOL.
* Examples of self-reported questionnaires include WOMAC, SF-36, and KOOS.
* Physical performance tests like TUG and 6MWT assess functional limitations.
* There is debate on whether self-reported questionnaires or performance-based tests are more effective in evaluating OA knee patients.
* Ideally, both types of assessments should be used in knee rehabilitation settings.
* A study aimed to correlate the KOOS questionnaire with the 6MWT, age, height, weight, and BMI in OA knee patients.
* Results showed weak correlation with height, stronger correlation with weight and BMI, and no correlation with age.
* Previous studies have shown correlations between self-reported measures and physical performance tests in OA knee patients.
* Weight gain is associated with worsening pain, stiffness, and function in knee pain patients.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
633,"<summary>
• An increasingly sedentary lifestyle and high consumption of caloric foods have led to obesity becoming a global issue.

column2: • Obesity is a chronic inflammatory disease caused by factors like eating habits, sedentary lifestyle, and genetic predisposition.

column3: • Adipose tissue secretes both proinflammatory and anti-inflammatory factors.
• High-fat diets in rodents can induce metabolic changes and chronic inflammation.
• Menopause can increase the risk of cardiovascular diseases due to hormonal changes.
• Estrogen plays a role in modulating inflammation and metabolic processes.

column1: • A study on rats showed that a high-fat diet combined with ovariectomy led to increased body weight gain and hyperleptinemia.

column2: • Ovariectomy combined with a high-fat diet caused changes in cytokine levels in adipose tissues.
• The combination of a high-fat diet and ovariectomy increased carcass lipid content and body weight gain.
• Estrogen replacement has been shown to decrease food intake and restore weight in ovariectomized rats.
• The study suggests that estrogen may have a proinflammatory effect on white adipose tissue.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
634,"<summary>
• Hemoptysis is a common symptom in respiratory diseases, with a mortality rate of over 50% when massive.
• Quick treatment is necessary to stop bleeding in cases of significant or life-threatening hemoptysis.
• Bronchial artery embolization (BAE) is a safe and effective treatment for massive, chronic, or recurrent hemoptysis.
• A retrospective study of 344 patients undergoing BAE showed successful control of hemoptysis in 96% of cases.
• Complications of BAE included arterial spasm, closure, and subintimal dissection, with recurrent bleeding occurring in 17.7% of patients within 1 month.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
635,"<summary>
• Helicobacter pylori (hp) infection and celiac disease (cd) can both lead to lymphocytic gastritis in pediatric patients.

column2: • Both conditions show an increase in intraepithelial lymphocytes (iels) and lymphoid aggregates in the gastric mucosa.

column1: • Immunohistochemical analysis of cd8 lymphocytes in the antrum may help differentiate between cd and hp infection in cases with overlapping features.

column2: • The presence of cd8+ iels may suggest a diagnosis of cd, while the number of lymphoid follicles may indicate hp infection.

636,"<summary>
• Angiogenesis is a crucial process for tumor growth, and targeting VEGF can inhibit this process in cancer treatment.

column2: • VEGF inhibitors like bevacizumab can reduce tumor growth and microvessel density in breast cancer.
• Anti-VEGF therapy also decreases macrophage infiltration in tumors, which is important for cancer treatment.

column1: • Inhibition of VEGF can lead to changes in immune cell infiltration and cytokine levels in breast cancer xenografts.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '•'}"
637,"<summary>
• Vulvar and vaginal atrophy (VVA) is a common medical condition in postmenopausal women, impacting quality of life and sexual relationships.

column2: • VVA symptoms are often not discussed with healthcare providers, leading to delayed diagnosis and treatment.

column1: • Effective patient education and communication between healthcare providers and patients are essential for identifying and managing VVA symptoms, with various treatment options available.

column2: • Screening questions and proactive patient education can help improve patient adherence and outcomes in managing VVA.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '•'}"
638,"<summary>
* In Denmark, women planning to conceive are advised to take 400 g of folic acid daily until the 12th week of gestation to reduce the risk of neural tube defects.

column2: * Neural tube closes at gestational week 6, making preconceptional fa supplementation crucial.
* Despite campaigns promoting fa recommendation, only 5-10% of Danish women have sufficient dietary folate intake.

column1: * Compliance with fa supplements among pregnancy planners in Denmark remains low, with only 22% adhering to the recommendation.

column2: * Predictors of noncompliance include young age, low education, smoking, overweight, and parity.
* No study has examined other health-related predictors of compliance during the preconceptional period.

column1: * A study of Danish pregnancy planners found that 62% adhere to the fa recommendation.

column2: * Higher age, education, income, and intercourse frequency were associated with increased fa or mv use.
* Lifestyle factors like smoking, alcohol intake, BMI, and physical activity also influenced fa or mv supplement use.

column1: * Previous spontaneous abortion and desire to conceive were positively associated with fa or mv use.

column2: * Chronic diseases like hypertension, diabetes, and thyroid disease did not significantly impact preconceptional supplement use.

639,"<summary>
• Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) is commonly caused by atherosclerosis in the lower extremities and is associated with increased cardiovascular risk.

column2: • PAD can manifest as intermittent claudication and is linked to oxidative stress and high cholesterol levels.

column3: • Statins, such as simvastatin, are effective in reducing lipid levels and improving endothelial function in PAD patients.
• Surgical treatment for PAD may lead to changes in lipid peroxidation parameters and antioxidant capacity.
• Further research is needed to understand the mechanisms and effects of statins in treating PAD.

640,"<summary>
* The demand for herbal remedies in Nigeria has been increasing, but there is a lack of scientific data to support their medicinal claims.

column2: * Herbal formulations are commonly used in Nigerian homes for health benefits due to limited access to formal healthcare.
* Concerns include the potential toxic effects of indiscriminate use of packaged herbals and the lack of scientific data to support claimed benefits.

column1: * The herbal remedy Fijk is made from a mixture of 13 medicinal plants and is indicated for various ailments.

column2: * Scientific data supporting the medicinal benefits of Fijk are lacking.
* Oral and repeated exposure to Fijk in rats resulted in changes in plasma biochemical indices and liver morphology.

column1: * The study found that exposure to Fijk herbal mixture caused reductions in rat plasma protein levels and alterations in lipid profile.

column2: * Elevated levels of triglycerides and LDL-C were observed, while HDL-C levels decreased.
* The study also showed increased levels of ALT and AST, indicators of tissue toxicity, in rats exposed to Fijk.

column1: * Oral and repeated exposure to Fijk in rats led to lipid peroxidation and oxidative stress, as evidenced by changes in MDA and GSH levels.

column2: * The histopathological examination revealed hepatic alterations, including hemorrhage and inflammation, in rats exposed to Fijk.
* The findings suggest potential health risks associated with the consumption of Fijk herbal mixture.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
641,"<summary>
* Carrier screening and testing for autosomal recessive or x-linked disorders before pregnancy can benefit prospective parents by identifying genetic risks and reproductive options.

column2: * Carrier screening detects carrier status in individuals without an increased risk, while carrier testing is for those with a higher risk based on personal or family history.

column3: * Screening can be offered individually or as part of an organized program during or before pregnancy.
* The goal of preconceptional carrier screening is to strengthen reproductive autonomy and informed decision-making.
* Commercial companies offer direct-to-consumer genetic tests for carrier screening, raising ethical concerns about informed consent, medical supervision, and resource use.
* The availability of carrier tests through commercial companies may disconnect the service from medical supervision and impact healthcare budgets.
* The criteria for responsible genetic testing, including the importance of the health problem and the predictive value of the test, should be considered.
* The potential negative psychosocial impacts of carrier testing and the need for quality information and counseling should be addressed to ensure informed decision-making.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
642,"<summary>
* Substantial growth in options for operative fracture treatment in recent decades

column2: * Newer and better internal fixation devices and implants
* Specially designed intramedullary nails, plates, and screws
* Titanium alloys and stainless steel commonly used for orthopedic implants

column1: * Debate over removal of asymptomatic hardware

column2: * Lack of clear guidelines
* Varying viewpoints among surgeons and patients
* Routine removal in children but not in adults

column1: * Common indications for implant removal

column2: * Pain/discomfort, infected hardware, implant failure, patient's insistence, other reasons
* Most common reasons: pain/discomfort and infected hardware
* Majority of patients needing removal were male

column1: * Complications and risks associated with implant removal

column2: * Difficulty in removing hardware from bone
* Loss of contour of screw heads
* Potential for major vascular injury or iatrogenic fracture

column1: * Need for concrete indication guidelines for implant removal

column2: * Routine removal in asymptomatic patients not recommended
* Removal surgeries fraught with risks and complications
* Removal may not always fulfill intended purpose

column1: * Limitations of the study

column2: * Small sample size and short follow-up period

643,"<summary>
• Glaucoma is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by the gradual loss of retinal ganglion cells and optic nerve atrophy.

column2: • Factors related to glaucoma include high intraocular pressure and low cerebral spinal fluid pressure.

column3: • Mller cells, the major type of glial cells in the retina, play a role in supporting retinal neurons and maintaining retinal function.
• Reactive Mller cells can exacerbate retinal damage by releasing cytokines like tumor necrosis factor-alpha.

column1: • In a rat model of acute ocular hypertension mimicking glaucoma, treatment with -aminoadipic acid (AAA) inhibited Mller cell gliosis and protected against retinal abnormalities induced by increased intraocular pressure.

column2: • AAA treatment reduced apoptosis of retinal ganglion cells, rescued the reduced number of ganglion cells, and attenuated Mller cell gliosis and tumor necrosis factor-alpha production in the retina.

column3: • These findings suggest that AAA may be a potential therapeutic target for neurodegeneration in glaucoma.

• AAA treatment showed protective effects on the retina by promoting survival of retinal ganglion cells through inhibiting Mller cell gliosis and downregulating tumor necrosis factor-alpha production.

644,"<summary>

column2: * Offers complete resection without peritoneal exposure of tumor cells or severe adverse events.

645,"<summary>
• Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is caused by defects in enzymes necessary for cortisol synthesis, with 90-95% of cases caused by 21-hydroxylase deficiency.

column2: • Patients with 21-OHD may experience signs of androgen excess, such as ambiguous genitalia in females and rapid somatic growth.
• Treatment typically involves oral glucocorticoid and mineralocorticoid administration to compensate for adrenal steroid deficiencies.

column1: • Four cases of patients with CAH managed with hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone developed adrenal masses.

column2: • Adrenalectomy was performed in two cases due to increasing mass size and virilization.
• Adrenal masses are common in untreated CAH patients, with most being benign.

column1: • CAH is an autosomal recessive condition caused by mutations in the cytochrome P450 21-hydroxylase gene.

column2: • The pathophysiology of CAH involves cortisol deficiency, leading to hyperplastic adrenal glands and metabolic disturbances.
• Classic CAH presents with cortisol and aldosterone deficiency, while non-classic CAH may manifest as hyperandrogenism.

column1: • Diagnosis of CAH can be done through newborn screening programs or corticotropin stimulation tests.

column2: • Treatment aims to suppress adrenal androgens while allowing for normal growth and development, with fludrocortisone used in salt-losing cases.

646,"<summary>
* Self-rated health (SRH) is a validated tool to predict mortality in populations with and without cardiovascular diseases.
* SRH is associated with lifestyle behaviors such as diet and physical activity.
* Poor SRH is linked to factors like lack of adherence to medical recommendations and symptoms of chronic diseases.
* High consumption of fruits and vegetables and regular physical activity can reduce the risk of cardiovascular diseases.
* Gender differences were observed in the relationship between lifestyle behaviors and SRH.
* Females who consumed fewer fruits and vegetables, high-fat foods, and engaged in less physical activity were more likely to report poor/fair SRH.
* Males who consumed high-fat foods and engaged in less physical activity were also more likely to report poor/fair SRH.
* The study population consisted of a diverse group, primarily minorities, with a significant proportion of Hispanics and Blacks.
* Ethnic differences in SRH were observed, with Hispanics rating their health poorer than non-Hispanic whites.
* Lifestyle behaviors such as diet, physical activity, and fat intake were associated with SRH, highlighting the importance of modifiable risk factors in cardiovascular disease prevention.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
647,"<summary>
* Endoscopic injection of dextranomer/hyaluronic acid copolymer (DX/HA) is a popular treatment option for pediatric vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) due to its ease of technique and short recovery time.

column2: * Success rates for DX/HA injections vary worldwide, with an overall success rate of 75% for patients and 84% for renal units after the first injection.

column1: * Intraoperative cystograms, such as positional instillation of contrast (PIC) cystography, can help detect occult VUR and guide treatment decisions, but they do not completely replace postoperative studies.

column2: * PIC cystography has been shown to be sensitive in identifying VUR and can prevent postoperative contralateral new onset of VUR in patients with unilateral reflux.

648,"<summary>
* The accuracy of detecting fetal pathology with ultrasound depends on the expertise of the sonographer and limitations of the imaging technique.

column2: * Limitations include descent of the fetal head, ossification of skull bones, maternal obesity, and oligohydramnios.
* Fetal MRI has become increasingly important in diagnosing prenatal anomalies, especially central nervous system pathology.
* MRI is used as an adjunct to ultrasound for cases of ventriculomegaly.
* Ventriculomegaly is classified based on the diameter of the lateral ventricles and thickness of brain parenchyma.
* Causes of ventriculomegaly include fluid imbalance, abnormal cerebral development, and destructive disease processes.
* Additional anomalies are often detected with ventriculomegaly, with varying incidence rates.
* Fetal MRI is safe and mainly performed on 1.5 Tesla scanners.
* MRI has limitations such as fetal motion impact and lower spatial resolution compared to ultrasound.
* MRI is valuable in detecting intraventricular hemorrhage, corpus callosum dysgenesis, cortical anomalies, and other malformations.

649,"<summary>
* Lung cancer is the third most common cancer in the US and the leading cause of cancer-related death.

column2: * In 2012, 226,160 patients were diagnosed with lung cancer and 160,340 died from the disease.

column1: * Early-stage lung cancer is often asymptomatic, leading to diagnosis at advanced stages.

column2: * The stage distribution of lung cancer cases diagnosed from 1999-2006 showed distant metastasis in 56% of cases.

column1: * Bone metastasis is common in lung cancer patients and can lead to skeletal-related events (SREs).

column2: * SREs include pathological fractures, spinal cord compression, and severe pain requiring treatment.

column1: * A study analyzed data from the SEER program and Medicare claims to quantify the impact of bone metastasis on mortality in older lung cancer patients.

column2: * Patients with bone metastasis had a higher risk of death compared to those without.

column1: * The study found that bone metastasis was associated with mortality in all age groups and stages of lung cancer.

column2: * The most common SRE in patients with bone metastasis was radiotherapy to bone.

column1: * Limitations of the study include the age restriction to 65 years and older and the lack of validation for identifying bone metastasis.

column2: * Other factors like treatment and comorbid conditions may also influence mortality outcomes.

650,"<summary>
• Fiber-reinforced posts offer advantages over cast posts in terms of esthetics, physical properties, and modulus of elasticity.

column2: • Posts are typically cemented with resin cements, which play a crucial role in retention and restoration success.

column1: • Self-adhesive resin cements, though less investigated, have shown resistance to moisture, fluoride release, and satisfactory esthetic and mechanical properties.

column2: • These cements do not completely remove the smear layer, affecting bond strength compared to etch and rinse systems.

column1: • Various chemical substances, such as sodium hypochlorite and EDTA, are used to remove the smear layer and enhance micromechanical retention of the cement.

column2: • Photodynamic diode laser treatment has shown promising results in increasing bond strength by modifying the smear layer.

column1: • A study compared different smear layer removal methods on bond strength of self-adhesive cement with fiber posts, showing significant differences in bond strength.

column2: • The use of photodynamic diode laser and orthophosphoric acid resulted in higher bond strength compared to other methods.

column1: • The study suggests that removal of the smear layer and formation of the resin-dentin interdiffusion zone are crucial for successful post restoration.

column2: • Laser treatment with a diode laser at a lower power level can improve bonding effectiveness without causing thermal damage.

652,"<summary>
* Onychomycosis is a chronic fungal infection of the nail, commonly caused by dermatophytes, yeasts, and nondermatophytes.

column2: * Trichophyton rubrum and Trichophyton mentagrophytes are the most common agents, with prevalence higher in toenails.
* Risk factors include aging, reduced peripheral circulation, and diabetes weakening the immune function.

column1: * Treatment of onychomycosis is challenging due to slow nail growth and limited drug penetration.

column2: * Topical antifungals are commonly used, but new drugs with greater safety and efficacy are needed.

column1: * A study on the use of tazarotene 0.1% gel for onychomycosis treatment showed promising results.

column2: * Tazarotene demonstrated therapeutic efficacy in reducing onychomycosis symptoms.

column1: * Further research is needed to confirm the efficacy of tazarotene in treating onychomycosis in a larger patient population with longer follow-up periods.

653,"<summary>
• Cardiac resynchronisation therapy (CRT) is an important treatment for heart failure patients with left ventricular dyssynchrony.

column2: • However, clinical non-response to CRT is reported in 25-35% of patients.

column1: • Causes of suboptimal response include patient selection and inadequate delivery of CRT therapy.

column2: • Challenges in optimal lead placement can be due to various factors such as coronary vein stenosis and lead instability.

column1: • A study was conducted on 24 patients who were not responding to CRT despite adequate medical therapy.

column2: • Acute haemodynamic response (AHR) was measured with endocardial pacing at different sites.

column1: • Patients with a positive AHR from endocardial pacing showed clinical improvement after 6 months.

column2: • Lead location, particularly in the posterolateral region, played a significant role in response to therapy.

column1: • Endocardial pacing opposite epicardial sites did not show acute haemodynamic improvement.

column2: • Further research is needed to determine the optimal cut-off value for AHR and the potential benefits of epicardial pacing as an alternative to endocardial lead placement.

654,"<summary>
* Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD) affects 1 in every 500 to 1 in every 1000 individuals, with various risk factors associated with a more rapid disease progression.

column2: * Complications in pregnant patients with chronic renal failure undergoing dialysis include maternal hypertension, preeclampsia, and anemia.

655,"<summary>
* The study analyzed milk yield patterns in cows based on biological efficiency and lactation persistency.

column2: * High persistency is linked to a slower decline in milk production, while low persistency is linked to a rapid decline.

* Lactation curve models were used to predict milk yield at different points during lactation.

column1: * Data on fortnightly test-day milk yields of Karan Fries cows over 12 years was collected from a livestock farm in India.

column2: * The climate of the farm is subtropical with varying temperatures and rainfall.
* Test-day milk yield increased until the 4th fortnight and then declined steadily.
* Peak milk yield was observed in the 4th parity in both normal and mastitis cows.

column1: * The study found that initial milk yield, peak milk yield, and lactation persistency varied across different parities in cows.

column2: * Peak milk yield was lower in the first parity and increased in subsequent parities.

* Male mice were fed different doses of NDGA starting at 12 months of age, with 3.5g/kg diet extending lifespan by 12%.

658,"<summary>
• Myosin Va is a processive molecular motor involved in intracellular cargo transport along the actin cytoskeleton.
• It consists of motor domains, lever arms, a coiled-coil rod domain, and a cargo-binding domain.
• Myosin Va's movement is driven by ATP hydrolysis and amplified by the lever arms.
• The motor's flexibility allows it to maneuver through actin intersections and switch tracks on actin bundles.
• Tethered particle microscopy was used to measure the flexural stiffness of individual myosin Va motors and their subdomains.
• The lever arms were found to have a flexural stiffness necessary for proper gating and processivity.
• The compliance of the lever arm/rod junction allows myosin Va to efficiently navigate through the dense actin meshwork.
• Changes in calcium levels can alter the lever arm stiffness, potentially affecting cargo transport and delivery in cells.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
659,"<summary>

* The study aimed to predict clinical outcomes after surgical resection of esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) or esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) based on genetic polymorphisms in proto-oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes.

column2: * Six single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in different genes were genotyped in 346 esophageal cancer patients who underwent surgery.
* Univariate analysis showed no significant associations between the tested polymorphisms and disease-free survival (DFS) in patients with EAC or ESCC.

column1: * In multivariate analysis, patients with EAC carrying the heterozygous mdm2 (rs2279744) genotype had improved DFS, while those with the homozygous cdh1 (rs5030625) genotype had reduced survival.

column2: * The mdm2 SNP was associated with a reduced risk of disease recurrence, while the cdh1 SNP was associated with an increased risk of recurrence.

column1: * The study suggests that genetic variations in proto-oncogenes and tumor suppressor genes can impact DFS in patients with esophageal cancer.

column2: * Patients with specific genotypes may benefit from early detection of recurrent disease and tailored treatment strategies.

column1: * Further prospective studies are needed to validate these associations and explore the prognostic significance of genetic variants in esophageal cancer patients.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
660,"<summary>
• The oral cavity is commonly colonized by Candida species in healthy individuals, with Candida albicans being the most prevalent.

661,"<summary>
• Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women, with approximately 1.67 million new patients diagnosed annually worldwide.
• Breast cancer predominantly spreads via the lymphatic system to locoregional lymph nodes.
• Sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB) with the combined technique of radioisotope and blue dye is the standard method for determining axillary staging in early-stage breast cancer patients.
• The use of radioisotopes is subject to stringent regulations on training of staff and handling and disposal of radioactive material.
• Recently, the use of a magnetic tracer and a handheld magnetometer was evaluated as a radiation-free alternative.
• Three different-sized superparamagnetic iron oxide (SPIO) formulations were evaluated in an in vivo porcine model.
• The hydrodynamic particle size of the magnetic tracers ferumoxytol, sienna+, and ferumoxide was determined to be 32 nm, 59 nm, and 111 nm, respectively.
• In vivo magnetic hotspots from the draining inguinal lymph nodes were successfully identified using the handheld magnetometer.
• The 59 nm tracer demonstrated the best performance in terms of rapid distribution, retention in the first nodes reached, and accumulation in high concentration.
• The 59 nm tracer is currently the best performing magnetic nanoparticle tracer approved for human use in SLNB with a handheld magnetometer.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
662,"<summary>
* Visceral adipose tissue-derived serine proteinase inhibitor (vaspin) is expressed in various tissues and is associated with metabolic traits.

column2: * Vaspin levels are higher in men with metabolic syndrome and diabetic patients with renal insufficiency.
* Serum vaspin levels are not significantly different between patients with renal insufficiency and those without, but are lower in diabetic patients compared to non-diabetic individuals.
* Adiponectin levels are higher in individuals with renal insufficiency, regardless of diabetes status.

column1: * Adiponectin is a hormone associated with obesity-linked diseases and cardiovascular risk.

column2: * Adiponectin levels are reduced in obese individuals, particularly those with visceral obesity.
* Adiponectin levels are higher in individuals with renal insufficiency and lower BMI, but no difference is seen in diabetic patients with or without renal insufficiency.

663,"<summary>

• Data from two multicenter, double-blind, randomized clinical trials were used to test surrogate variables for neuropathic DFUs and explore the correlation between granulation tissue development and complete healing.

column2: • Trials included patients with Wagner grade 3 or 4 DFUs >1 cm, receiving intralesional injections of rHEGF.
• Surrogate markers of complete healing were generated, including percent change in area, log healing rate, and ratio of log areas at the 2nd week and end of treatment.

column1: • Granulation tissue development was found to be a predictor of wound healing in advanced DFUs.

column2: • Granulation tissue covering >75% of the ulcer area at the end of treatment was the most efficient predictor of healing.
• The proportion mediated by granulation tissue in the healing process was close to 100%.

column1: • Area change variables were proposed as surrogates for healing, but their predictive capacity was lower in more complex ulcers.

column2: • Cutoff points for these variables may need further research and validation in larger samples.
• Granulation tissue development can be a valuable predictor for wound healing in clinical trial design and new product development for diabetic foot ulcers.

664,"<summary>
* Laparoscopic transabdominal preperitoneal (TAPP) mesh repair is a standard treatment for inguinal hernia in adults.

column2: * Patients undergoing TAPP repair often experience early postoperative pain, which can lead to chronic pain.

column1: * Surgical trauma, mesh implantation, and mesh fixation are possible causes of postoperative pain.
* The use of fibrin glue or self-fixating mesh with microhooks can reduce chronic groin pain.
* Needlescopic surgery (NTAPP) and single-incision laparoscopic surgery (STAPP) have shown superior outcomes compared to conventional TAPP repair.

column2: * NTAPP involves smaller trocars and shorter operative times than STAPP.

column1: * NTAPP results in reduced postoperative wound pain and shorter sick leave compared to STAPP.
* Both NTAPP and STAPP procedures have similar long-term outcomes in terms of hernia recurrence, abdominal wall mobility, and cosmetic satisfaction.
* NTAPP is associated with less surgical trauma to the abdominal wall tissue and requires less operating time than STAPP.
* Further research, including randomized controlled trials, is needed to validate the benefits of needlescopic surgery in hernia repair.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
665,"<summary>
• The breathing process is essential for survival, with nose breathing providing ideal conditions for air reaching the lungs.

column2: • Nose breathing activates immunological processes like mucociliary transport and microbicidal activity.

column3: • Mouth breathing in childhood can lead to pathological adaptations in facial structures.
• Causes of mouth breathing in children include tonsil hypertrophy and nasal issues.
• Mouth breathing can result in functional changes in the stomatognathic system.
• A multidisciplinary approach is necessary for diagnosing and treating mouth breathers.

column1: • Nasopharyngoscopy and cephalometry are used to diagnose hyperplasia of the pharyngeal tonsils.

column2: • Nasopharyngoscopy provides a dynamic view of the nasopharynx, while cephalometry underestimates tonsil size.

column3: • Cephalometry can complement nasopharyngoscopy by providing information on facial growth.
• Nasopharyngoscopy is considered the gold standard for assessing nasopharyngeal obstruction.
• Cephalometry is useful for early identification of alterations in mouth-breathing patients.

666,"<summary>
• Breast cancer survivors may experience ipsilateral breast tumor relapse (IBTR) after treatment, which can be classified as either a true local recurrence (TR) or a new primary tumor (NPT).

column2: • TR is characterized by regrowth of malignant cells from the original tumor site, while NPT arises from residual breast tissue with different histological features.

column3: • Genetic sequencing is the best way to differentiate between NPT and TR, although classification criteria are not standardized yet.
• Salvage mastectomy is the standard treatment for IBTR, providing locoregional control in 90% of patients, but further studies are needed to determine optimal systemic therapy.

• Patients with TR have a poor prognosis and may benefit from more aggressive adjuvant treatment, while those with NPT generally have a favorable prognosis and similar therapeutic decisions to de novo breast carcinoma patients.

667,"<summary>
* Age-related macular degeneration (AMD) is a leading cause of severe vision loss in people aged 55 and older.
* Neovascular AMD, involving choroidal neovascularization (CNV), is the main cause of severe central vision loss.
* Upregulation of angiogenic factors, including vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), plays a role in AMD development.
* Intravitreal anti-VEGF treatment has transformed AMD management, with agents like ranibizumab and aflibercept being effective options.
* Clinical studies have shown that switching to aflibercept from ranibizumab can lead to improvements in contrast sensitivity, visual acuity, and central retinal thickness.
* Aflibercept has a longer duration of action and higher binding affinity to VEGF compared to ranibizumab.
* CS testing can detect subtle vision changes not captured by visual acuity testing alone.
* The NEI VFQ-25 questionnaire is used to assess vision-related quality of life in patients with chronic eye diseases.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
668,"<summary>
• Multiple sclerosis (MS) is an autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, causing cognitive and physical impairments.
• MS is most commonly the relapsing-remitting type, with genetic and environmental factors playing a role in its development.
• IL-25, a cytokine involved in immune responses, has been studied for its potential role in MS pathogenesis.
• A study in an Iranian population evaluated the c424c/a polymorphism within the IL-25 gene in MS patients.
• The study found no association between the c424c/a polymorphism and MS in the Iranian population.
• Other polymorphisms within IL-25 may be more relevant in regulating its expression in inflammatory diseases like MS.

669,"<summary>
• Aortic aneurysm (AA) can be life-threatening, and aorta size is crucial for determining the need for intervention to prevent ruptures, dissections, or aneurysm-related deaths.

670,"<summary>
• Endometrial cancer has surpassed cervical cancer as the most common invasive malignancy in developed countries.

column1: • There is a need for an effective approach to screening endometrial carcinoma and its precursors to reduce new cases and deaths.

column2: • Endometrial complex hyperplasia with atypia and endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia are considered precursors of type I endometrioid adenocarcinoma.

column1: • Traditional methods for obtaining endometrial samples for histologic analysis include D&C or hysteroscopy.

column2: • The adequacy of specimens obtained using the SAP-1 device compared to traditional methods is unknown.

column1: • Liquid-based SurePath preparation for endometrial cytology testing aims to maintain the three-dimensional structure of the endometrium.

column2: • Histology is the gold standard for evaluating the accuracy of endometrial cytology testing.

column1: • The SAP-1 device is a flexible latex loop with spines and a smooth tip designed for minimal pain during sampling.

671,"<summary>
* Breast cancer is the most common cancer among women worldwide, with high incidence rates in Europe and North America.

column2: * Screening mammography has been associated with up to a 50% reduction in breast cancer mortality.
* Digital mammography (DM) has shown improved sensitivity and reduced radiation dose compared to screen-film mammography (SFM).

column1: * Tomosynthesis, a 3D mammography procedure, may help overcome limitations of conventional mammography in detecting breast tumors.

column2: * Intravascular contrast material with DM may enhance tumor detection by taking advantage of malignant neovascularity.

column1: * Adding digital breast tomosynthesis (DBT) to standard mammography has shown promise in increasing cancer detection rates and reducing false-positive recalls.

column2: * DBT provides clearer imaging of breast tissue by creating thin slices, reducing the problem of overlapping tissue.

column1: * DBT has the potential to decrease recall rates, improve patient comfort, and increase efficiency in detecting and characterizing abnormalities.

column2: * Combining DBT with other modalities, such as contrast-enhanced techniques, may further enhance cancer detection and reduce the need for additional imaging.

672,"<summary>
• Diphenhydramine has been shown to inhibit cough reflex sensitivity, making it an effective antitussive.

column2: • Diphenhydramine is classified as an antitussive by the FDA and is commonly used in OTC cough and cold medications.

column1: • Dextromethorphan is the most commonly used OTC antitussive in the US, but lacks robust evidence supporting its efficacy.

column2: • Studies on dextromethorphan's ability to inhibit cough reflex sensitivity are outdated and limited.

column1: • Capsaicin cough challenge testing is a reliable method for measuring the effect of pharmacological interventions on cough reflex sensitivity.

column2: • The concentration of capsaicin inducing 5 or more coughs is a standard end point in capsaicin cough challenge testing.

673,"<summary>
• The global population, especially in developed countries, is aging, leading to an increase in cardiovascular diseases.

column2: • Aging is associated with decreased ability to resist cellular stresses and increased cardiovascular risk factors.

column1: • Endothelial dysfunction plays a key role in cardiovascular diseases in the elderly.

column2: • Alterations in endothelial function can lead to atherosclerosis and other vascular disorders.

column1: • Oxidative stress and inflammation are major mechanisms involved in endothelial aging.

column2: • Exercise has been shown to improve endothelial function by boosting antioxidative and anti-inflammatory mechanisms.

column1: • Endothelial cells play a crucial role in vascular function by producing nitric oxide and other vasodilators.

column2: • Aging leads to a decline in endothelial repair capacity and function, contributing to cardiovascular diseases.

column1: • Regular exercise can slow down age-related losses in endothelial function and upregulate antioxidant defense mechanisms.

column2: • Exercise-induced increases in shear stress and nitric oxide production contribute to improved endothelial function.

674,"<summary>
• Axillary lymph node status is the most important prognostic factor in breast carcinoma.

column2: • Prognosis worsens with increasing number of metastatic lymph nodes.

column1: • The number of metastatic lymph nodes depends on the number of removed lymph nodes.

column2: • Studies show that the number of metastatic lymph nodes increases with more lymph nodes removed.

column1: • The lymph node ratio (lnr) provides more useful prognostic information compared to nodal disease classification.

column2: • Studies indicate that higher lnr values are associated with worse prognosis.

column1: • Different lnr threshold values have been identified for different types of disease recurrence.

column2: • lnr is a more powerful prognostic factor than the number of metastatic lymph nodes.

column1: • lnr can be used to separate breast carcinoma patients with 1-3 metastatic lymph nodes into low- and high-risk prognostic groups.

column2: • lnr may be useful in standardizing adjuvant therapy and comparing treatment results between different hospitals.

675,"<summary>
• Acid phosphatases can efficiently transfer phosphate moieties onto hydroxylated compounds using inorganic polyphosphates as activated phosphate donors.

column2: • Enzymes such as phonsf, phonse, and piacp were found to be efficient catalysts in phosphorylating various alcohols.

column3: • Phonsf generally delivered the highest product titers with primary alcohols as acceptors.
• The enzymes displayed absolute chemoselectivity for ophosphorylation over nnucleophiles.
• Kinetic control of the reaction is crucial to maintain high product titers and avoid product depletion by hydrolysis.
• Physical separation of the phosphatase using a continuous flow reactor can help maintain high product levels and scale up the reaction.

column1: • The enzymatic phosphorylation of primary and secondary alcohols using acid phosphatases proceeded with high regioselectivity for primary hydroxy groups.

column2: • The use of mild reaction conditions allowed for the formation of phosphate monoesters as sole products.

column3: • This resulted in environmentally innocuous inorganic monophosphate and unreacted phosphate donor as byproducts.
• The thermodynamically favored hydrolysis of phosphate esters could be minimized by controlling various reaction parameters.
• Scale-up was demonstrated by the synthesis of 4hydroxybutyl phosphate using an immobilized enzyme in flow mode.

676,"<summary>
* Various non-native biological invaders have been noted for centuries, causing significant impacts on ecosystems and species.
* Examples include the phylloxera destroying grapevines in Europe and the chestnut blight devastating tree species in North America.
* Charles Elton's work in the 1950s brought attention to non-native invasions, leading to increased research and public awareness.
* Research on invasive species has shown impacts on native species through competition, predation, and disease transmission.
* Recent research has focused on ecosystem-level impacts and genetic interactions between native and introduced species.
* Criticisms of invasion biology include concerns about overblown problems, xenophobia, and inhumane methods of control.
* Some critics argue that introduced species can increase biodiversity or that the battle against invasions is futile.
* The debate also includes philosophical discussions on the rights of individuals versus collective entities like species.
* Despite criticisms, research has shown that many introduced species have harmful impacts, and eradication efforts can be successful.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
677,"<summary>
• Schwannomas of the vidian canal are rare tumors that can cause symptoms such as headaches, facial pain, and nasal dryness.

column1: • Recent advancements in imaging and radiation delivery offer more conformal treatment options for vidian canal schwannomas.

column2: • Options such as single-fraction stereotactic radiosurgery and fractionated radiation therapy can provide effective tumor control while minimizing adverse effects.

678,"<summary>

• Short-segment posterior spinal instrumentation using pedicle screws is a standard method for fixing thoracic and lumbar fractures, with advantages including less surgical dissection, blood loss, and time in surgery.
• Loss of reduction and instrumentation failure are common with this technique due to poor bone quality, inadequate anterior column support, and insufficient points of fixation.

• The addition of intermediate screws at the level of a burst fracture significantly increases the stability of short-segment pedicle fixation, regardless of whether monoaxial or polyaxial pedicle screws are used.
• The intermediate screws provide a 3-point fixation of the fractured segment, reducing flexion, extension, and torsion in both monoaxial and polyaxial screw groups.
• The use of polyaxial screws facilitates the installation of the connecting rod and may provide better coupling between the screw heads and the rod, resulting in less stress on the entire construct.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
679,"<summary>

• Electrochemical self-assembly (ESA) of nanostructured hybrid thin films of inorganic semiconductors and organic dyes has opened a new synthetic route for obtaining photoanode material for dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs).

column2: • ESA method bypasses the high-temperature sintering needed for nanoparticulate TiO2 electrodes, allowing the use of conductive plastic substrates.

column3: • ESA with ZnO structures has been demonstrated for constructing photoanodes.
• Addition of water-soluble dye molecules with substituents for anchoring to ZnO surface impacts crystal growth and nanostructure evolution.
• Coprecipitation of dye molecules does not deteriorate ZnO crystallinity.

column1: • CUSCN-based hybrid thin films prepared through ESA could serve as a counterpart to ZnO-based hybrid systems.

column2: • Dyes with soft Lewis basic NCS groups are suitable for binding to soft Lewis acidic Cu(I) sites of CUSCN.

column3: • Dyes like N3 and FLTC were added to the bath for electrodeposition of CUSCN.
• Hybrid thin films exhibited dye-sensitized photocathodic properties, showing hole injection from the dye excited state.

column1: • Method for ESA of hybrid CUSCN/RB nanoporous films allows nearly complete removal of RB SDA.

column2: • Varying relative concentration of Cu and SCN changes crystal orientation of resulting nanostructure.

column3: • Preliminary dyes show photoinduced hole transfer to CUSCN.
• Best systems tested in photoelectrochemical studies for dye-sensitized photocathodic properties.

680,"<summary>

column2: • Most patients are symptom-free, but some may develop bursitis, a cyst, or an abscess.

column1: • The incidence of nasopharyngeal bursitis is approximately 4% in adults.

column2: * In 2012, there were 76,250 new cases of invasive melanoma in the USA, resulting in 9,180 deaths.

column1: * Dermoscopy is a noninvasive diagnostic technique that aids in visualizing morphological features.

column2: * Different techniques like solar scan and epiluminescence microscopy can improve diagnostic sensitivity.

682,"<summary>
* Type 2 diabetes is a chronic disease characterized by high blood glucose levels.

column2: * Complications of type 2 diabetes include cardiovascular disease, renal failure, and blindness.
* The number of people with diabetes is expected to rise to 552 million by 2030.
* Lifestyle and genetic factors contribute to the development of type 2 diabetes.

column1: * Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor coactivator 1 (PGC-1) gene is involved in various metabolic processes.

column2: * Genetic studies have shown associations between PGC-1 loci and type 2 diabetes.

column1: * Genetic polymorphisms in Mfn2 and Esrra genes were evaluated for associations with type 2 diabetes.

column2: * Certain alleles of Mfn2 gene were found to confer protection against type 2 diabetes.

* Interactions between genetic variants in Mfn2, Esrra, and PGC-1 genes were observed in relation to type 2 diabetes.

column1: * Further studies are needed to explore the functions and interactions of Mfn2, Esrra, and PGC-1 genes in the pathogenesis of type 2 diabetes.

column2: * Functional studies, multiplex-gene analyses, and computational biology are recommended.

683,"<summary>

column2: * High on-treatment platelet reactivity with clopidogrel is associated with increased risk of ischemic events, particularly stent thrombosis.

684,"<summary>

column2: * She experienced medically intractable seizures that worsened over time despite anti-epileptic drugs.

686,"<summary>
• Type 1 diabetes is characterized by autoimmune destruction of pancreatic cells, leading to insulinopenia symptoms.

column2: • Glucose homeostasis is restored with exogenous insulin, and some patients experience partial remission (PR) or a honeymoon period.

column3: • PR is defined by insulin-dose-adjusted A1c levels and correlates with stimulated C-peptide levels.
• PR is a crucial target for interventions to preserve residual beta-cell mass.
• PR duration varies, with most patients experiencing it for less than a year.

column2: • Factors influencing PR include absence of diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) at diagnosis and lower A1c levels.

column3: • Girls entering PR had lower A1c levels at diagnosis, while younger patients had shorter PR durations.
• Early A1c levels may predict PR duration, with lower levels associated with longer PR.

column2: • C-peptide levels at diagnosis were higher in patients entering PR, especially in older patients.

column3: • Age and treatment modalities may influence C-peptide levels.
• Patients with two positive autoantibodies had shorter PR durations.

column2: • PR did not have long-term effects on complications or severe hypoglycemia.

column3: • Short-term effects on metabolic control were observed in patients with longer PR durations.

695,"<summary>

column1: • Patients with BSS have a low risk of malignancy and require long-term follow-up.

column2: • Genetic counseling and molecular diagnosis through the study of the CYLD gene in patients and their relatives are essential.

column1: • Clinical manifestations of BSS include the progressive development of skin tumors in the scalp and face, starting since puberty and more common in females.

column2: • Associated with an increased risk of salivary gland neoplasms and other tumors.

column1: • CYLD gene mutations lead to the loss of deubiquitinating activity, correlating with tumorigenesis.

column2: • Germ-line mutations predispose individuals to BSS, with a second acquired somatic mutation sometimes determining the final phenotype.

696,"<summary>

698,"<summary>

699,"<summary>
* Modern nasal surgery focuses on both cosmetic appearance and improving natural functions of the nose.

700,"<summary>

• Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of mortality in economically developed nations, with ongoing research focusing on preventing early development of risk factors such as atherosclerosis, hypertension, and chronic inflammation.

column2: • N-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (n-3 PUFAs) have been shown to have beneficial effects in observational and experimental studies.

column3: • N-3 PUFAs have lipid-lowering, anti-inflammatory, antithrombotic, and antiarrhythmic effects.

• Plant sources of n-3 fatty acids are not considered a replacement for seafood-derived n-3 PUFAs.
• Studies have shown that n-3 PUFAs, particularly EPA and DHA, can lower the risk of coronary heart disease.
• EPA and DHA have been found to reduce triglyceride levels and improve endothelial function.
• They may also compete with n-6 fatty acids for prostaglandin and leukotriene synthesis, leading to anti-inflammatory effects.
• N-3 PUFAs have been shown to modulate inflammation and endothelial function, potentially reducing the risk of cardiovascular disease.
• Overall, dietary intake of n-3 PUFAs may improve cardio-metabolic health through their antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and antiarrhythmic actions.

* Neonates born to women with severe hypoproteinemia had worse outcomes, including lower birth weight and higher rates of preterm delivery.

column1: * Severe hypoproteinemia was a significant risk factor for cesarean section, poor maternal outcomes, and poor neonatal outcomes in preeclampsia.

column2: * The study highlighted the impact of hypoalbuminemia on maternal and neonatal health in preeclampsia.

709,"<summary>
* Lcn2 mice were generated by gene targeting in embryonic stem cells from mouse strain 129 and backcrossed onto the b6 background for 10 generations.

column2: * Mice were housed in a pathogen-free facility and handled following NIH guidelines.
* Experimental procedures were approved by the University of Minnesota animal care committee.

column1: * Lcn2 mice showed increased body weight, adiposity, and organ weight when fed a high-fat diet.

column2: * They also exhibited larger adipose cells and higher liver, heart, kidney, and spleen weights.

column1: * Lcn2 mice displayed cold sensitivity and could not survive exposure to 4°C for more than 10 hours.

column2: * They had lower body temperature and decreased thermogenic activity in brown adipose tissue.
* Lcn2 mice showed impaired mitochondrial oxidative capacity in BAT and skeletal muscle.

column1: * Lcn2 mice developed systemic insulin resistance, glucose intolerance, and hyperinsulinemia.

column2: * They had elevated levels of fasting serum glucose and insulin, reduced adiponectin levels, and unchanged leptin levels.

column1: * Lcn2 deficiency led to increased expression of proinflammatory cytokines and decreased anti-inflammatory markers in adipose tissue and liver.

column2: * Lcn2 mice demonstrated increased lipid accumulation in the liver, suggesting hepatic insulin resistance.

column1: * Lcn2 mice exhibited reduced expression of genes involved in lipid metabolism and adipokines in adipose tissue.

column2: * They also showed decreased insulin responsiveness in muscle, adipose tissue, and liver.

column1: * Lcn2 may play a critical role in energy metabolism, adaptive thermogenesis, and insulin resistance.

column2: * It could be a potential therapeutic target for obesity-associated type 2 diabetes and metabolic complications.

711,"<summary>
* Nurses are called to be actively engaged in national policy processes due to their pivotal role in healthcare delivery.
* Nurses comprise the majority of the global healthcare workforce and work closely with patients and families.
* Their experiences and insights can guide improvements in health service delivery and inform health systems strengthening.
* Nurses' input on health sector policies can ensure supportive work environments for clinical practice.
* Nurses' limited participation in policy processes is attributed to various factors such as lack of awareness, skills, and opportunities.
* Strategies to enhance nurses' engagement in policy processes include assuming formal leadership positions, lobbying, and advocacy.
* Nurses can engage directly in policy processes by taking on leadership roles in the healthcare system.
* They can also engage indirectly through lobbying and advocacy with policymakers via professional organizations.
* Building nurses' understanding of policy and politics through training programs can enhance their competencies.
* Nurses need to utilize research as credible evidence to inform policy decisions and strengthen their research abilities.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
712,"<summary>
* Urinary tract infections (UTIs) in neonates present with non-specific symptoms and require a sepsis workup followed by antibiotic therapy.

column2: * Neonates with UTIs may exhibit fever, irritability, lethargy, vomiting, abnormal urination, and jaundice.
* UTIs in newborns can lead to urosepsis or neonatal sepsis and are often managed as cases of sepsis.

column1: * Most UTIs in infants are caused by gram-negative bacilli, with E. coli being the most prevalent organism.

column2: * Other enterobacteriaceae causing UTIs in neonates include Klebsiella, Enterobacter, and Citrobacter.
* Gram-positive bacteria like Staphylococcus and Enterococcus are less commonly found in neonatal UTIs.

column1: * A study conducted at Bahrami Children's Hospital in Tehran aimed to determine the frequency of UTI causative organisms in neonates over an eight-year period.

column2: * The study included 73 cases, with E. coli being the most prevalent organism, followed by Enterobacter.
* Resistance to ampicillin was high among E. coli isolates, while Enterobacter showed resistance to amikacin and ampicillin.

column1: * The study highlighted the importance of understanding the susceptibility patterns of causative organisms to choose appropriate empirical antibiotic therapy.

column2: * The authors recommended third-generation cephalosporins plus an aminoglycoside as a better choice for empiric therapy of neonatal UTI.
* Further prospective studies are needed to assess the changing susceptibility patterns of uropathogens in neonatal UTIs.

715,"<summary>
* Heart rate monitors have been widely used in sports and sports science over the last 25 years.

column2: * Development of handy heart rate monitors with chest belts has made heart rate measurement easily accessible.

* Recent technical developments focus on real-time monitoring instead of post-exercise evaluation.

column1: * Four commercially available systems were tested in a field test for comparison.

column2: * Systems allow direct and real-time monitoring of multiple individuals simultaneously.
* Data are transmitted wirelessly to a receiver connected to a laptop with relevant software.
* Main purpose of the study was to compare systems in terms of operating distance and validity against ECG.

column1: * Study involved 12 active participants, including amateur soccer players and a male subject for ECG validation.

column2: * Tests included measurement of failure ratio during a soccer match, distance measurement, and comparison against ECG.
* Polar and Acentas systems scored highest in hardware evaluation, while Activio had the best software concept.
* Acentas system showed the best performance in terms of operating distance, heart rate signal validity, and low failure rate.

column1: * Each system had its strengths and weaknesses, with Acentas scoring the highest overall.

column2: * Polar had a clear design and usable features, while Activio had functional software and detailed instruction manual.
* Suunto experienced a total breakdown during competition measurements, highlighting the importance of system reliability.
* Study findings can be used for further system improvements and do not recommend a single system due to individual preferences and needs.

716,"<summary>
* Stem cells have the ability to make identical copies of themselves and proliferate extensively.

* Cell surface proteins unique to stem cells are used for efficient isolation.

column1: * Stem cells play a role in lung repair and response to injury.

column2: * Stem cell behavior includes self-renewal, proliferation, and multipotency.

column1: * Different populations of stem cells have been identified throughout the lung.

column2: * Proximal airways contain tracheal basal cells capable of pluripotency.

column1: * Lung carcinomas are associated with stem cells from different airway regions.

column2: * Cancer stem cell hypothesis explains tumor growth and heterogeneity.

column1: * Targeted therapies against specific lung cancer stem cell types are being developed.

column2: * Cells expressing CD133 in lung tumors have worse prognosis and resistance to therapy.

column1: * Lung stem cells may play a key role in lung tumorigenesis.

column2: * Cells with stem cell properties are present in many tumors.

column1: * Questions remain about the role of stem cells in lung tumorigenesis.

column2: * Uncertainty about the transformation of healthy adult stem cells into cancer cells.

727,"<summary>
• Human cystic echinococcosis (CE) is caused by Echinococcus granulosus and is a widespread parasitic zoonosis.
• Humans acquire infection through accidental ingestion of E. granulosus eggs from infected dogs.
• CE usually presents with symptoms related to fluid-filled cysts in the liver, lungs, or other organs.
• Postsurgical relapses or treatment failure can occur due to nonradical surgical procedures or spillage of parasite material.
• Serology has been used for postoperative monitoring of CE patients, but the long persistence of antibodies makes diagnosis of relapse challenging.
• New antigens are being sought to classify patients into cured and noncured categories.
• Western blotting has shown promise in diagnosing and monitoring CE patients post-surgery.
• Antigenic bands with molecular weights of 52, 24, 39, 46, 63, and 60-61 kDa have been identified as specific for hydatid disease.

728,"<summary>
• Obesity is a common metabolic disease worldwide, often assessed by parameters like BMI, waist circumference, and waist-to-hip ratio.

column2: • New obesity indices like waist-to-height ratio (WHtR) and visceral adiposity index (VAI) are gaining attention for assessing metabolic complications.

column3: • WHtR may be helpful in predicting cardiovascular events in obese patients.

column2: • New obesity indices like VAI, WHtR, and BAI showed associations with lipid profile.
