735,"<summary>
• Cesarean sections (CS) are necessary for life-saving medical indications to prevent maternal or perinatal complications.

column2: • Appropriate CS rates should be associated with the lowest morbidity and mortality.

column3: • World Health Organization recommends a 10-15% CS rate.
• Many countries have CS rates far exceeding the recommended range.
• Iran has seen a six-fold increase in CS rates over the past three decades.
• The debate between vaginal delivery (VD) and CS continues.
• Postpartum period is critical for women's physical, emotional, and social well-being.
• Socio-economic deficiencies and medical problems can impact postnatal quality of life.
• Mode of delivery can affect long-term health-related quality of life (HRQOL).

column1: • A prospective study in Iran compared postpartum physical and mental HRQOL between VD and CS.

column2: • Physical HRQOL was better in VD women at 2 and 4 months postpartum.

column3: • VD women had higher physical health scores than CS women.
• Mental HRQOL was generally higher in CS women, but not significantly.
• VD group showed more improvement in mental HRQOL from time 1 to time 2 assessments.

column2: • Future studies should include specific questionnaires and consider social and cultural factors affecting postpartum HRQOL.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
736,"<summary>
• Maslow's hierarchy of needs, proposed in 1943, categorizes human needs into a pyramid structure.
• Physiological needs, safety, belongingness and love, esteem, and self-actualization are the levels of needs.
• Physiological needs include food and sex, while safety needs encompass personal security and financial security.
• Safety needs can dominate behavior and block physiological needs.
• Safety needs are more fundamental than physiological needs and can lead to fear and anxiety.
• Fear and anger are reactions to unexpected events that threaten safety.
• The amygdala and NE/LC system are neural structures related to safety needs and fear responses.
• Safety needs are linked to mental disorders like anxiety, phobia, depression, and PTSD.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 8, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
737,"<summary>
* Epoxyeicosatrienoic acids (EETs) play a crucial role in various physiological functions such as blood pressure regulation and anti-inflammatory activity.

column2: * EETs are metabolized from arachidonic acid by cytochromes P450 and their levels are dependent on specific isoforms.

column1: * Inhibiting soluble epoxide hydrolase can increase EET levels, offering a potential therapeutic intervention for EET-mediated processes.

column2: * Various structural modifications have been made to EET analogues to improve stability and activity, with some analogues showing promising vasorelaxant and enzyme inhibitory properties.

column1: * Studies have shown that certain EET analogues have dual activity as vasorelaxants and soluble epoxide hydrolase inhibitors, making them potential candidates for further development.

column2: * The synthesis of EET analogues involves multiple steps, including desilylation, bromination, and cyanide treatment, to produce compounds with improved biological activities.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
738,"<summary>
• The Patient-Centered Medical Home (PCMH) model was developed by several medical associations to improve healthcare in the US.

column2: • It is based on the Chronic Care Model (CCM) and aims to provide quality, coordinated, and cost-effective care.

column1: • Transitioning to a PCMH involves challenges such as promoting physician buy-in, changing office culture, and leveraging electronic medical records.

column2: • Practices must create their own policies adhering to PCMH principles and decide whether to transition incrementally or all at once.

column1: • Care coordination, team-based care, and patient engagement are key components of the PCMH model.

column2: • Practices may struggle with implementing these components due to financial incentives, lack of training, and time-consuming procedures.

column1: • Smaller practices may face difficulties in transforming into a high-functioning PCMH due to resource constraints.

column2: • Shared coordinators and electronic medical records can help smaller practices overcome some of these challenges.

column1: • The ultimate goal of PCMH is to improve patient care quality and reduce healthcare costs through preventative and care management services.

column2: • Practices must continuously strive for improvement and maturation even after achieving NCQA recognition as a PCMH.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '•'}"
739,"<summary>
• Incremental improvements in survivorship from CPR occurred as more people were trained in CPR and portable defibrillators were deployed in more locations.

column2: • More people trained in CPR
• Portable defibrillators deployed in more locations

column1: • In the early 21st century, the survival rate of cardiac arrest outside the hospital was 78%.

column2: • 78% survival rate
• Most patients did not survive or had neurological deficits

column1: • Mild hypothermia therapy has been proposed for brain protection after CPR.

column2: • Proposed therapy for brain protection
• Reduces metabolic rate and expression of pro-apoptosis proteins

column1: • Meta-analysis conducted to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of mild hypothermia on cardiac arrest patients.

column2: • Evaluation of effectiveness and safety
• Inclusion and exclusion criteria for studies

column1: • Extensive literature search conducted using various databases.

column2: • Literature search methods
• Databases searched

column1: • Six randomized controlled trials included in the meta-analysis.

column2: • Inclusion of six trials
• Comparison of therapeutic effects under different conditions

column1: • Hypothermia showed improvement in survival rate and neurological function after 6 months.

column2: • Improvement in survival rate
• Improvement in neurological function

column1: • Mild hypothermia did not influence the incidence of rearrest.

column2: • No influence on rearrest
• No significant difference between treatment and control groups

column1: • Mild hypothermia therapy for cardiac arrest patients is considered safe.

column2: • Safety of therapy
• Main adverse events identified

column1: • Limitations of the study include inadequate number of trials and potential clinical and methodological heterogeneity.

column2: • Inadequate number of trials
• Potential clinical and methodological heterogeneity

740,"<summary>
* Varicocele is a common cause of male infertility, affecting approximately 40% of cases.

column2: * It is characterized by enlargement and elongation of the pampiniform plexus, leading to venous stasis and compromised testicular oxygen concentration.

column1: * Diagnosis involves physical examination, including palpation and ultrasound, with a focus on testicular size and varicocele severity.

column2: * Surgical repair is recommended for varicocele with testicular hypotrophy on the affected side.

column1: * Laparoscopic varicocele repair has shown to increase testicular volume in the majority of cases.

column2: * Hormonal tests and semen analysis post-surgery are essential for evaluating the efficacy of treatment.

column1: * Surgical techniques for varicocele repair include open varicocelectomy, laparoscopic intervention, and sclerotherapy.

column2: * Laparoscopic repair, such as the Bernardi technique, is preferred for adolescents due to its minimally invasive nature.

column1: * Hormonal regulation of the reproductive system plays a crucial role in spermatogenesis and fertility.

column2: * Normal levels of testosterone, LH, and FSH post-surgery indicate successful treatment and improved sperm parameters.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
741,"<summary>
• Radical retropubic prostatectomy is the preferred surgical treatment for localized prostate cancer.

column2: • Studies have shown good tumor control, functional results, and low morbidity with this procedure.

column3: • Major long-term morbidity is erectile dysfunction due to cavernosal nerve injury.
• Nerve-sparing techniques have improved potency rates, but there is variability in outcomes.
• Anatomical studies have shown even distribution of periprostatic nerve fibers, guiding nerve-sparing procedures.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"
742,"<summary>
* Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is an autoimmune disease characterized by chronic inflammation and degradation of cartilage and bone.

column2: * Serum amyloid A (SAA) is an acute-phase protein produced in response to inflammation.

column3: * SAA levels increase dramatically during acute inflammation.
* SAA is also involved in cholesterol metabolism and can contribute to cardiovascular disease.
* Persistently high SAA levels can lead to amyloidosis, a complication of RA.

column1: * SAA levels were found to be high in the majority of RA patients, indicating sustained inflammation.

column2: * SAA levels correlated with disease activity and inflammatory markers.
* Treatment with glucocorticoids was associated with higher SAA levels.
* Biological DMARDs were associated with lower SAA levels in women.

column1: * Elevated SAA levels were also associated with increased risk of atherosclerosis and kidney disease.

column2: * SAA may play a role in joint destruction and cartilage damage in RA.
* SAA levels were higher in patients with atherosclerotic plaques and increased cystatin-C levels.
* SAA levels were inversely associated with QTc duration, indicating a risk of arrhythmias.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
743,"<summary>
* Glucocorticoids are known for their anti-inflammatory and immunosuppressive effects.

column2: * They play a role in promoting inflammation and th2-type immunity.
* Eosinophil production is increased in asthma models.
* Oral tolerance to allergens can affect eosinophils and neutrophils in bone marrow.

column1: * Corticosterone surge induced by allergen challenge increases eosinophilia in bone marrow.

column2: * Blockade of glucocorticoid signaling abolishes the bone marrow response.
* Dexamethasone increases eosinophil production in bone marrow.
* Perforin deficiency leads to a selective defect in granulocyte production.

column1: * Wild-type lymphocytes can correct the granulopoietic response to dexamethasone in pfp mice.

column2: * Depletion of CD4+ or CD8+ cells affects reconstitution of eosinophilic or neutrophilic responses.
* Perforin may play a role in the correction of the granulopoietic response.
* Further studies are needed to understand the mechanisms involved in lymphocyte transfer and granulocyte production.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
744,"<summary>
* 62.4 million Indians have type 2 diabetes mellitus, with fear of hypoglycemia and weight gain being barriers to insulin therapy.

column2: * A multinational study assessed the safety and effectiveness of insulin analogues in routine clinical care for people with type 2 diabetes.

column1: * Insulin analogues such as biphasic insulin aspart, basal + insulin aspart, insulin detemir, and insulin aspart improved glycaemic control and quality of life in patients.

column2: * Hypoglycemic events reduced, blood pressure decreased, and overall lipid profile improved after 24 weeks of treatment.

column1: * Insulin analogues were found to be effective and safe for treating type 2 diabetes in Mumbai, India, with no major hypoglycemic events reported.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
745,"<summary>
* Various cell types have been studied for cardiac regeneration, including embryonic stem cells, mesenchymal stem cells, skeletal myoblasts, and bone marrow-derived progenitor cells.

column2: * Embryonic stem cells can differentiate into cardiovascular lineages and have shown promising results in rodent models.

column1: * Induced pluripotent stem cells can be generated from adult somatic cells and have shown potential for cardiac regeneration.

column2: * They can differentiate into cardiovascular lineages and have been successful in restoring myocardial structure and function in animal models.

column1: * Mesenchymal stem cells can be induced to differentiate into cardiomyocytes but have limitations due to their propensity to differentiate into non-cardiac tissues.

column2: * Clinical trials have shown improved ventricular function after intracoronary infusion of autologous mesenchymal stem cells post-infarction.

column1: * Skeletal myoblasts have shown limited success in clinical trials due to issues with electromechanical coupling with the surrounding myocardium.

column2: * They have not shown significant benefits in large-scale trials and have been associated with more frequent arrhythmias.

column1: * Bone marrow-derived mononuclear cells have shown improvements in left ventricular function and decreased scar size in patients with acute myocardial infarction or chronic ischemic cardiomyopathy.

column2: * Intracoronary infusion of adult bone marrow-derived stem cells has shown positive outcomes in terms of ventricular function and reduction in adverse events.

column1: * Stem cell delivery methods include intravenous injection, intracavitary injection, intracoronary infusion, and intramyocardial injection, with varying levels of success in terms of cell retention.

column2: * Intramyocardial delivery has shown better cell retention than intracoronary delivery in animal studies.

column1: * Strategies to improve stem cell homing to the myocardium include ex vivo and in vivo conditioning of donor cells, as well as genetic modification to overexpress survival factors.

column2: * Hypoxic preconditioning and genetic modification of donor cells to overexpress survival factors have shown improvements in cell recruitment, survival, and differentiation in the infarcted heart.

column1: * Cardiac progenitor cells, such as side population cells and c-kit positive cells, have shown regenerative potential in animal studies and may hold promise for cardiac regeneration in humans.

column2: * Isolated cardiac progenitor cells can differentiate into functional cardiomyocytes and improve ventricular function after transplantation into the injured heart.

column1: * Differentiation of committed cardiac progenitor cells from various cellular resources, such as embryonic stem cells or induced pluripotent",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
746,"<summary>
• Polyhalite microfabrics from hallstatt include:
• Vein-filling, fibrous polyhalite of likely middle to late triassic age
• Polyhalite mylonites of early cretaceous age
• Metamorphic reaction fabrics of a post-early cretaceous age
• Cavity-filling polyhalite of uncertain age

• The polyhalite mylonites contain a wide range of shear fabrics commonly known in mylonitic quartzofeldspathic shear zones within the ductile crust and developed from a more coarse-grained precursor rock

• Metamorphic reaction fabrics (microfabric type b-2) of fine-grained polyhalite seams, which have grown due to the decomposition of bldite (or astrakhanite) [na2mg(so4)2.4h2o] and anhydrite have also been found
• Reaction fabrics may have formed by exsolution, (re-)crystallisation, parallel growth or replacement
• Coarse-grained polyhalite grains or twins in a fine-grained polyhalite matrix (microfabric type a-4) were only observed in samples from hallstatt
• The cataclastic polyhalite microfabric a-5 was also only found in one hallstatt sample (ht-6)
• The metamorphic reaction fabric b-2 was also reported from one polyhalite
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
747,"<summary>
* Oxidative stress is caused by an imbalance between free radicals and antioxidants, leading to systemic diseases.

column2: * Reactive oxygen species (ROS) play a critical role in the development of diseases.

column3: * Inhibition of ROS formation or scavenging can protect against oxidative stress-induced ailments.

column1: * Propofol, a lipid-soluble anesthetic, has antioxidant properties similar to vitamin E.

column2: * Studies have shown propofol's antioxidant effects in vitro and in vivo.

column3: * Propofol has been found to have antiapoptotic effects by acting as an antioxidant.

column1: * In a study on rats, propofol did not significantly affect levels of MDA but increased lipid profile markers.

column2: * Propofol administration led to increased total cholesterol, triglycerides, and LDL-cholesterol levels.

column3: * Propofol also decreased HDL-cholesterol levels in the rats.

column1: * Propofol increased hepatic GSH levels and activities of GST and GPX in a dose-dependent manner.

column2: * The increase in GSH levels enhances the detoxifying and antioxidant capability of the liver.

column3: * Propofol's effects on GST and GPX activities may be due to increased substrate availability or enzyme synthesis.

column1: * Propofol administration in rats led to increased serum LDH and CK-MB activities, indicating potential cardiotoxicity.

column2: * The drug also increased total bilirubin levels but had no significant effects on AST, ALT, creatinine, or urea levels.

column3: * Propofol's antioxidant effects were beneficial, but its impact on lipid profile and cardiac markers should be considered in patients with cardiovascular or lipid disorders.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
748,"<summary>
• Idiopathic hypogonadotropic hypogonadism (IHH) is a rare condition caused by a deficiency of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) release from the hypothalamus.

column2: • Prevalence of IHH is about 1/10,000 in men and 1/50,000 in women, with a male-to-female ratio of 4-5:1.

column1: • A network investigation approach was used to collect data on IHH patients in China, showing improvements in clinical symptoms with hormone replacement therapy.

column2: • Patients in the gonadotropin + androgen therapy group had better outcomes in terms of physical development and testosterone normalization compared to the gonadotropin therapy group.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '•'}"
749,"<summary>
* Nonsurgical endodontic retreatment is the primary choice to reduce microbial content in failed teeth.

column2: * Well-compacted root fillings resist retreatment instruments, leaving residues that hinder disinfection.

column1: * Various instruments are used for retreatment, but complete removal of root fillings is often not achieved.

column2: * Extruded irritants during retreatment can cause postoperative inflammation and impaired healing.

column1: * The study aimed to evaluate debris extrusion after using Protaper Universal RFS and different finishing files.

column2: * The null hypothesis was that the three files would show no significant differences in debris extrusion.

column1: * Standard procedures were followed for canal preparation, irrigation, obturation, and retreatment.

column2: * Protaper Universal RFS was used to remove bulk fillings, followed by supplementary files for residue removal.

column1: * WaveOne file showed the highest debris extrusion, followed by Protaper Next and Self-Adjusting File.

column2: * Saf exhibited the least extrusion among the three experimental groups.

column1: * The study concluded that all retreatment systems caused apical debris extrusion.

column2: * Saf instrumentation resulted in less extrusion compared to Protaper Next and WaveOne.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
750,"<summary>
• The traditional method of anesthetizing maxillary teeth involves multiple injections in the mucobuccal supraperiosteal fold, causing collateral anesthesia of the lip and facial muscles.

column2: • Disadvantages of traditional method:

column3: • Requires multiple injections
• Causes collateral anesthesia
• Inconvenient for patients

column1: • The AMSA nerve block technique offers a single injection for anesthesia of multiple maxillary teeth without affecting the face or causing lip numbness.

column2: • Advantages of AMSA nerve block:

column3: • Single injection
• No collateral anesthesia
• Effective pulpal anesthesia

column1: • The success rates of AMSA nerve block using a conventional syringe ranged from 16.7% to 66.6% with varying induction and duration times.

column2: • Results showed:

column3: • Low success rates
• Gradual decline in anesthesia duration
• No anesthesia of lips or facial muscles

column1: • The AMSA nerve block technique may be beneficial in restorative dentistry and periodontal surgery due to reduced injections and excellent hemostatic control.

column2: • Clinical observations:

column3: • More of an infiltrative technique than a nerve block
• Limited to anterior maxillary teeth

column1: • Comparison with infraorbital nerve block (IONB) showed varying success rates, with AMSA having advantages in terms of facial numbness and palatal anesthesia.

column2: • Comparison results:

column3: • AMSA had lower success rates in central incisors
• IONB had higher success rates in premolars and canines

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"
751,"<summary>
* Malaria is a significant public health issue in South-East Asia, with India contributing 76% of cases.

column2: * India has a high transmission rate in certain areas, with Plasmodium falciparum and Plasmodium vivax being the main causes.
* Lack of medical attention in rural areas contributes to high malaria mortality rates.
* Community knowledge and practices play a crucial role in implementing effective malaria interventions.

column1: * A study in Jammu and Kashmir, India, showed good knowledge and attitudes towards malaria prevention and treatment.

column2: * Majority of participants associated malaria with mosquito bites and knew about symptoms and prevention.
* Most participants considered malaria a serious health problem and were willing to seek medical help promptly.
* Despite good knowledge, there was a lack of awareness about specific malaria treatments due to low literacy levels.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
752,"<summary>
• Recent advances in molecular biology and microscopy have improved our understanding of genome folding.

column2: • Chromatin folding is crucial for gene expression and DNA replication regulation.

column3: • Genome is folded hierarchically into chromosome territories, genomic compartments, and topologically associating domains (TADs).

column4: • TADs are stable structures enriched with specific long-range looping interactions.

column2: • Perturbations in genome folding units are linked to diseases and cancer.

column3: • TAD boundaries are associated with specific proteins and histone modifications.

column4: • Loss of BRG1, a chromatin remodeling enzyme, weakens TAD boundaries.

column1: • BRG1 regulates gene expression related to extracellular matrix and lipid synthesis.

column2: • BRG1 knockdown alters long non-coding RNA expression.

column3: • BRG1 primarily binds to genic regions and super-enhancers.

column4: • BRG1 contributes to nucleosome occupancy and higher-order chromatin organization.

column1: • BRG1 loss affects nucleosome occupancy at CTCF-bound regions.

column2: • BRG1 may impact TAD boundary strength by regulating nucleosome occupancy.

column3: • BRG1 interacts with topoisomerases and CTCF to maintain TAD boundaries.

column4: • BRG1 knockdown leads to increased inter-TAD genomic interactions.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"
753,"<summary>
* Statistical modeling using poisson and negative binomial regressions with zero inflation is used to investigate count data in various research studies.

column2: * Poisson regression is commonly used for count variables such as the number of blood donations or failed courses.

column1: * Factors such as gender, age, motivation, and prior academic performance have been shown to affect academic performance in students.

column2: * Demographic and educational factors play a significant role in determining academic success.

column1: * In a study at Iran University of Medical Sciences, data on failed courses and semesters were analyzed using zero inflated poisson and negative binomial regressions.

column2: * The study found that university average and quota system had an inverse relationship with failed semesters.

column1: * Results showed that an increase in university average and choosing a free quota system can reduce the number of failed semesters.

column2: * The number of failed courses was found to be influenced by factors such as gender, marital status, educational level, and faculty.

column1: * The study highlighted the importance of university average in reducing failed courses and semesters.

column2: * Choosing more bachelor and master students can also help reduce the number of failed courses.

column1: * The research was supported by Iran University of Medical Sciences under grant number 370.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
754,"<summary>
• Electrostatic interactions in enzyme catalysis play a vital role by assisting in ligand binding and stabilizing the transition state.

column2: • These interactions are significantly modulated by conformational changes during the catalytic cycle.

column1: • The enzyme E. coli dihydrofolate reductase (ecDHFR) was studied to probe changes in the active site electrostatic environment.

column2: • The enzyme catalyzes the conversion of 7,8-dihydrofolate (DHF) to 5,6,7,8-tetrahydrofolate (THF).

column1: • Thiocyanate probes were incorporated at specific locations in the active site to analyze changes in the electrostatic environment.

column2: • Experimental data showed changes in the active site electrostatic environment due to structural rearrangements.

column1: • QM/MM analyses of molecular dynamics simulations reproduced experimentally measured vibrational frequency shifts across the catalytic cycle.

column2: • The electric field along the hydride transfer pathway between the substrate and cofactor was examined.

column1: • Residues and ligands in the active site contributed to the electric field along the CN axis and the hydride transfer axis.

column2: • The changing electrostatic environment in the active site of ecDHFR was associated with conformational changes during the catalytic cycle.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '•'}"
755,"<summary>
* Magnetic particle imaging (MPI) is a new imaging method using superparamagnetic iron oxide nanoparticles to visualize spatial distribution with high resolution and signal-to-noise ratios.

column2: * MPI relies on the superparamagnetic nature, nonlinear magnetization curve, and ability to be magnetically saturated of the nanoparticles.
* Possible applications include cardiovascular imaging and guidance of interventions.
* Ideal MPI tracers should have a homogeneously distributed iron core diameter of 30 nm for optimal performance.

column1: * Resovist, a commercial MPI tracer, has a rapid decay in blood signal and is not suitable for long-circulating applications.

column2: * Differences in blood half-life between different sources of Resovist highlight the need for dedicated MPI tracers.
* Research is focused on developing MPI-specific tracers with ideal characteristics for improved imaging performance.
* Standardized physicochemical testing protocols are proposed to facilitate the development and approval of new MPI tracers.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
756,"<summary>
• Intracellular pathogens have evolved to coexist with host defense mechanisms over millions of years.

column2: • In vitro studies of host-pathogen interactions often exclude the inflammatory milieu.

column3: • Major challenge in studying host response in vivo is distinguishing pathogen-specific responses from general inflammatory responses.
• Components of the complement cascade, coagulation pathway, and acute phase response play a role in the host response to infection.

column1: • Transcriptomic response of uninfected cells exposed to inflammation can be used to measure the baseline response to insult.

column2: • Transcriptomic networks specific to infected cells represent pathogen-induced changes.
• Transcriptomic networks in uninfected cells may identify responses beneficial to the host.

column1: • Experimental model of Leishmania infection revealed aberrant expression of the RXRA-centered pathway in infected cells.

column2: • Pharmacological manipulation of RXR activity enhanced leishmanicidal activity in infected cells.
• Study demonstrates the use of cells exposed to inflammation to discover pathogen-regulated transcriptomic pathways in vivo.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 9, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"
757,"<summary>
• The control of appetite involves inputs from physiological and environmental sources.

column2: • Early theoretical approaches focused on signals from glucose metabolism, amino acids, or adipose tissue.

column3: • Glucostatic, aminostatic, and lipostatic hypotheses were proposed.
• Recent models emphasize inputs from adipose tissue, the gastrointestinal tract, and sensory features of food.
• Major signals include leptin, ghrelin, pyy, and insulin.

column2: • Models aim to regulate appetite and body weight through specific molecular signals to the hypothalamus.

column3: • Interest in appetite regulation has increased with the rise of molecular biology.
• A new formulation explains how body composition and energy expenditure regulate hunger and appetite.

column2: • Exercise can impact appetite through changes in heart rate, gut hormone activity, and nutrient absorption.

column3: • Different intensities and durations of exercise can affect appetite control differently.
• Exercise may stimulate hunger but also increase post-prandial satiety signaling.

column2: • Body composition, particularly fat-free mass, plays a significant role in appetite regulation.

column3: • Resting metabolic rate and fat-free mass are correlated with meal size and daily energy intake.
• Leptin acts as a tonic inhibitory signal, while episodic signals from the GI tract suppress eating.

column2: • The interplay between physiological drives, inhibitions, and episodic signals determines eating behavior.

column3: • Energy balance is influenced by body composition, resting metabolic rate, and leptin levels.
• The energy density and palatability of food also impact energy intake and weight regulation.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '•'}"
758,"<summary>
• Polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) is widely used in prosthetic dentistry for denture bases since 1937.

column2: • Advantages of heat-polymerized PMMA include excellent esthetics, low water sorption, repair ability, and simple processing technique.
• Disadvantages of heat-polymerized PMMA include dimensional changes and inaccuracies in fit.

column1: • Chemically activated resins are less commonly used for denture bases than heat-activated resins.

column2: • Chemically activated resins show less polymerization shrinkage and greater dimensional accuracy.

column1: • Injection molding has advantages over compression molding in terms of processing time, cost, and skin sensitivity.

column2: • Injection molding can improve bond strength between denture teeth and denture base resins.

column1: • Surface treatments with monomer or airborne particle abrasion significantly improve bond strengths of denture teeth to denture base resins.

column2: • Treatment of the ridge lap surface of denture teeth is crucial for enhancing bond strength.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '•'}"
759,"<summary>
* The hazard of ultraviolet radiation (UVR) emitted during arc welding is influenced by welding current, shielding gas composition, and type of welding current.

column2: * Hazard increases with higher welding currents.
* Hazard is greater when using 80% ar + 20% co2 as a shielding gas compared to 100% co2.
* Pulsed welding currents are more hazardous than non-pulsed welding currents.

column1: * The hazard of UVR also depends on the metal transfer mode during welding.

column2: * Spray transfer mode results in the highest hazard.
* Hazard is influenced by the amount of metal vapor in the arc.
* Effective irradiance is strongly influenced by pulsed current, with hazard increasing with decreasing pulsed current.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
760,"<summary>
• A wide variety of taxonomically different groups of microorganisms are known to produce intracellular energy and carbon storage compounds called polyhydroxyalkanoates (PHAs).

column2: • Bacterial cells with a higher content of PHAs can survive longer and more efficiently in extreme environments or when nutrient availability is poor.

column1: • PHAs are synthesized by many bacteria and archaea when carbon is available but other essential nutrients are not.

column2: • PHAs are commonly divided into short-chain-length (SCL-PHAs) and medium-chain-length (MCL-PHAs) based on the number of constituent carbon atoms in their monomer units.

column1: • The enzyme PHA synthase plays a main role in PHA synthesis, regardless of the type of PHAs synthesized.

column2: • Extremophiles in polar areas are a potential source of novel enzymes with industrial applications, including PHA production.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '•'}"
761,"<summary>

* Reclaiming arid and semi-arid lands involves modifying topography, creating suitable surface composition, and establishing vegetation, with the most uncertainty surrounding vegetation establishment.

column2: * Vegetation establishment is important for reducing erosion, improving public perception, allowing for productive land reuse, and reintegrating disturbed lands into the landscape.

column3: * Reliance on unpredictable rainfall for germination and establishment is a primary source of uncertainty.
* Native vegetation is now recommended over non-natives due to long-term stability, resource value, and better public acceptance.
* A mixed plant community with the same functional groups as a natural community is needed for long-term positive impact.

column1: * Modeling using historical rainfall data in southern Arizona showed potential for seeding success in warm-season grasses, with factors like root elongation rate and soil moisture influencing survival.

column2: * Germination periods, root growth, and other sources of mortality after germination are critical factors for successful establishment.

* Funds for reseeding should be available for at least a second year to account for potential reclamation failures, and a diverse mix of species may reduce the risk of seeding failure in years with poor rainfall distribution.

762,"<summary>
* Major depression is a leading cause of disability and burden of disease globally, with up to 40% of patients not responding to initial antidepressant therapies.

column2: * By 2020, major depression is projected to rank second in disability-adjusted life years.

column1: * Treatment-resistant depression (TRD) is defined as a poor response to two adequate trials of different classes of antidepressants.

column2: * Staging methods help categorize TRD patients for better intervention planning.

column1: * Neuromodulation therapies (NTs) are gaining interest for TRD management due to their targeted brain circuit approach and limited side effects.

column2: * NTs include seizure therapies, noninvasive therapies, neurosurgical approaches, and emerging approaches like focused ultrasound and optogenetic stimulation.

column1: * Research on NTs like repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) and vagus nerve stimulation (VNS) show promising results in TRD patients.

column2: * Studies on deep brain stimulation (DBS) and magnetic seizure therapy (MST) also report antidepressant effects with minimal cognitive side effects.

column1: * Further research is needed to establish the efficacy, safety, and cost-effectiveness of NTs in larger TRD populations.

column2: * Collaboration, larger sample sizes, standardized protocols, and comparative studies are recommended to advance the understanding and utilization of NTs in TRD.

763,"<summary>
* Small RNA molecules play a critical role in regulating gene expression levels in a targeted manner through RNA interference (RNAi).

column2: * RNAi involves double-stranded short interfering RNAs (siRNAs) that can downregulate expression levels via the RNA-induced silencing complex.

column1: * RNAi can also modulate gene transcription itself, as seen in various organisms including fission yeast, plants, and mammals.

column2: * Short-activating RNAs (saRNAs) have been developed to upregulate specific cellular genes, including those involved in stem cell regulation and reprogramming.

column1: * SaRNAs targeting key reprogramming genes, such as KLF4 and c-Myc, have been shown to efficiently upregulate gene expression in human mesenchymal stem cells.

column2: * The upregulation of KLF4 and c-Myc by saRNAs was found to be time- and dose-dependent, leading to increased mRNA and protein levels.

column1: * SaRNA-mediated upregulation of endogenous genes did not activate interferon response pathways and showed specific activation of transcription.

column2: * Microarray analysis revealed that saRNA treatment resulted in differential gene expression profiles compared to lentiviral transduction, with similarities in pathways related to stem cell maintenance and cell cycle regulation.

764,"<summary>
• Chronic kidney diseases lead to end-stage kidney failure and are associated with changes in kidney structure and fibrosis.

column2: • Urinary tract obstruction is characterized by tubular atrophy or dilation, tubular cell death, interstitial leukocyte infiltration, and increased interstitial matrix deposition.

column3: • Obstruction can be caused by various factors such as benign prostatic hyperplasia, calculi, strictures, or neoplasms.
• Hydrostatic pressure resulting from the blockage initiates renal injuries, leading to tubular dilatation, inflammatory infiltration, fibroblast activation, and interstitial fibrosis.

column2: • Taurine and paclitaxel have been shown to have beneficial effects on renal fibrosis in different kidney diseases.

column3: • Taurine plays a role in ion reabsorption, renal blood flow, and antioxidant properties in the kidney.
• Paclitaxel stabilizes microtubules and has been reported to ameliorate fibrosis in kidney and liver models.

765,"<summary>
* Pathogen recognition receptors (PRRs) trigger innate immune responses by sensing microbial components such as lipopolysaccharide (LPS), lipoprotein, flagellin, and nucleic acids.
* PRRs drive the activation of transcription factors, leading to the expression of inflammatory cytokines, chemokines, and antimicrobial genes.
* Aberrant activation of innate immune responses can lead to inflammatory diseases like autoimmune disease and septic shock.
* Protein degradation, including autophagy, plays a critical role in regulating innate immune responses.
* Autophagy is essential for survival during neonatal starvation and is involved in cellular homeostasis, cell death/survival, and lipid metabolism.
* Autophagy is also crucial for host defense responses by promoting the elimination of pathogens and antigen presentation to T cells.
* ATGs are essential components of the autophagic machinery and are highly conserved between yeast and mammals.
* ATGs mediate membrane trafficking required for autophagosome formation and are involved in the clearance of infectious agents.
* Recent studies have identified the involvement of ATGs in the maturation of phagosomes after exposure to microbial components.
* Loss of ATG16L1 enhances inflammatory immune responses, leading to intestinal inflammation and susceptibility to inflammatory bowel disease.
* Macrophages lacking ATG16L1 produce high amounts of IL-1 and IL-18 in response to LPS, indicating the importance of ATG in regulating the inflammatory response.
* ATG16L1 is essential for autophagy under both nutrient-rich and nutrient-starved conditions and plays a critical role in host defense against microbial infection.
* ATGs are involved in the regulation of innate immune responses triggered by engagement of PRRs with microbial components.
* Stimulation of NOD1 and NOD2 induces the formation of autophagosomes, promoting antigen presentation and bactericidal responses.
* ATGs such as ATG5, ATG7, and ATG16L1 are required for the induction of autophagy in response to microbial components and play a key role in host defense against infections.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
766,"<summary>
* Betel quid chewing in India has evolved from a culturally accepted practice to a significant public health problem.

column2: * Introduction of tobacco by European settlers four centuries ago led to the combination of tobacco with betel quid.
* Tobacco in the quid was identified as the major culprit for oral cancer, not betel nut.

column1: * The incidence of oral cancer and oral submucous fibrosis has increased in India due to the widespread use of gutkha and pan masala.

column2: * Gutkha and pan masala are more dangerous than betel nut alone due to prolonged exposure in the mouth.
* Lack of statutory warnings, low cost, easy availability, and aggressive marketing contribute to their popularity.

column1: * Betel nut chewing is associated with various health issues, including addiction withdrawal symptoms, psychosis, and systemic diseases.

column2: * Betel nut is classified as a Group 1 human carcinogen, with evidence linking it to oral, pharyngeal, and other cancers.
* Animal studies have shown a strong dose-response relationship between betel nut chewing and cancer development.

column1: * India is a major producer and consumer of betel nut, with millions depending on the industry for livelihood.

column2: * Health education and a ban on gutkha and pan masala are necessary to address the health risks associated with betel nut chewing.
* Emphasis should be placed on reducing and eliminating the use of betel nut and tobacco products through public awareness campaigns.

767,"<summary>
* Patient blood management is gaining attention due to the risks associated with allogeneic red blood cell transfusions.

column2: * Reports emphasize the need for reducing transfusions to avoid increased morbidity and mortality.
* Studies show that transfusions are common in cardiac surgery, but guidelines recommend individualized transfusion triggers based on oxygenation needs.

column1: * In cardiac surgery, patients with advanced age and long cardiopulmonary bypass are at higher risk of postoperative bleeding.

column2: * Excessive bleeding can be caused by surgical factors and impaired haemostasis.
* Studies have shown varying outcomes regarding the impact of blood transfusions on mortality in cardiac surgery patients.

column1: * Strategies for patient blood management include developing local policies, evaluating costs, and individualizing transfusion triggers.

column2: * Preoperative evaluation should include defining acceptable blood loss and evaluating cardiovascular reserve.
* Perioperative assessment should focus on monitoring haematocrit levels and evaluating the need for transfusion based on absolute haemoglobin content.

768,"<summary>
* Neurogenesis occurs in the olfactory epithelium throughout adult life

column2: * Recent research has shown that neurogenesis occurs in specific tissues like the hippocampus, dentate gyrus, subventricular zone, and olfactory epithelium

column3: * Neuronal regeneration can occur even after birth in mammals
* Olfactory epithelium shows substantial recovery and regeneration after injury
* Various types of stem cells have been studied for neural regeneration, with olfactory epithelial stem cells showing promise

column1: * Globose basal cells (GBCs) in the olfactory epithelium have been identified as neural progenitor cells

column2: * GBCs have been isolated and characterized as definitive multipotent stem cells

column3: * GBCs have been shown to give rise to neurons and non-neuronal cells
* GBCs express neural progenitor cell markers and lack voltage-gated ion channels

column1: * Isolation and characterization of GBCs from the olfactory epithelium have been standardized

column2: * GBCs have been isolated in a pure form using fluorescence-assisted cell sorting (FACS)

column3: * GBCs have been shown to form multiple generations of neurospheres in culture
* GBCs express markers like NCAM, nestin, and SOX-2, confirming their neural progenitor cell nature

column1: * Future research directions include using magnetic-assisted cell sorting (MACS) for GBC isolation

column2: * Electrophysiological studies on GBCs to understand their functional properties and drug interactions

column3: * Animal studies using GBCs for repairing spinal cord injuries and other nervous system disorders

769,"<summary>
* The central nervous system (CNS) is no longer considered immune-privileged, with microglia playing a key role in innate immunity.

column2: * Microglia facilitate immune surveillance of brain interstitial fluid (ISF) through the glymphatic system.
* CNS immune system is more active than previously thought, with microglia derived from erythromyeloid progenitors in the yolk sac.

column1: * Microglia in the postnatal brain have multiple functions, including immune surveillance and synaptic refinement.

column2: * Microglia phagocytose pathogens and apoptotic neurons, recognize apoptotic cells, and secrete TNF for neuroprotection.
* Microglia play a role in angiogenesis by synthesizing VEGF and are maintained through cellular division.

column1: * Cortical spreading depression (CSD) is a slow wave of depolarization in neurons, contributing to brain injury in conditions like stroke.

column2: * CSD can be induced by various stimuli and leads to changes in cerebral blood flow and neuronal activity.
* Microglia express ion channels sensitive to CSD and are activated by it, contributing to inflammation and synaptic repair.

column1: * Multiple CSD episodes lead to microglial activation through HMGB1 release from neurons and subsequent TLR2/4 signaling.

column2: * Activated microglia may engage in synaptic repair and dendritic spine remodeling after multiple CSD events.

column1: * The involvement of microglia in CSD initiation and progression, as well as their potential systemic effects, require further investigation.

column2: * Understanding the molecular mechanisms of microglial activation and their role in synaptic pruning is crucial for addressing CSD pathophysiology.
* Exploring the interaction between activated microglia and the CSF/lymphatic system may provide insights into conditions like familial hemiplegic migraine.

770,"<summary>
* Transposable elements (TEs) were once considered junk DNA but are now recognized for their role in genetic innovation and organismal evolution.
* TEs can be molecularly domesticated to form new cellular protein-coding genes.
* TE-derived genes have important functions in various biological processes in vertebrates.
* The formation of TE-derived genes, such as GIN1 and GIN2, through molecular domestication events has played a significant role in vertebrate evolution.
* GIN2, in particular, shows expression in brain and gonads in fish and may have a role during gastrulation.
* Future genome comparisons and functional gene analyses are expected to reveal more domesticated genes and their essential biological functions in vertebrates and other organisms.
* Molecular domestication of TEs has been a driver of genetic innovation during evolution.
* The identification of TE-derived genes specific to different vertebrate sublineages will contribute to understanding diversification within vertebrates.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
771,"<summary>
• Progressive diseases affecting increasing number of people

• Role of molecular chaperones in maintaining normal cellular proteostasis
• Opposing protein misfolding, unfolding, and aggregation
• Activation of heat shock response under cellular stress

• Evidence of spreading through interconnected regions in the central nervous system
• Recruitment of soluble proteins leading to amplification and propagation

• Small molecules interfering with aggregation, proteostasis, and inflammation
• Strategies enhancing cell stress pathways and chaperone activity
• Potential use of neurotrophic factors, immunotherapy, and stem cell treatments
• Challenges in developing specific strategies for interfering with protein assemblies propagation
• Key step in the process is the docking of protein assemblies to the cell
• Potential approaches involving molecular chaperones and antibodies
• Identification of binding interfaces for designing therapeutic molecules

772,"<summary>
• Hepatitis C virus (HCV) affects approximately 3.2 million people in the US, with African Americans (AA) being twice as likely to be infected compared to non-Hispanic Caucasians.

column2: • Response rates to interferon (IFN) based therapies are historically lower in AA patients.

• AA patients who achieved SVR showed improved liver outcomes and reversal of fibrosis.
• Fibrosis, rather than cirrhosis, at the first visit was a significant risk factor for developing HCC in AA patients.

773,"<summary>
• Stroke is a leading cause of death globally, with a high percentage of deaths occurring in low and middle income nations.

column2: • Genetic influences play a role in the pathogenesis of ischemic stroke, likely through polygenic mechanisms.

column1: • Beta adrenergic receptors, part of the GPCR family, are involved in stroke and are affected by various mechanisms leading to receptor activity loss.

column2: • Cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) is implicated in atherogenesis and may be a target for atherosclerosis prevention and treatment.

column1: • Meta-analysis was conducted to assess the association between 2AR polymorphisms and ischemic stroke risk.

column2: • Studies included in the analysis showed no significant association between the Arg16Gly polymorphism and ischemic stroke risk.
• However, a significant association was found between the Gln27Glu polymorphism and ischemic stroke risk.

column1: • Limitations of the study include lack of haplotype analysis, gene-environment interactions, and adjustment for confounding factors.

column2: • Selection bias in control subjects, ethnic population differences, and deviation from HWE equilibrium may have impacted the results.

column1: • The study suggests carriers of the Gln27Glu polymorphism of 2AR have an increased risk of ischemic stroke, but larger prospective cohort studies are needed for validation.

column2: • Understanding the molecular pathways underlying susceptibility to ischemic stroke is crucial for future research.

774,"<summary>
* Methadone is frequently used in therapies for opioid addiction and pain syndromes.

column2: * Chronic exposure to methadone can negatively impact cognitive abilities.
* Changes in cytosolic calcium levels are involved in cellular processes and can lead to cell death.

column1: * Methadone can induce rises in cytosolic calcium levels in neuronal cells.

column2: * Methadone-induced calcium deregulation may involve mitochondrial dysfunction.
* Mitochondrial inhibitors can modulate methadone-induced calcium deregulation.

column1: * Methadone can alter mitochondrial morphology and impair calcium uptake.

column2: * Methadone-induced mitochondrial damage may contribute to cell death.
* Imbalance in mitochondrial calcium homeostasis could be linked to cognitive impairment.

775,"<summary>
* Risk-reducing salpingo-oophorectomy (RRSO) is a cancer prevention strategy for women with BRCA1/2 mutations.

column2: * RRSO is associated with substantial reductions in the risks of breast, ovarian, and fallopian tube cancers in BRCA1/2 mutation carriers.
* Data on the effects of birth cohort, timing of surgery, and other factors influencing risk reduction estimates are lacking.
* A meta-analysis of 10 published reports showed significant risk reductions in breast and ovarian cancer with RRSO.

column1: * Studies included case-control, prospective, and retrospective cohort studies.

column2: * Limitations include variable study designs, small sample sizes, and short follow-up times.
* RRSO was associated with an 80% reduction in ovarian/fallopian tube cancer risk and a 50% reduction in breast cancer risk.
* The findings support the utility of RRSO in reducing cancer risks in BRCA1/2 mutation carriers.

column1: * Questions remain regarding the optimal age for RRSO and the differences in risk reduction between BRCA1 and BRCA2 mutation carriers.

column2: * Hormonal modulation by RRSO may have a greater impact on breast cancer risk in BRCA2 mutation carriers.
* Studies suggest potential benefits of hormone replacement therapy post-RRSO for cardiovascular and bone health.
* Additional research is needed to understand the long-term effects of RRSO and hormone replacement therapy in BRCA1/2 mutation carriers.

776,"<summary>
* Oral lichen planus (OLP) is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the oral mucosa, with a prevalence of about 1-2% of the population.

column2: * Lesions rarely undergo self-remission and can have malignant potential.
* Histologically, OLP is characterized by lymphocytic infiltration, increased intraepithelial lymphocytes, and degeneration of basal keratinocytes.

column1: * The etiology of OLP is unclear, but immune dysregulation, especially involving a T-cell-mediated immune response, plays a role.

column2: * Proinflammatory molecules are aberrantly synthesized and secreted in OLP lesions.
* The IL-23/IL-17 axis, involving cytokines IL-23 and IL-17, is implicated in chronic inflammation in various diseases.

column1: * IL-23 and IL-17 are overexpressed in OLP lesions, with a potential regulatory role of IL-23 in IL-17 production.

column2: * IL-23 induces TH17 cells to produce IL-17, contributing to inflammation.
* IL-17 affects oral keratinocytes, selectively regulating the expression of inflammatory mediators.

column1: * Understanding the IL-23/IL-17 axis in OLP may lead to novel therapeutic strategies.

column2: * Blocking IL-23 or IL-17 could be a potential treatment approach for OLP.
* Further research is needed to explore the mechanisms and interactions of the IL-23/IL-17 axis in OLP pathogenesis.

777,"<summary>
* Cell separation is essential for clinical and research purposes.

column2: * Techniques based on size, density, and affinity are commonly used.

column1: * Microfluidic devices offer advantages such as small sample volumes and high portability.

column2: * Size-based approaches do not require specific markers for cell separation.

column1: * Electrophoretic separation processes, such as dielectrophoresis, can trap and sort cells based on their response to stimuli.

column2: * Microfabricated systems can achieve high purity and throughput levels.

column1: * Adhesion-based separation systems, like cell affinity chromatography, can separate cell populations based on surface antigens.

column2: * Microfluidic devices can provide high surface areas per unit volume for efficient separation.

column1: * Magnetic separation techniques, such as magnetophoresis, can be miniaturized for small sample volumes.

column2: * Microscale magnetic separation systems offer advantages in terms of cost and efficiency.

column1: * Lysis-based separation methods can selectively lyse undesired cell populations while leaving behind desired cells.

column2: * Microfluidic devices can reduce the time required for cell lysis and avoid damage to cells.

778,"<summary>

column2: * Morphological signs on imaging exams, such as the caudate-to-right lobe ratio and the right posterior notch, can help diagnose cirrhosis.
* The expanded gallbladder fossa is another sign of cirrhosis, but has lower sensitivity compared to other signs.

column1: * Different imaging signs have varying diagnostic performance in diagnosing cirrhosis, with the caudate-to-right lobe ratio and the right posterior notch showing similar diagnostic accuracy.

column2: * The expanded gallbladder fossa has lower sensitivity but high specificity for diagnosing cirrhosis.

779,"<summary>
• The study evaluated optic nerve structure and visual function in glaucoma patients over a 2-year follow-up period.

780,"<summary>
* New technologies and innovations are seen as a solution to challenges in the healthcare industry.

column2: * Research institutions are facing funding cuts, leading to fewer grants and discoveries.
* Efficiency in translating research into products is crucial for improving healthcare.
* Technology has the power to drive performance improvements and cost reductions.

column1: * Successful innovation in healthcare requires navigating a challenging journey from research to commercialization.

column2: * The ""valley of death"" between research and commercialization is a key obstacle.
* Technologies without a clear commercialization pathway often fail to attract investors.
* Academic investigators may lack the skills and motivation to address commercial issues.

column2: * HCPs balance advancing projects with building team skills.

column1: * HCPs should address healthcare-specific challenges like buying dynamics, reimbursement complexity, and regulatory pathways.

column2: * Content in HCPs should cover healthcare-specific challenges in addition to traditional entrepreneurial topics.

781,"<summary>
• Bladder cancer is strongly linked to smoking, with 85% of cases limited to the urinary bladder at diagnosis.

column2: • Carcinogenic factors include aromatic amines found in tobacco smoke.
• Passive smoking is a common social phenomenon, with high rates in Poland.

column1: • Cotinine levels in urine can objectively assess smoking history and exposure, aiding in smoking cessation recommendations.

column2: • Cotinine analysis through HPLC/DAD provides a reliable method for assessing smoking habits.
• Monitoring cotinine levels can help convey the risks of tobacco smoking and encourage patients to quit.

782,"<summary>
* Anal incontinence is a common issue among women, with various risk factors such as obstetric anal sphincter injury (OASIS), age, obesity, and medical conditions.

column2: * OASIS is a major cause of anal incontinence in nonpregnant women, with a higher prevalence in women with multiple vaginal deliveries.
* Age, obesity, and certain medical conditions increase the risk of anal incontinence.

column1: * Prevalence of anal incontinence varies among different study populations, with higher rates in women attending gynecological clinics and nursing homes.

column2: * Community-based studies show an increase in prevalence with age.
* Postpartum studies indicate a high prevalence of anal incontinence in women who have experienced OASIS.

column1: * A study on pregnant women in their second trimester found a prevalence of anal incontinence of 8.4%.

column2: * Most women reported complete anal continence, while some experienced fecal incontinence or urgency.
* Urinary incontinence was significantly associated with anal incontinence in all parity groups.

column1: * Risk factors for anal incontinence in nulliparous women included low educational level and certain medical conditions.

column2: * Previous OASIS was the strongest risk factor for anal incontinence in parous women.
* Women with previous cesarean deliveries had the lowest prevalence of anal incontinence.

column1: * The study population consisted of unselected pregnant women from all parity groups, providing valuable insights into the risk factors for anal incontinence during pregnancy.

column2: * The study highlighted the importance of preventing OASIS to reduce the incidence of bothersome anal incontinence in fertile women.

783,"<summary>
* The incidence of hypotension in non-obstetric patients ranges from 5% to 66%, with higher rates in hypertensive patients.

column2: * Intraoperative hypotension is associated with myocardial ischemia and increased stroke risk.

column1: * A study aimed to compare normotensive and hypertensive patients under spinal anesthesia with hyperbaric bupivacaine.

column2: * Hypertensive patients had higher blood pressure values but similar rates of hypotension compared to normotensive patients.

column1: * Antihypertensive medications were given to hypertensive patients on the morning of surgery.

784,"<summary>
* Chronic pain and depression are common health problems in primary care patients.
* Pain is associated with limitations in daily activities and increased prevalence of depressive disorders.
* Studies show that pain is often comorbid with depression, but healthcare providers may underestimate the intensity of pain in patients with depression.
* Optimizing antidepressant therapy and pain self-management can improve both depression and pain.
* Dolotest is a validated tool for assessing pain and health-related quality of life, and it can be used as a screening tool for depression in primary care.
* The study population included 715 patients visiting a primary care clinic in Denmark.
* Dolotest profiles and scores were used to assess the impact of pain on patients' quality of life and screen for depression.
* A cut-off value of 65 on the ""low spirits"" domain of Dolotest showed high sensitivity and specificity for detecting depression.
* Coexistence of pain and depression is associated with reduced function, work capacity, and increased healthcare costs.
* Screening for the cooccurrence of pain and depression is important in primary care settings.
* Treating both pain and depression when they coexist is crucial for optimal treatment outcomes.
* Dolotest proved to be an easy-to-use screening tool for pain and depression in clinical settings.
* Patients meeting criteria for depression had higher pain scores and reduced quality of life.
* Identifying patients with the coexistence of pain and depression allows for individualized treatment to improve health-related quality of life.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 4, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
785,"<summary>
• Human papillomavirus (HPV) is a non-enveloped DNA virus belonging to the family Papillomaviridae, with over 130 genotypes that can infect mucosal areas and lead to cancer.

column2: • High-risk HPV serotypes can cause cervical cancer, while low-risk serotypes can lead to benign tissue changes and genital warts.

column1: • Genital HPV infection is common in sexually active individuals, with a global prevalence of 11.7%.

column2: • Prevalence rates vary by region, with higher rates in Africa, including Nigeria.

column1: • Persistent high-risk HPV infections can lead to precancerous lesions and cervical cancer.

column2: • Factors associated with HPV infection include sexual behavior, smoking, and educational status.

column1: • A study in Nigeria found a seroprevalence of 42.9% among women of reproductive age, with higher rates in older women and those with certain reproductive characteristics.

column2: • Recommendations include introducing HPV vaccines in national immunization schedules and improving knowledge and screening programs for cervical cancer prevention.

786,"<summary>

column2: • Medical professionals face challenges in transferring research knowledge to clinical practice.

column1: • Evidence-based medicine aims to integrate the best available evidence with clinical experience and patient preferences.

column2: • It helps in identifying effective and efficient care methods while eliminating ineffective treatments.

column2: • Evidence-based healthcare systems ensure the generation, storage, and use of the best evidence for effective and safe services.

column1: • National health care systems play a crucial role in providing quality healthcare and promoting community health.

column2: • Stewardship is essential in determining rules and strategies for the health system and ensuring accountability.

column1: • Evidence-based practice systems in leading countries focus on clinical knowledge management, evidence-based practice, and clinical effectiveness.

column2: • These systems aim to provide the best evidence for decision-making and promote evidence-based care among providers.

column1: • Strategies and interventions at both individual and organizational levels are needed to promote evidence-based practice and ensure the production and application of clinical knowledge.

column2: • Collaboration among stakeholders and the adoption of policies are essential for successful implementation.

787,"<summary>
• Human metapneumovirus (HMPV) is a negative single-stranded RNA virus closely related to avian metapneumovirus (AMPV) and is a major concern in child respiratory tract viral infections.

column2: • HMPV genome is approximately 13 kb in length with a gene composition similar to human respiratory syncytial virus (HRSV).
• HMPV shows a great synonymous codon usage bias, with preferred codons ending in A/U nucleotides, influenced by nucleotide composition and mutation pressure.
• Nucleotide composition bias is the main force shaping codon usage patterns in HMPV genomes.
• Mutation pressure is the primary determinant of codon usage bias in HMPV, with phylogenetic differences and host factors also playing a role in shaping codon usage bias.

column1: * Functional roles are assigned based on global (homology similarity) and local (domain and motif) sequence similarities.

column2: * Multiple query sequences can be uploaded in fasta format for analysis.

column1: * Protsweep classifies proteins into categories such as identical, homolog, similar, weakly similar, and putative proteins based on blast hits and annotation.

column2: * Domainsweep identifies domain architecture within a protein sequence using different database search methods for protein/domain family databases.
* 2dsweep identifies structural domains in proteins and aids in finding structural elements, including secondary structure predictions, transmembrane regions, and more.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
789,"<summary>
* Patients with delirium had higher phe/tyr ratios, lower trp/lnaas ratios, and lower levels of arginine and citrulline compared to patients without delirium.

column2: * This suggests decreased bh4 availability, disturbed serotonergic neurotransmission, and increased oxidative stress may play a role in delirium pathogenesis.

column1: * Further research is needed to confirm these findings in a larger population and explore differences in delirium pathophysiology in patients with and without cognitive disorders.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
790,"<summary>
* Overweight and obesity prevalence rates are increasing worldwide, with high rates found among ethnic minorities and low socioeconomic status groups.

column2: * Health risks associated with overweight and obesity include cancer, cardiovascular diseases, and mobility problems.

column1: * The WHO recommends adults aged 18-64 to engage in at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic physical activities per week.

column2: * Active transport, such as walking or cycling, can help achieve sufficient levels of physical activity.

column1: * Age and overweight were inversely correlated with physical activity, while male gender and white ethnic origin were positively correlated with being active.

column2: * Studies have shown positive relations between physical activity and neighbourhood walkability, especially among high socioeconomic status populations.

column1: * Inhabitants of Dutch deprived neighbourhoods have higher rates of overweight and lower levels of physical activity compared to the average population.

column2: * More insight into personal and neighbourhood factors associated with active transport is needed for effective interventions targeting ethnic minorities.

column1: * The Urban40 study evaluated the health impact of area-based interventions in the 40 most deprived neighbourhoods in the Netherlands.

column2: * Participants were recruited through home visits and questionnaires, resulting in a final sample of 622 adults.

column1: * Active transport was defined as minutes per week spent on walking or cycling from point A to point B.

column2: * Neighbourhood walkability and personal characteristics such as age, sex, ethnicity, and BMI were assessed for their associations with active transport.

column1: * Migrants and women were found to be more responsive to neighbourhood walkability than Dutch respondents.

column2: * Personal characteristics were stronger associates of active transport than neighbourhood characteristics, with some interactions showing differential effects within subgroups.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
791,"<summary>
* Optic neuritis related to MS is an acute optic neuropathy occurring in young people, especially women.

column2: * Clinical picture includes decline in visual acuity, eye pain, contrast sensitivity decline, dyschromatopsia, and visual field changes.
* Incidence is 1-5 per 100,000 annually, more common in women aged 18-30.
* Study aimed to determine optic neuritis onset as first MS presentation and analyze morphometric changes in optic nerve and visual field.

column1: * Study conducted at Sarajevo University Clinical Centre from 2009-2011.

column2: * MS verification based on clinically defined criteria.
* Optic neuritis was first clinical manifestation of MS in 70% of female patients.
* Pulse corticosteroid therapy showed significant improvement in visual acuity.

column1: * Visual field disturbances analyzed after 7 and 15 days, then 1, 3, 6, and 12 months.

column2: * Centrocecal scotoma most common disturbance.
* OCT results showed thinning of nerve fibers, especially in upper quadrant.
* VA improved from 0.1-0.3 to 0.6-1.0 after corticosteroid therapy.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '*'}"
792,"<summary>
* Diabetes knowledge among the Karen ethnic rural community is low

column2: * Only one-third of the population had knowledge about diabetes risk factors
* Women had lower knowledge levels compared to men

column1: * Lack of diabetes knowledge can lead to missed or late diagnosis and higher incidence of complications

column2: * Language barriers and cultural differences may contribute to poor health education
* Health education interventions are urgently needed to prevent a diabetes epidemic in this population

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 3, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '*'}"
793,"<summary>
• Individuals with serious mental illness (SMI) have higher rates of morbidity and mortality compared to the general population, with diabetes impacting approximately 25% of those with SMI.

column2: • Factors contributing to the increased prevalence of diabetes in this population include lower utilization of preventive care and use of newer antipsychotic medications.
• The Affordable Care Act (ACA) has promoted new avenues of health care delivery, such as health home programs, to reduce barriers to care for those with chronic conditions.

column1: • A behavioral health home (BHH) program was implemented to provide population-based care for individuals with SMI, focusing on identifying abnormal hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) levels and providing individualized interventions.

column2: • The BHH program was embedded in a division of community psychiatry and targeted individuals with SMI enrolled in intensive mental health services.
• The BHH program identified gaps in care, improved somatic care quality, and led to the diagnosis and management of diabetes and prediabetes in the population.

column1: • Preliminary data from the BHH program showed improvements in HbA1c levels for some patients with type 2 diabetes, as well as the identification of individuals not compliant with recommended guidelines for diabetes monitoring.

column2: • The program also revealed the need for patient-centered primary care within mental health settings to address the high rates of mortality and morbidity in individuals with SMI.
• Future research is needed to further evaluate the effectiveness of BHH services, including examining patient satisfaction and conducting meaningful statistical tests with control groups.
