794,"<summary>
• Unemployment, little work experience, low income, and temporary employment deter union formation in Europe.

column2: • Income effects are strong and significant, supporting the male breadwinner hypothesis.
• Employment effects run partly via income, suggesting non-financial elements also influence union formation.

column1: • Cohabitation is more sensitive to economic insecurity than marriage in Europe.

column2: • Men not employed or with temporary jobs are more likely to choose cohabitation over marriage.
• Income has a weaker effect on the choice between marriage and cohabitation.

column1: • Income is less important for marriage after cohabitation than for initial union entry.

column2: • Men in good health are more likely to transition from cohabitation to marriage.
• Higher educated cohabiting men are more likely to marry, indicating cohabitation is less of a long-term option for them.

column1: • Men's economic position is more influential in traditional societies than in more egalitarian ones in Europe.

column2: • Employment and school enrollment effects are stronger in traditional societies.
• Income effects are weaker in egalitarian societies, suggesting costs of setting up a household are more often shared.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '•'}"
795,"<summary>
* Osteoporosis is a condition of impaired bone strength leading to increased fracture risk.

column2: * Bone quality depends on macro- and microarchitecture, as well as intrinsic properties of bone materials.
* Bone remodeling is crucial for maintaining bone structure and strength.

column1: * Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a chronic disease affecting nerve fibers in the brain and spinal cord.

column2: * MS patients are at higher risk of osteoporosis and fractures due to immobility and long-term glucocorticoid therapy.
* Management of MS requires long-term disease-modifying therapy.

column1: * Patients with MS have lower bone mineral density (BMD) compared to healthy controls.

column2: * Vertebral BMD is affected to a lesser degree than femoral BMD in MS patients.
* Progressive forms of MS show more severe loss of BMD than relapsing-remitting MS.

column1: * Immobilization in MS patients can lead to bone loss and increased fracture risk.

column2: * Disability and glucocorticoid therapy contribute to bone loss in MS patients.
* Vitamin D deficiency and muscle weakness also play a role in osteoporosis development.

column1: * Assessment of clinical risk factors and BMD measurement are important in evaluating bone health in MS patients.

column2: * Exercise, calcium, and vitamin D supplementation are recommended for preventing bone loss in MS patients.
* Pharmacological therapy, such as bisphosphonates or anabolic agents, may be necessary for patients at high risk of fractures.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 10, 'n_subpoints': 3, 'symbol': '*'}"
796,"<summary>
• Malaria is a widespread disease caused by parasites transmitted through mosquito bites, with common symptoms including fever, chills, and weakness.

column2: • Treatment with chloroquine and primaquine can lead to a reduction in fever and pain symptoms, but may also cause gastrointestinal issues and hemolysis.

column1: • Adverse effects of chloroquine and primaquine include gastrointestinal symptoms, changes in vision, and hemolytic anemia, especially in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency.

column2: • Health care providers should be aware of potential side effects and take measures to minimize them during malaria treatment.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 2, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '•'}"
797,"<summary>
* The life span of humans has increased globally, leading to a higher proportion of elderly individuals in the population.

column2: * Elderly men often experience lower urinary tract symptoms (LUTS), erectile dysfunction (ED), and decreased libido simultaneously.

column1: * Studies have shown a strong correlation between sexual dysfunction, age, and the severity of LUTS.

column2: * LUTS and ED prevalence increase with age and are often present together.

column1: * The pathophysiological link between LUTS and ED is not fully understood, but hypotheses suggest autonomic nervous system overactivation and hormonal imbalance.

column2: * Lifestyle changes, such as nocturia and sleep disorders, may impact ED occurrence.

column1: * Treatment with alpha-blockers has shown to improve LUTS and sexual dysfunction in patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

column2: * Concomitant administration of alpha-blockers and anticholinergics may enhance LUTS improvement and potentially sexual function.

column1: * A study on male patients with LUTS/BPH and ED found that a combination of tamsulosin and solifenacin improved LUTS but did not significantly impact sexual function.

column2: * Improvement in voiding symptoms was associated with enhanced sexual function in patients receiving tamsulosin alone, but not in those receiving both medications.

column1: * Further research is needed to understand the relationship between LUTS, BPH, and ED, as well as the effectiveness of different treatment approaches.
</summary>",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
798,"<summary>
* Specific miRNAs are expressed in a cell type-specific manner, at specific developmental stages, and in disease states including cancer.

column2: * MiRNAs can act as oncogenes or tumor suppressors during cancer initiation and progression.

column1: * MiRNA expression profiles differ between normal and cancerous tissues of the endometrium, breast, and ovary.

column2: * MiRNAs can affect the expression of proteins involved in cancer-relevant pathways such as apoptosis and metastasis.

column1: * Epithelial to mesenchymal transition (EMT) is a process involved in cancer progression, with miR-200 family members playing a role in this process.

column2: * ZEB1 and ZEB2 are transcription factors involved in EMT and are targeted by the miR-200 family.

column1: * Loss of miR-200c is associated with chemoresistance and aggressiveness in breast, ovarian, and endometrial cancers.

column2: * MiR-200c can repress ZEB1 and ZEB2, as well as other mesenchymal genes.

column1: * ZEB1 and miR-200c regulate each other in a double-negative feedback loop, impacting the epithelial and mesenchymal states of cells.

column2: * The effects of miR-200c on migration, invasion, adhesion, and chemosensitivity are independent of E-cadherin expression.

column1: * MiR-200c downregulates TUBB3, a protein associated with resistance to microtubule-targeting agents, leading to increased chemosensitivity.

column2: * The enhanced chemosensitivity is not solely due to increased proliferation but also to the downregulation of TUBB3.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 6, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"
799,"<summary>
* The transobturator approach for treating female stress urinary incontinence was first described by Delorme and later refined by De Leval to reduce complications.

column2: * Meta-analysis found similar cure rates for retropubic, outside-in transobturator, and inside-out transobturator midurethral sling procedures.

column1: * Anatomical studies confirmed the safety of both obturator approaches from a neurovascular perspective.

column2: * Traditional anatomical dissections do not allow for studying the tape's configuration in relation to the urethra.

column1: * A cadaveric study compared the relationship between the tape and urethra in inside-out and outside-in approaches using CT scan image analysis.

column2: * The in-out approach had a more acute angle around the urethra compared to the flatter trajectory of the out-in approach.

column1: * Radiographic visualization showed the tapes lying posterior/dorsal to the urethra and a safe distance from the obturator canal for both techniques.

column2: * The in-out approach buried the tape deeper inside the internal adductor muscles, while the out-in approach stayed closer to the ischiopubic ramus.

column1: * Clinical implications include the need for careful rotation around the ischiopubic ramus in the in-out passage and full thickness vaginal epithelial layer dissection in the out-in passage.

column2: * Three-dimensional ultrasonography may allow for dynamic measurements of tape trajectories in vivo and correlation with clinical outcomes.

column2: * Some schools saw sustained progress even after the programme ended.

860,"<summary>
• The Children, Young People and Education Committee discussed the progressing condition of the Schools Challenge Cymru program.

column2: • Members present included Lynne Neagle AM, Kirsty Williams AM, Steve Davies, and Ruth Conway.

column3: • No apologies for absence were received.
• Members declared any interests.
• The inquiry focused on targeted funding to improve educational outcomes.
• Kirsty Williams AM discussed the targeting of the pupil development grant (PDG) and its impact on educational outcomes.
• The discussion highlighted the importance of individual interventions for children eligible for free school meals.
• The concept of growth mindset and attachment disorder training were mentioned as examples of effective interventions.
• The eligibility criteria for free school meals as a proxy for need was discussed.
• Flexibility in eligibility criteria and longer-term projections were considered.
• The impact of PDG on attendance, engagement, and attainment of free-school-meal pupils was evaluated.
• The use of PDG for more able and talented children was emphasized.
• The importance of guidance, awareness, and measures for appropriate PDG usage was highlighted.
• The discussion also touched on the potential changes in eligibility criteria and the impact of universal credit on identifying relative need.
• The flexibility in eligibility criteria and the potential impact of changes in the PDG allocation process were considered.
• The discussion shifted to the practical uses of PDG, with a focus on targeted funding for vulnerable learners.
• The impact of PDG on attendance, engagement, and educational outcomes for vulnerable learners was explored.
• The discussion also addressed the targeting of PDG for looked-after and adopted children.
• The challenges and strategies for supporting looked-after and adopted children were discussed.
• The impact of PDG on attainment and exclusion rates among looked-after children was evaluated.
• The need for a multi-agency approach and investment in well-being to support vulnerable learners was emphasized.
• The transition from Schools Challenge Cymru to regional consortia and the lessons learned from the program were discussed.
• The importance of leadership, systems, processes, teacher quality, and collaborative activity in school improvement efforts was highlighted.
• The ongoing support for schools and the focus on sustained progress post-Programme completion were emphasized.
• The engagement with Professor Mel Ainscow and the evaluation of the Schools Challenge Cymru program were discussed.
•",0,"{'n_points': 7, 'n_subpoints': 4, 'symbol': '•'}"

875,"<summary>
• PhD D has been working on spectral subtraction, applying it with an overestimation factor to estimate noise and subtract it from the signal spectrum.

column2: • The gain of the filter in spectral subtraction varies over time, causing musical noise and negative values in the spectrum.
• PhD D implemented nonlinear smoothing on the gain trajectory to reduce musical noise and improve results.

column1: • The smoothing in the time domain did not completely eliminate musical noise, but reduced it in the mel frequency bands.

column2: • The smoothing approach helped in reducing the spots of high energy randomly distributed in the spectrogram, characteristic of musical noise.

column1: </summary>",0,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 2, 'symbol': '•'}"
876,"<summary>
* The meeting discussed the use of a belief-net system for decision-making tasks.

column2: * The system would extract properties from different tasks and use them in specific Bayes-nets for decision-making.

column1: * The goal was to create a general system that could be applied to various tasks and generate powerful generalizations.

column2: * The system would use deep cognitive linguistics to extract deep semantic information from constructions.

column1: * The meeting also touched on the idea of a ""cognitive dispatcher"" module to gather and recombine information for decision-making.

column2: * This module would analyze object trees and fill in missing parts to make decisions.

column1: * The architecture would allow for flexibility and potential replacement of components in the future.

column2: * The focus was on creating a system that could be decoupled from specific problems and generalize over different tasks.

column1: * The meeting concluded with plans to continue meeting in the same location and reflections on the performance of a test subject in the study.

column2: * The test subject showed strengths and weaknesses in decision-making tasks, providing valuable insights for the system's development.

column1: </summary>",1,"{'n_points': 5, 'n_subpoints': 1, 'symbol': '*'}"

* Dr. Blaney highlighted the uncertainty surrounding relationships with the EU and potential financial impacts.
* Bethan Owen mentioned a decrease in EU and non-EU student applications to Welsh institutions.
* They discussed the challenges facing the Welsh higher education sector, including funding, student recruitment, pay and pension costs, and infrastructure investment.
* The impact of Brexit on student mobility, research funding, and academic quality was also addressed.
* The need for increased investment in research and the importance of engaging with charitable sector research funding were highlighted.
* The committee noted several letters from the Welsh Government regarding education and childcare funding.

column2: • The Bill is not addressing child abuse but prohibiting all forms of physical punishment.

column3: • The United Nations Committee on the Rights of the Child recognizes any physical punishment of children as incompatible with their human rights.

column1: • Parents and professionals have different views on the Bill, with some supporting and others opposing it.

column2: • Parents who oppose the Bill believe they understand the difference between child abuse and a light smack from a loving parent.

column3: • The Bill aims to provide the same protection from physical punishment to children as adults.

column1: • Concerns have been raised about the potential increase in reporting and workload for social services, schools, and other agencies.

column2: • The impact on social services, schools, and other agencies will depend on the frequency of reporting and referrals.

column3: • The implementation group is working on addressing potential challenges and gaps in service provision.

column1: • The Bill's provisions have been assessed in relation to the European Convention on Human Rights, including articles on the right to respect for private life, freedom of conscience and religion, protection from torture, and discrimination.

column2: • The Government believes the Bill's provisions are necessary and proportionate to protect children's rights and freedoms.

949,"<summary>

• Emergency legislation will provide Welsh Ministers with powers to temporarily close schools or other educational institutions, direct resources, and relax requirements around ratios in childcare settings.
• Powers include the ability to temporarily close or direct the opening of institutions, direct staff to other locations, and suspend or direct food provision.
• Flexibilities may be granted to relax nutrition requirements in schools providing food and to adjust childcare ratios.
• Insurance coverage for disruptions due to government directions may not be guaranteed, as insurance companies may not consider it a disruption to business.
• The Minister is not an expert on insurance, but insurance companies may not pay out for disruptions even if directed by the government.
• Insurance companies may not consider disruptions due to government directions as eligible for coverage.
• Insurance coverage for disruptions due to government directions may not be guaranteed.

* The legislation may help in situations where the Government directs closures, but insurance coverage may still be a challenge.
* Insurance companies may not pay out for disruptions to business even if directed by the Government.
* The Minister is not an expert on insurance, but discussions around insurance coverage have been a topic of concern.
* Insurance coverage for disruptions due to Government directions may vary depending on the insurance company's policies.
* The Minister has faced challenges in ensuring that directions from the Government are recognized by insurance companies, such as in the case of cancelling school trips abroad.
* Insurance companies may require specific criteria to be met for coverage in situations of Government-directed closures or disruptions.

* Student maintenance payments will continue as normal, and efforts are being made to ensure continuity of learning through online platforms and support services.
* The Minister is working with institutions to maintain services and support students during the pandemic.
* Emergency legislation will provide flexibility for directing resources, suspending activities, and making decisions to ensure the continuity of education and support services.

957,"<summary>
* The meeting discussed functional requirements for a new remote control design.
* Research showed users disliked current remote controls and wanted more user-friendly options.
* Most irrelevant functions were audio settings and screen settings for brightness and color.
* The new remote control should target users below forty and incorporate a screen and speech recognition.
* Younger users are more open to advanced functions, while older users prefer simpler options.
* The design should be fashionable, user-friendly, and reflect corporate identity.
* The remote control should have a power button, channel and volume selection, and channel programming options.
* Other functions include sound adjustments like treble, bass, and pitch, as well as screen settings for brightness and color.
* The design should include LED lights under buttons for visual feedback.
* The User Interface Designer will focus on designing the menu layout for the LCD screen.
* The Industrial Designer will focus on the physical layout and functionality of the remote control.
* The Project Manager will organize the information and write the meeting minutes.
